I'm surprised by the number of interesting businesses that dot the Alberta Avenue neighborhood.  Popular bakery is exactly one of those.  Old school, been there, been renovated etc., this bakery carries the charm of an old neighborhood like none other. 

They're a portuguese bakery and cafe, with reasonable amount of seating space and big glass windows that makes this place inviting and worth it.  The coffee is nothing great, I'll be honest, but then again if you want coffee that you're going to drink in Portugal, you better expect it not to be Italian.  What I would highly recommend is their single serving custard pies.  So freakin' delicious and goes great with a warm cup of latte.  

The bakery section looks nice but I haven't bought anything other than their ciabatta buns.  Those buns are creating quite a wave around in Edmonton.  Popularized by Drift Food truck who make great use of them in their sandwiches, these buns are so delicious and worth their price at 6 buns for $2.25.  Spongy, tasty and capable of holding a lot of material in it, these buns are certainly my favorite in Edmonton.

I would love to come again and not only shop for buns but try some of their sandwiches etc.  I love how affordable this place is, yet is all neat and tidy.  I could totally picture myself doing work here, if my work warranted sitting on a laptop in a coffee shop (well, on some days it does).

I came here to meet up some friends. They love this place and I thought I would give it a go. The bartender was amazing and super helpful in choosing a beer for me. I tried the Pork Bahn Mi. I have to say that for some crazy reason this sandwich has become a major trend in most restaurants. The Bahn Mi at Twenty Tap is probably one of my favorites. I love how they serve it with dill pickles on the side and the french fries are perfect. I can't wait to go again and try the Poutine. The menu is varied so it offers something for everyone and is not over pretentious. They also offer Vegan options which I think are awesome. If you're looking for a new spot to try I suggest this one!!!

This was such a fun, enchanting wine bar to spend some time in. This would be a great place to come with some girlfriends or a date (or really, anyone!). The tasting room is super cute. My in-laws and I each had a flight of reds. I loved that the wines come with a description and the name; so often I forget what I had to drink and am not able to really compare flavors, so this was really fun! I wish I were local, but we get up to Santa Barbara at least a couple times a year so I'll definitely be back. I was bummed I didn't get to try a cupcake flight- next time for sure! They also had some games, so my husband and mother-in-law played jenga in the corner (how cute is that?).

Arnold's is the absolute best place in Nashville for southern food. Everything is cooked just right and tastes amazing. You cannot go wrong with Arnold's. You can kiss the Loveless Cafe and Cracker Barrel goodbye! My favorites at Arnold's are the roast beef, macaroni and cheese, green beans, carrots and spicy chocolate pie. Arnold's is a family owned and operated,restaurant and is the food is served cafeteria style. Don't let the small building and the long line out the door turn you away, as the wait through the line goes fast!

Cajun Seafood has a vibe that's a cross between a cafeteria and a carryout, because it is both of those things, and hot seafood served in a plastic bag is part of the charm/experience.  Bucking the trend, had a grilled shrimp po boy on a bun and a boiled potato. The po boy was awesome, really flavorful and not overcooked.  The potato was kind of bland and didn't soak up much of the cajun seasoning, but I still liked it, though admittedly, I love potatoes and have rarely met one that I didn't like.  I also tried some of my sister's boiled crab legs and shrimp, which were delicious, but only  shrimp were really spicy.  

I would be willing to eat any of these things again, but everything was so good that I'd be curious to also try every other menu item.  Highly recommended.

I always get delivery so I forget to check in and write a review. 

First of all, we always get one cheese pizza because it's one of the best in town. It's the only pizza in town that the whole family can agree on. 

Salads are another must-have. I know salads aren't really something to comment on but they do it right. They make a Greek salad that even my 5 year old LOVES. 

Tater tots and fried mozzarella are typical bar food and pretty good. Sandwiches are also above average. 

Like so many others have said, the main great thing about this place is the people. Very down to earth and make the atmosphere of no anchovies a place you just wanna hang out. Not pretentious or trendy. 

They have been doing what they do for a while and they're good at it.

When I asked the front desk lady at the hotel I was staying at for a great lunch place, she recommended me Mr. B's bistro, emphasizing their BBQed shrimp. Of course I was hyped, more so because this was my first ever meal in New Orleans.  The shrimp itself was outstanding. I don't think I've ever had such fat, juicy mouthwatering shrimp in my life (drooling as I'm writing this review). All  the shrimps were gigantic as if they were on steroids. 

I had to look at the menu twice (or three times) to make sure $1.50 martini and Bloody Mary wasn't a typo. It wasn't!!! Not a big fan of either one, but I couldn't pass on such a deal. It was only my first meal in NOLA and I was already in love. Before I even ordered my food. 

Catfish fingers are literally meant to be eaten with fingers only. I tried to use a fork, and it just fell apart. And you have to hold it so lightly so you don't break it to pieces. It was delicious though not too special. Coconut beer shrimp was ok. Mr. B's BBQed shrimp was the winner, as expected, and I wish I'd ordered a full portion for myself, instead of sharing between me and one other person. I don't like messy food, meaning, having to peel and work for the food I eat, but I didn't mind working for this one at all. Licking the sauce off of my fingers was the best part. 

Also, I am not ashamed to admit that I asked for the complimentary bread 4 times. So good!

The wife and I stopped in on a Sunday morning to continue our breakfast/brunch tour of Indy. We LOVE rockstone pizza and live right by Sahms Place, but unfortunately neither of those are open at 8am (although Sahms does do brunch later in the day)

We arrived about 8 and were seated immediately. As quickly as we could order it, coffee was at the table. We debated a while, but both settled on pancakes. I went with my token choice of bacon in the cakes and added a poached egg. 

I'm going to start with the egg: 100% perfectly poached. The cakes...tasted weird. They didn't taste bad, but they wouldn't make me want to come back. 

After eating I saw some egg dishes come out with sides of bread and remembers the yelp reviews talking about homemade bread. I think your best bet here is probably eggs with bread. 

Unfortunately, we had great service but I can't award more than 3 stars based on those mediocre pancakes. But, we promised ourselves we would try them again and eat eggs and homemade bread.

The food here is pretty good. I waited an HOUR AND A HALF for a table! We had a large group sure and they gave us a 35-40 minute wait, but after that time had passed they told us it would be another 35-40 minutes. I think it's just standard operating procedure for restaurants in New Orleans to have huge waits. 

The waiter, Charles was friendly but I think things slipped his mind-it could've easily have been a double shot of Wild Turkey he admitted to taking because he was working New Years' Eve. He passed me a cup of gumbo I didn't order and forgot my buddy's side of black eyed peas.

I liked the food-the gator sausage was delicious it was spiced right, fried up and the sauce was tangy. The meatloaf, was okay but the greens and mac and cheese were kind of eh, tons of hot sauce and salt barely saved my mustard greens. I love Frenchmen street though but I wouldn't frequent this place again.

I really loved Strange Donuts when they opened up their original store in Maplewood, but over the years the premise has changed and it doesn't spark as much joy as it initially did. 

I used to look forward to all their special donut creations coming out watching them intently on social media. I remember the super long lines that would form outside the doors each weekend evening. 

On my last visit my husband and I were the only ones there. It had been years since I had been in, but I had a coupon for a free Creation Done in our STL Experience Book we wanted to redeem before the end of the year. Strange Donuts had a special Andes Mint Done for $5, so we decided to use our coupon on that and pay the difference.

The mint icing was pretty good, with a ball of fudge in the center topped with Andes Mint pieces. But the chocolate donuts stacked together were pretty dry and bland. Not like the dones I once knew and loved.  

Obviously Strange Donuts is doing well since they've expanded so much, but I really miss the dones of yesteryear.

The only reason this is a two star review is because the woman behind the counter was SO nice. Otherwise, this would be a one star review. 

We had a voucher (worth $24) because we were staying next door at the Nestle Inn. We each ordered the breakfast sandwiches on wheat bread and mochas. Choice of "sides" was vanilla yogurt or banana, so we ordered one of each. 

My breakfast sandwich consisted of very dry wheat bread (butter? Please???), some kind of steamed (?) whipped egg patty filled with chopped ham, and some semi-melted cheddar. (The way the sandwich is described on the menu, I was imagining something closer to an Egg McMuffin, with a fried egg and a slice of ham.) Oh, and a whole, unpeeled and un-apeeling banana. Jean's breakfast was the same, except she had a little bowl of overly sweet vanilla yogurt. The mochas, while lovely to look at, were extremely sweet. The sweetness overwhelmed any other flavor in the drink. 

The plate my breakfast was served on was chipped in three or four places. Seriously? I understand plates get chipped at restaurants, and I can overlook one or even two chips. But this plate was chipped on three of four sides (square plate). Tacky, even for a coffee shop. 

Yes, the woman behind the counter was super friendly. She let us stand there for five minutes trying to decide what to order and was helpful explaining what was available for "brunch". If this was a review just for service it would be four or five stars. But it's for the food and the food AND coffee was not good. We won't be back. It's a shame, great location and so much potential.

I plan on going back, even if desert disappointed me.

The Gretchen sandwich ($7.50) is awesome - egg, bacon, cheese on a tasty buttered toasted bread. I added the provided tomato as well. Also? I ordered sausage and potatoes and proceeded to pile those on as well, plus some of the salsa the potatoes came with. Win! 

The potatoes are alright ($3 small, $4 large). They have some garlic and other items with them but I like my potatoes with more seasoning and increased browning. The sausage ($3) is a thick sausage , not your tiny link or patty. My friend got the black bean patty and portobello patty. Both are tasty! 

Tip: thinking about the portobello sandwich? It's $8.50. Or just order the portobello patty for $3.50. It just means you don't get the bread and couple toppings, but heck of a deal!

Finally, dessert...our lovely waiter asked if we wanted some pie. Sure! Chocolate peanut butter pie is the best!! But...sweet merciful Odin. It was $5 and a tiny slice. Very rich, ganache chocolate with some good whipped cream on the side. The problem? THIS IS NOT PIE. Sure, some pies are not fluffy or gooey, like Derby pie or pecan pie. But pies in general are gooey awesomeness - like apple, chocolate, coconut, etc. This "pie" is more of a cheesecake texture. I loved my visit, but honestly the fake pie was a huge downer. Where can I find homemade delicious pie in this city?!?!

Otherwise, surprisingly reasonably priced for broad ripple and tasty. Can't wait to try the other menu items!

I came to this outlet mall back in July when I was in Florida and loved every minute of shopping I did here. Since these outlets are pretty new it made the experience nicer. They have a good selection of stores to choose from and you can definitely catch some good deals depending on when you go. They have dining options such as Auntie Anne's, Johnny Rockets, Starbucks, Haagen-Dazs, and more! If you're looking for something fun to do check out Tampa Premium Outlets!

Although I'm not much of a beer fan, I was excited to check out King's Road Brewery. I love the BYOF concept and stopped in at nearby Passariellos for a takeout order of their gourmet pizza and fries before I settled in at Kings Road. The brewery is pretty small, so if you're planning to eat dinner there and definitely need a table it may be a good idea to secure the table first and have someone from your party wait at the table while other grab food (or order delivery). However, if you do manage to snag a table they're plenty roomy and the brewery is well decorated and warm.

 I ended up getting a flight of beer which was reasonably priced at $10. I typically don't enjoy beer, but I was a huge fan of the Pawnee Chocolate Coffee stout (whether this beer is named after Pawnee, Indiana in Parks and Rec or is just a coincidence remains to be seen). This beer had a distinct coffee flavor that I haven't tasted in other coffee beers before. I tried a few others which were not particularly noteworthy but all in all it was a great experience. Kings Road is a great place to spend a chill evening with good food and drink!

(I think I may be giving it 5 stars for sentimental reasons, but I've also got some legit claims)

So I grew up in a white Jewish neighborhood. Sometimes my father, who was African American, just had to flee the scene to get a taste of his childhood. This meant that we'd often make our way down Broad Street to Sid Booker's. If you can get past the bullet-proof screen and the little lazy-susan they use to take in cash and serve up fried goodies, I recommend you stop by once in your life.

Oh, this place may be in what you consider the "ghetto" but it ain't cheap (honestly, if it were cheap, I'd be concerned about the ingredients they were using) so hit the ATM first. I don't really love shrimp, but I do adore Sid Booker's fried version. Large, plump, tender, and with a crisp batter that will make your arteries weep. We'd take our foil wrapped bundles home and have a little feast as if we were in Richmond with the family and not in Elkins Park. The ladies there are always kind, but they do a brisk business at certain times of day so don't expect a whole lot of chit chat.

Note: This is take-out only and you're going to have to wait on the corner or in your car for a bit while they get your order ready. Contrary to El S.' review, I don't think you're likely to get taken down in a drive-by here as there are usually lots of folks. But like any denizen of a city, I wouldn't be hoppin' in the car for shrimp at 11pm if I wasn't a card-carrying member of that particular 'hood.

Love this place. Some people might disagree but it's one of the best restaurants that I've been to in Edmonton. The food is exceptional and the staff provides friendly and attentive service. The decor is far from contemporary or modern but I always enjoy it when I'm there because it has a more authentic charming feel to it with many art pieces.

I have tried many of the dishes here and they've all been good. Most recently I came with three others and we shared the tom kar and tom yum soups, mango salad, pad thai and pa-nang beef curry. All delicious. Top it off with some coconut rice and a thai iced tea and the meal is complete. The staff came around at least three or four times to refill our water. From previous experience here, the one thing I'm not fond of are the spring rolls so I tend to stay away from that. 

I used to live literally a block and a half away from Numchok Wilai. Unfortunately not anymore. This review serves as a reminder for me to go back more often. Anyone looking for some thai food or looking to change up their dining experience, I would recommend this place in a heartbeat as I have to many friends and coworkers.

Another Uber Eats review here, because dining out just ain't it yet.

As always, we preheat our oven when meals are on the way, this goes a long way to helping your orders, y'all. 

We ordered the Pork Belly Kimchi fried rice, the Pad thai with tofu and of course, a churro with chocolate sauce.

I wasn't able to taste the fried rice due to an allergy, but souse says it was incredible. Like he LOVED it. My pad thai was very good, I loved the flavor. I think they go easier with the fish sauce and I appreciate that. My regret (and it's totally on me!) is that I forgot to ask for spice. I wont forget next time.

The churro was put in the 200 degree oven while we ate our mains. By the time we were ready for it, the churro had reheated perfectly and was as if it had come straight from the fryer. Not gonna lie, this churro was fantastic. It was crispy, chewy, well cooked and well sugared. The sauce was also very good. Next time I will branch out and try one of the fancier ones. Can't wait!

So what is a spaghetteria?  My vision is of a cafeteria that serves spaghetti.  Maybe you grab a tray and a bowl of spaghetti, then hold the bowl under a spigot that applies the sauce of your choice; red, white, meatball... plunk plunk.  A place you might take your grandma if you don't like her a lot.  Certainly never a date.  That's my vision - I'm glad to report the real restaurant is nothing like this.

Arrived with the family Friday night about 7 - no reservations required, but the place was maybe half full.  They are in and old building with a cool brick parking lot.   I would guess the history of this property was industrial.  The transformation to restaurant looks like it was done a while back...feels kind of like a Caleco's, early 90's.  Comfortable and casual.  We actually liked the ambience.  

Service was excellent and very friendly.   Food was good.  The wife  ordered the cannelloni special.  I thought it was pretty good, but there was some kind of spice in there she didn't really like.   I had "Verone" spaghetti, which had roasted garlic, chicken, spinach and sun-dried tomatoes.  Too much garlic for my taste, but I'm sure a garlic lover would be in heaven.   My daughter had a pepperoni pizza and it was really good (mozzarella and lots of it).  Unfortunately, the only size they could bring us was 12 inch so she needed about a fourth of it.   The leftovers made a great lunch a couple of days later. 

The prices are very reasonable and, even though our food didn't blow us away, we really liked the place.  Portions were huge, pizza was great, it was apparent they care about quality and service was excellent.   This would be a great place to grab a pizza before a Cardinals or Blues game.  We'll be back for sure.

Okay this place ROCKS. Vibes inside are exactly what you'd want from a coffee shop - hipster meets businessperson meets mid-20s coffee date. My friends and I just stopped in here as I had to speed off for work, but I wish I had time to sit and enjoy the lovely atmosphere. I got an iced vanilla latte which was good, not the best I've had, but the peanut butter banana toast.... I know plain and simple but theirs was AWESOME. I really didn't know pb banana toast could be fancy but they I want to say flambé? the banana and then drizzle this unreal honey on it. It was dreamy. I wish there was one closer to me but next time I'm in Tampa I'll definitely be stopping by.

I took last year off (I think? I don't remember going) from po-boy fest, so the last time I had been there before returning this year was the 2010 fest - this was when the lines really started getting crazy-insane. I'm not too claustrophobic, but even the 2010 lines made me a little queasy and panicky. 

Fast forward to 2012 - I'm not sure whether all these changes were new to this year or in 2011, but I really appreciated that they did away with having a main stage right at Carrollton and Oak. Really seemed to cut down on the bottleneck at the very beginning. Also, the mobile beer vendors were excellent! Anytime I needed a beer, I never had to go more than half a block. 

I LOVED that Bike Easy provided free valet bicycle parking. What a fantastic service. There were even some nice guys who helped me out with a quick pro bono tire tuneup, which was much appreciated. I'm not sure how widely advertised the valet service was, since I saw tons of bikes locked up on fences around the fest. 

There are still damn long lines and big crowds at Po-Boy Fest. If you truly get panicky around big lines or crowds, Po-Boy Fest is probably not for you. That said, I was in an epic long line (Jacques-Imos) that actually moved pretty fast. 

One suggestion: I wish there were a few more sweets vendors. It was hard to find a way to satisfy my sweet tooth after chowing down on po-boys.

I think this is one of my favorite festivals in New Orleans, but then I'm a glutton who loves excuses to eat anytime, anywhere.

I've been wanting to go here, but I've been resisting for some reason.  I had a BOGO coupon so I figured what the heck.  Well, I love it!  The pizzas are made fresh in front of you, and with the exception of the cheese and one-topping, they are all one price.  

When you walk in you get to choose your pizza type, and if you build your own you get to advance to the toppings station which is mind blowing!  Tons of amazing, fresh meat and veggie toppings for every taste.  If i have lots of veggies available, I don't even need meat, and trust me, there are plenty to choose from!  You can also pick your sauce, and I recommend the spicy red sauce.  VERY spicy, but super flavorful and satisfying.  

Once built the pizzas are slung into a fire oven and they come out AMAZING AND HOT!  So crispy and perfectly cooked from crust to center.  They have lots of salads, and some desserts near the checkout to go with your pizza, and I assume they are personal sized (oh boy that's embarrassing if they're not), but they have boxes out for leftovers.  

I went on Friday after work, and it was dead...I was the only customer there, but I bet they are slammed at lunch.  I can easily see this becoming a once-a-week staple for me.

Since I live close to the loop, by go to art supply store is Blick. However, I've been here once and it is fantastic!

When I was here, they had bristol paper on sale and that made me really excited. I also browsed through their random sale items section and it was great. I guess the situation was perfect mostly because I was looking to make a birthday package for my best friend who lives in NYC. I got funky pens and a tiny notebook for her here. She called to tell me she LOVED them. 

Additionally, this place has a larger supply of pretty decorative paper than Blick. I was really impressed by their selection. If I get into book binding again, I'm totally coming back here for paper!

ALL THE STARS! This place is exactly what it wants to be, and I love it. It's dark. It kinda feels like you could be in a diff country. Great beer selection. Great cocktails. Fantastic food, especially brunch. Good service, in their own way. This isn't an episode of Pioneer Woman, so don't expect that - but the bartenders/servers are cool and eclectic and polite enough. Just go, this place is cool and dripping w/ character the kind of which is perfect for Philly.

My friends and I were going to go to Biscuit Love, but decided we wanted a more diverse menu. Every one of us enjoyed our meals, from Biscuits, Juices, Smoothies, Bowls, etc. Great atmosphere and decent prices. Happy that we went here over going to Biscuit Love.

We stopped by Sun King and thought we would check out the new Oca restaurant/shop inside. Oca, meaning "Goose", is a spin-off for Goose the Market that opened inside the public area of the brewery. Although they hadn't "officially" announced they were open, I had heard that they were open in the evenings and were working through a soft opening process. So glad we stopped by!

My wife and I both tried one of the bundled French Bread sandwiches. Tonight's featured City Ham and Gruyere with Dijon mustard, tarragon, and mini sweet pickles (cornichons). I placed our order at the counter, paid, and gave my name. They asked if I wanted the sandwiches toasted (yes!) and that allowed me time to pick up a couple drafts at the Sun King counter. As soon as I was making my way back to our table, the Oca staff called out my name and I was good to go. 

I loved the crispy crunch of the bread and the toasting brought out the flavors of the ham and cheese. Excellent pairing for the spices too. Can't wait to come back to try some of the sausages and charcuterie. 

*****update******
I made it back one evening and decided to try the Choucrote Garnie which may as well translate to "meat lover's dream!"  Actually, it's a "traditional dish of France's Alsace region bordering Germany" and the Choucrote is fermented cabbage while the Garnie means it is dressed with Riesling (white wine), herbs, potatoes, and charcuterie.

 This huge option is brought out in a roasting pan.  My eyes started to glaze over at all the meats.  In the center was a large peppery Knack(wurst) nestled over a large serving of the Choucrote.  To the left was a thick (a full inch) smoked rib chop that was the most tender pork chop I've had.  In the upper left corner were two Nuremberg sausage (technically much larger at about 5 inches instead of the 9 cm traditional).  The Nuremberg have a thicker casing and more in the Bratwurst family.  To the right of the Knack were a couple slices of Pancetta that looked like American bacon, but have a higher salt content.  Just below that, there were two Strasbourg frankfurters.  Oh, and there were two potatoes that were halved and roasted.

The Choucrote itself was a great surprise at how much I enjoyed it.  My mother used to make a really nasty version of sauerkraut and dressed it with white vinegar.  I hated it!  But here, the pungent odor of vinegar is replaced by the pleasing notes of the Riesling.  The sour of the dish is tempered as well, so the overall taste is quite pleasing, especially since it is warm and served thoroughly tender. (I am not a fan of the sometimes rubbery and tough texture of raw cabbage.)

The portion size suggests it is for two to four people.  They mean it on this dish!  I made really great headway on devouring the dish, but common sense struck me before I was stuffed and decided to get a to go box.  Not for the picky eater, this is a dish that goes great with a dark beer (I went with the Sun King "Stuck in the Middle" Milk Stout option. Yum!)

*****back to the original review*****

As if I didn't have enough reasons to stop by Sun King already, now I can get great quality sandwiches while there. Note that Oca sells packaged meats to take home if you stop by to fill your growler.

Tech stuff: They are open generally the same hours as the brewery.  Parking is free in the Sun King lot.  A number of platters are meant for 2 to 4 people, so bring friends!

Review #439
Rev #30

Great service but the main courses were Ok at best. We started with a free appetizer courtesy of Yelp, check-in offer. We had Garlic Fries. Those were good and a twist on just fries. They prepare these with garlic and taste good. It's not a big plate and at a regular price of $6.95 , I would not have paid for them.

I ate their Mango salsa Jerk chicken taco, served with black beans and white rice. I thought great sweat mango salsa will be a great balance to the spicey flavor that I love in good jerk. Instead what I got was all sweat. The "jerk" chicken tasted bland and not warm. Plus the taco shell had that not so crisp taste.

My son ordered the pizza from the adult menu, I thought , well worst case I can help hm finish or take part with me. Small portion for $12. Ok taste, nothing to go nuts about. My wife and daughter split a cheese burger that they ate, but said tasted ok.

Overall, I was disappointed a bit with this place. I have eaten at the GB in Washington DC and we loved that place nd had expected similar here. I was let down, I'll give them maybe another try, but with so many options in NOLA, it maybe a while.

My husband has lived in Chinatown for 25+ years and has never tried Ray's cafe, although he rationalizes that it must be good, b/c of how long it's been around!  I've lived in Chinatown for four years and have never tried Ray's Cafe before yesterday.  Although I just had tea - I was impressed and will definitely be back.  I met up with a new friend (who recently moved to the neighborhood) for coffee & tea.  Instead of going for the usual Starbucks, we decided to go for a hometown staple!  

I ordered the ginger tea and she ordered an iced coffee.  My ginger tea was delish and rivaled the home-made tea that my father-in-law makes especially for me.  My friend also raved about her iced coffee.

I would definitely be interested to go back and try some of the meal options (especially the leek dumplings, which I love from the local dim sum spot)!  Maybe I can even bump my 4 stars up to 5.

I love the atmosphere at Gelateria Del Leone. In the evening it's dimly lit, has plenty of comfortable seating, and it's as much of a coffee shop as it is a Gealteria. 

On my most recent visit I enjoyed some of their gelato on their adorable patio out back. They have cafe tables with a fountain in the middle and lights strung above. The patio feels like one of the best kept secrets of Tower Grove. It's a hidden little bungalow. It's getting a bit chilly so you might have to wait until spring to check it out. 

The staff is all friendly and the patrons seem to primarily consist of students studying away for their next exams. This is a great place to go with a couple friends, a date night, or even just to study alone. 5/5 would recommend.

I love and hate The Cake Bake Shop recently. Their desserts are pretty good. Definitely not the best I've ever had but probably the best in Indiana. The problem is they've got a great looking cafe and a great menu but their wait for to go is ridiculous. My wife and I were talking about it and we are almost certain that they make you wait an unnecessarily long time to get your dessert to just make the restaurant appear busier. 

We stopped in and ordered two pieces of pie today. They were busy yes but we waited 20 minutes after we placed the order just to get the two pieces. In their display case one of the pies already had a slice cut and sitting there. I just don't understand this type of service. Yes I get it you are probably trying to keep your restaurant looking busy but it really makes us think twice about even going and messing with the wait just for a dessert. Again Cake Bake, you are good but you are not that good!

If they aren't intentionally creating a wait then they definitely have a major flaw in their to go order work flow because they literally have at least 12-15 employees working simultaneously on any given weekend.

Probably the best liquor store I've been to in Edmonton. The variety is outstanding. Sometimes I can get overwhelmed when faced with the decision of which wine to buy. This place has handy stickers on wines that are staff top picks. It's a nice way to try new wines and find new favourites. I normally go for Aussie wines because I know more about those but this place is breaking me out of my comfort zone and allowing me to confidently try some Canadian wines.
Hubby loves this place for the beer selection. Quirky beers from all over the world, some gimmicky bottles with dinosaurs or James Bond (that he can't resist). Sherbrooke Liquor also stocks cans of Tennants Lager, which is bog standard in Glasgow and a little taste of home for us.

Great location and student friendly prices plus discounts. I love this place for its patio in the summer for a happy hour stein.  I wouldn't recommend this place for gourmet food or good conversation as its loud and dark inside.  Great for watching sports though

I'm not gonna lie. I won't do it. This place would have gotten five stars, if there wasn't a hiccup with the order. The açaí was really really really good and the fruits were super super super fresh. It tasted exactly like it should. It made me fall in love with açaí bowls. During the order, I guess there was a little mixup so we had to wait a bit longer to get our food. However, I will absolutely return here next time I'm in Santa Barbara to get some breakfast or a snacccccc

Russell Gardens Center in Churchville, Bucks County, Pa., may not be the largest nursery garden plantation in the region, but in my estimation it is one of the best. I have been shopping here since moving to Bucks and starting a garden around the house (The enterprise is never done).  Originally, I was tipped off to its existence by a nurseryman friend who helped me with design and bare root tree planting.  He swore by Russell's for perennials and colorful annuals and shrubs that most other dealers either lacked, or only possessed in inferior quality.

As an example, twenty years ago I bought a small pot of Coreopsis, a hardy fern-like leafy base with yellow star flowers that bloom in late June/early July, and spread to fill any space they are in.  Yesterday, I returned to see what was new in this native American beauty.  Now, they are available in a few shades of red/orange, and most strikingly, in a red/yellow flower that is breathtaking in its simplicity and kinship to its elder cousin.  Love at first sight. It is now planted across the walkway from the original, and it is easy to imagine its growth over the coming years.  

We purchased 3 other low growing, shade loving varieties to replace the old builder's grade junipers that had run their course.  Three Heuchera with rich dark maroon/gray foliage, two Veronica (Speedwell) that push up spikes of pale blue to indigo flowers in early June, and three low dark green/purple grasses that spread through their roots to cover bare soil and need little maintenance. They are all happily in place beneath the living room window. 

Always more work to do.  Plans call for a redo of the west side foundation plantings.  Russell Gardens will get the call as we lay out our plans.  Their inventory, knowledge and understanding of gardens and gardeners, makes it the place I trust most with suggestions and products. Prices are about the same as the other shops. 

Russell Gardens is why we dig in the earth.

I loved this packy & wish we had some up in New England! There are so many wines and champagnes to choose from and all at brilliantly low prices, my head was spinning! Total Wine & More was like a BJ's Wholesale Club a'la alcohol. They even have associates giving out little tastey samples. I really wish I had bought more but wasn't sure I'd have the luggage room. Bring TW&M up north please!

This is one of the worst schnucks I've ever been in. Better yet, one of the worst grocery stores I've ever been in. 

First off, the layout makes no sense. Food on both ends of the store separated by cards, diapers, and cleaning supplies in the middle? Why wouldn't it all be together? The store feels cramped due to lack of space, the aisles end right where the checkout lines start. It's difficult to get around. 

Secondly, does this store sell any bread besides bunny bread? Literally all we could find were some rolls in the schnucks bakery and a couple loves of bunny bread at the end of an aisle. 

Maybe my level of frustration was heightened because I was in on a Saturday and it happened to be the Saturday before "snowpocalypse" but I'm never going back to this location again.

More like 2.5 stars.This was my first visit to the "New improved Khyber" in a couple of years. Although the place underwent a much needed face lift, I'm sorry to say that our dining experience overall was just fair.

Our party of 5 arrived about 7 on a Sun. during Philly Beer Week.Found a table w/o a problem. Service was extremely slow. Was busy, but not crazy busy. Seemed a bit understaffed? The music was too loud at times; a pet peeve of mine. We're here to relax have some beers, a bite to eat, some conversation.

The food ranged from good to bad. The bacon grease popcorn was delicious and addicting.My 1/2 oyster/ shrimp po boy was tasty and authentic. The bread although toasted was a bit stale. The 3 shrimp and 3 oysters were nicely seasoned but small. The mac' n' cheese was standard. Served in a piping hot bowl topped w/ bread crumbs. It would have been better had it been creamier and more flavorful. I prefer a sharper cheese profile; like w/ some Romano? Filling, but not very satisfying. In New Orleans you can get a better po- boy at any dive bar for 2/3 of the price, but yes this is not NOLA. My mate loved his red beans & rice; his crawfish etoufee not so much.He thought the spices could have been cooked longer; to me it tasted like it just needed salt. His patrner got the muffuletta which she enjoyed,but could not finish. Our other friends got the ribs. Big mistake. They were huge, mostly bone. They complained that the meat was not tender- falling off the bone, and had an abundance of fat & gristle. When asked by our waiter how the food was, they told him and he gave a discount for the ribs. Nice gesture.

Glad to see the beer selection is still great. They were featuring Perennial Ales that day/ night and my Saison was outstanding. There probably will be a next time for me here, just for beer & popcorn.

OMG, I love having 5-ways with you Skyline.  5-way chili that is: spaghetti, chili, red beans, cheese, onions, mmmmm. 

Why aren't you in my hometown.  I guess I have to wait until next year when I make the annual Christmas family visit to get some more of your goodness.  Cincinnati style chili rocks and I believe the secret is cinnamon.  If you've never tried it, you must at least once.  This is one of my shameful Midwest obsessions, along with White Castle!  

Sadly, I must admit to smuggling some cans of Skyline home in my suitcase- not even close to the real thing.  Yuck, stick with the restaurant.

Happy hour 5-7. Half off wine and draft beer.

I wish I could write two separate reviews. One for happy hour and the other on food. For happy hour, you really can'y find a better place (price wise). The also have $2 Miller High Life all the time. 

My fiace stopped in for hh after checking in to our b&b. We had gone when it was the Sand Bar and it's always been tradition that we start our trips to New Hope there. As we walked, we realized they changed names, but where happy to see much of the staff was the same. We wer impressed to see the hh specials, so I partook in much wine before dinner. I peaked at a menu and was pleased to see they had more of a tapas style menu. I love tapas. Everything sounded great, so we made plans to return the next day for lunch. I give hh 5 stars. 

So we returne the next day, no wine this time around. Too much the night before. We sat at the bar and ordered the lunch box special. You can choose 3 options for $18. We ordered the Spaetzle Mac and Cheese, Curry Mussels, and Snails. Nothing tasted bad, just everything lacked seasoning. We were still a little hungry and asked what they had that had soffered a bit of a kick. The bartender suggested the Banh Mi Sliders. Didn't really hit the spot. We were really hoping to love the food, but overall we were disappointed.

If I could give 3.5 stars I would. I will definitely be going back to happy hour, but for dinner I'll dine at one of the many restaurants in New Hope.

I've been wanting to try Route 6 for months. A while back a friend told me that the menu included shrimp and grits which stimulates my salivary glands upon the mentioning of. For that reason, I brought my mother and sister here for Mother's Day last night. Shrimp and grits was not on the menu so, consequently, my salivary glands were not stimulated. 

The food was good but it wasn't slap ya' mama good (which is good in a way because if the food would have induced a slap to my mama she would've probably uppercut me). My mom and sister agreed that it was good but not slap ya' mama good. 

We ordered fried calamari, crab deviled eggs, and mussells for apps. The calamari and mussells were excellent. The crab deviled eggs were interesting. Not bad at all but not something I would order again. My sister had the rainbow trout which she said was good but not great. Mom dukes had the lobster roll. The bread looked really tasty. She enjoyed the roll but I've definitely seen her more excited over $8 buffalo wings. I had porgy which was the special for the night. It was grilled. Absolutely loved the crispy grilled taste. It was also really juicy. The flavor could have been a bit bolder though. It fell short in the flavor categoy. For sides, we had spinach and asparagus which, of course, were good enough. You could even taste the grill flavor in the asparagus-mmm. 

Our waitress, the hostesses, and the rest of the staff were great. The restaurant itself, including the furniture, the outdoor area, and decoration is really simple but cute. I love the white/brown/beige color scheme. It's also huge inside but with an intimate feel.

I have to try it out again.

I love pets of any shape and size. And I love cool stores that cater to fur babies.
This location of Doggie Style had a nice selection of items. I like looking at all the cool clothes and treats. They are more pricey that your big box pet suppliers but, the experience is much more pleasant and the stock is much more varied and interesting. 
Pet people are also more apt to drop some cash for our babies. 
Best of all, there are usually pets for adoption. This is a wonderful thing for these shops to do as a service to pets that would possibly be destroyed and to the communities where these stores are located. Bravo!

We visited Flyte for my birthday and had a really incredible experiences.  We told them that we were visiting for an occasion and they did such a great job making it a special meal, including bringing us champagne and some little brownies.  I love the whole 'flyte' idea, especially when it comes to wine.  I always want to try more than I should reasonably consume...so bringing me three small portions is an excellent idea.  I loved all of what we ordered, but the highlight for me was the lamb flyte.  It is a bit pricey, I'd say a special occasion type deal for sure.  

I also thought that their temps were a bit off, ambiance wise.  Halfway through the meal I started burning up, where hubs was apparently under an air-vent and very cool and cozy.  I'm not sure what they can do about this...but it might be something to look into.  Also, forced-valet parking angers me.  You have a parking lot, I am a good parker, and I can also walk ten feet.  

I am intrigued by their happy hour specials, however, so I may be lured back for that in the meantime.

I love that this place delivers for lunch...there are too few of those options in the area. The chicken cheesesteak was very good (especially for the burbs) and the Caesar salad was very fresh! Delivery was on-time and friendly. Overall, I would recommend Rich's.

I love this place!
We came here last nights and rented a karaoke room. 
The food was pretty standard. 
We got fried rice, udon noodles, squid steak, calamari, chicken wings (soooo good), sashimi salad, and tuna tataki which I definitely recommend! 
Great service and I would come back again!

Despite its name, this cute little shop didn't look cluttered to me.

You'll find a variety of neat classic and vintage items when you stop in here. And there's really no reason not to pop in...after all, it's right in the center of town!

If you're a globe lover and collector like me, you're in serious luck. I found one from the 1950s for $25 that I desperately wanted, but since I'm in the process of clearing clutter ahead of my move back to Collingswood, I resisted. It was so hard! They also had a bunch of big ones in stock.

Right now, they're selling banners depicting the PATCO stops. They're pricey at $59, but otherwise really cool. I would've loved to splurge on one, but again, stopped myself!

If you're looking to add some quirky or elegant items to your home, this is a good spot to look. I'll certainly be back for a serious browse session once I'm settled in my new place.

Pastaria is getting a well deserved update and I'm bumping them back up to 5 stars. Yes, there are a few things that I wish would change. But the bottom line is that they are darned good, family friendly, and now you can use the No Wait app to get in line before you go. 

I've been a handful of times since my other reviews. I love the bread - the oils and parmasan on the table are so yummy. The risotto balls are my favorite! The burrata is also very good. The canestri cacio e pepe is my favorite pasta. The wine list is also delicious. My husband, son and I enjoyed a great dinner here last night out on the patio area. It was warm but we had some shade from a tree, which helped a lot. They brought out my son's meal before ours (which they had asked if they should do and we said yes). He was happy. I wish the kids meals had a protein option other than meat sauce on spaghetti. Chicken or something. But not a huge deal. He loved his mac n cheese and also the risotto balls that we ordered. The meal took quite awhile to get to us, and when it was brought out, we were told that dessert was on them. We appreciated this a lot! We were not mad about it since our son was happy and occupied and we also had bread and an appetizer to fill us up in advance. Service was great. When we arrived, we were able to sit right down but when we left, the wait was 90 minutes. Come early to avoid the crowds! 

The blackberry gelato and tiramisu we enjoyed due to the wait on our food were wonderful. We'll be back, Pastaria - you're back in my good graces.

Best biscuit I've ever had! This was on our list of places to try, we drove by the other location and the line was out the door - about 30-40 ppl deep! It had been raining all morning so wondering if people waited out the rain, so we decided to go to the this location instead. Worst part was the parking - there's a lot across the street but Biscuit Love was not a place listed for places the lot was allotted for. We didn't want to take chances as we've heard the meter maids are pretty diligent here. After 10 mins of circling, we found parking about 2 blocks behind the restaurant that allowed 2 hour parking.

We were prob 5th in line and it was raining - the staff was super nice and actually had in-house umbrellas in anticipation of lines. Took about 10 mins to get our order in and another 5-7 mins to get our food. We ordered the East Nasty and Wash Park. Wow - the biscuit was a heavenly pillow of fluffiness and not dry at all. Fried chicken thigh was good but not great but the gravy was delicious (could've used a bit more gravy). We also ordered the famous bonuts - soooo good! They're much bigger than the pictures depicted so I had half of one and was done. My bf wanted the Gertie (for you people with a sweet tooth - get it, it's ridiculous), one bite and I was dunzo, way too rich for my palate, but he was in chocolate/PB heaven. 

We ended up taking 75% of the bonuts and Gertie to go. Gertie didn't re-eat well, really should be eaten warm but the bonuts were still really good later that day. Overall, this was prob one of my favorite places during our visit to Music City. If the fried chicken were a little bit better, this would've been a 5 star review. Now I ponder regrets of not getting the Nasty Princess - an off the menu item that is a combo of the East Nasty and the Princess....there's always next time.

Besides the unbelievably "my pleasure," friendly service, I love this location in particular because you can get through the driveway super fast. If drivers go through by themselves, they chicken out (pun intended!) on the left side of the drive through. Be brave! All you have to do is reach through the passenger window ;) You can't go wrong with a huge platter of chicken nuggets and a sweet tea to make mama happy!  There is no place to sit at this location, so be sure you are ready to eat on the go. Otherwise, great service and experience!

I had a great experience at this restaurant. Coyote Crossing definitely has a more upscale Mexican vibe, which was definitely reflective in their menu and drink selection. Prices are steep, be forewarned. I think some menu items were totally overpriced. I started off the evening with their Don Margarita, which was almost a house marg with fresh lime juice and Patron. Unlike many other margs I have had, I knew this one had alcohol in it. For dinner, I ordered the Mocajete Azteca. This was a pretty unqiue dish served on steaming hot volcanic rock. I love how all food is served very hot. They start you off with chips and pico, and the first round is free (they should really not charge for this at all given the prices of everything else.) My boyfriend had the enchiladas with chicken. Tangy and delicious. Our server, Christian was excellent. Another added bonus, this place has a parking lot. Which is so nice for Conshy.

I've been on a pizza kick the last couple weeks. I'm not sure why. I've always loved pizza but it's starting to become an addiction. I opened up yelp to see if I could try any new pizza places. I've heard of Fox Dens before but never had it. I check their website & saw a "today's special" for one large topping pizza for $7.99. I figured that would be something good to try. I called & ordered a pepperoni pizza. The pizza would be ready in 10-15 minutes. I made my way over after work. 

This location is located off Elm Hill Pike in a strip mall. I've passed by this strip mall a million times but never noticed Fox Dens in it. I pulled up & walked inside. The shop is small, a couple tables are inside if you'd like to eat there. The woman didn't ask for my name over the phone, but it was 5:30 & I guess they didn't get a lot of call in ordered because she knew the pepperoni pizza was mine. I also noticed that they had a 100 score from the health department. That always makes me feel good. My total was $8.74 & I was on my way. 

The weight of the pizza seemed a little light to me for a large. The box was big though. I waited to look at it when I got home. I opened the box and noticed how big it was. I'm not sure if the inchage (is that a word?) but they cut the large into ten pieces. I like that. It also makes me feel like a fatty because I ate 5 slices. 

I thought the pepperoni pizza was great for the $7.99 price. The crust and bottom had the right amount of crisp to it. I liked how the cheese was cooked golden brown. The amount of pepperoni was good, however I thought the amount of cheese was a little spare. Maybe next time I'll order with extra cheese. Was it the best ever? No. But I'm looking to try other pizzas they have. From the menu it looks like they've got some different signature pizzas.

I pass The Coffee Station everyday on my way to work and always think how I need to try it. Well, today we did! After a night full of partying we needed some early breakfast to wake up so we headed over around 7:30 am. 

My husband had Johns Big Breakfast and I had the egg, home fries and toast meal...the name escapes me right now.

Both were pretty good, my husband made a comment that their pancakes were better than most breakfast spots in the area. I thought the home fries left a little to be desired and needed salt but they weren't terrible. My over-easy eggs were perfect. 

I didn't realize how cool this place was on the inside either, there were a ton of tables and lots of pictures all over the walls. My husband loves the eagles memorabilia everywhere. Next time we will definitely dine in!

Oh Han Dynasty, I really wanted to love you.  I really did.  You've been on my "must go" list for months now, and when I finally get a chance to go, you let me down.

I'm a sucker for good service, and the guy at the front of the house was the worst.  We had a reservation at 7:00 - granted, a busy time for any restaurant, but at the very least I expect to be acknowledged.  We were ignored with not so much as eye contact for a full 20 minutes.  During this time, he was taking delivery orders and instructed patrons on the other end of the line to "make it quick, we're busy in here".  We were very tempted to walk out!

Host aside, the food was generally good and the service during dinner was solid.  My DP and I had the much-hyped dan dan noodles and they were hands down my favorite part of the meal.  If I lived close enough for delivery, I'd order just for these!  We also got the wontons in chili oil, which were disappointing.  The wontons were flimsy and bland and combined with the overkill on the oil, they were a big miss for me. 

The garlic sauce style pork was pretty good, but there wasn't much to set it aside from generic Chinese takeout.  My DP got the shrimp in the crispy rice style, which I loved.  The rice had a satisfying crunch and the black and wood ear mushrooms were tasty.

I will probably give HD another shot, but more than likely at another location.

Went there on a Saturday night with a group of 5 friends. Yes, it used to be a Taco Bell, but the inside looks nothing like that. It is clean, with only 8 tables total, this is a small place. Chef Ma and his team are very friendly! He came out to greet us as we were sitting down. He again came by to check in with us at the start of the meal. The best part was the end of the meal, we had a chat and he genuinely offered my friend an opportunity to go into the kitchen to learn some basic prep and knife skills and to learn a couple of  essential chinese dishes! What a gem!
There are 2 menus, the one printed in landscape form has Americanized Chinese dishes, but get the one printed in portrait form and it has the authentic Chinese dishes!

To start, we got the Hot Oil Juicy Chicken and Salt and Pepper Tofu. Keep in mind this is an appetizer, so the chicken is served cold, but it sure is moist and tender, it has chili oil and jalapeno peppers drizzled on, but if you brush it aside, it's not too spicy. The tofu was crisp on the outside and silken soft on the inside with savory, salt and pepper crumbs on top!
For entrees, we ordered a feast of Chef Ma's signature dishes: Lamb Stew, Fish Soup, stir fried lotus root, twice cooked pork and spicy clams. All of his signature dishes can be found as photos around the restaurant. My favorite was the claypot lamb stew which has bamboo shoots, chinese mushrooms, fork tender lamb, chinese leeks, in a rich meaty stock with ginger and sugar cane. The fish fillet soup was the next favorite with needle mushrooms, oyster mushrooms, chinese cabbage. Both broths were soul warming on a 10 degree night! The twice cooked pork was stirfried with stewed firm tofu, in a chili hot oil, but don't let that scare you, it imparts a smokey flavor to the pork with just a slight kick of spiciness at the end. One of our group is a vegetarian and the stirfried lotus root was perfect, tender lotus root with snap peas and chinese mushrooms, healthy and delicious. Now, the spiciest dish of the meal were the clams, but they were certainly very fresh, and perfectly cooked! 
Chef Ma's style of Chinese cooking is rich but yet light, flavorful but not overpowering. 
What a feast! We love Chef Ma and his team! Our interaction with everyone there, together with our experience will certainly have us coming back many more times!

A hidden gem! I absolutely love Tiki Tolteca. They stay true to their brand in all areas (food, drinks, decor, and service). The prices are great and it's never overly packed. My favorite drinks to order would have to be the Hurricane and Pain Killer.  Both are blazing with power and punch! The bartenders are amazing and very patient when it comes to indecisive patrons. Please visit for a happy hour, I promise you won't be disappointed.

Can Kim come with me everywhere?! I absolutely adored her, her energy, and her style. She did a great job curling my hair and made my locks bounce with just enough fluff. I loved it.

Buff Beauty Bar is a little underwhelming when you first arrive. It's in a refurbished building that seems like the insides could use a little fluff itself. A swipe of fresh paint and refinished flooring (please keep the tile look) would do a world of good.

So when I first arrived I was a bit skeptical.

The hair chairs are located up stairs and there are four of them. They were very comfortable.

Service was impeccable from start to finish the women in here are so friendly, and the glass of sparkling while getting ready was just what this hair-iliterate gal needed.

My first time with Afghani food, though the dishes we tried seemed very familiar.  Prices were a bit on the higher side, but this isn't a doner kebab takeaway!

You will need a group of six people at least to reserve the spot where you can all sit around a low table with your shoes off. Good to know in the future!  We were miffed to know we were short one person to get it and we almost considered dragging someone off South Street to join us - hahaaha.

The ambiance was lovely - our table of five could easily chat and hear each other. It's definitely a white table, candle light and clinking glasses kinda place. We shared a number of different dishes, none of which I care to attempt to spell out, but everything was delicious.  I loved my Afghani meatballs, my sister loved  her kebab (not the most appetizing looking thing, but it was spiced well), and the four different appetizers we tried out were all gone quickly (they were on the smaller side, so we could each only have a bite or so each).

Yes.  Yes.  Yes.  Love the place, love the menu, love the owner's other place, loved my po boys.  I shared an oyster po boy and a shrimp remoulade fried tomato po boy.  Nothing should be this good.  I don't know if I could weigh in at under 200 pounds anymore if I moved here.  Seriously, these were both terrific sandwiches and the onion rings were pretty great too.  Nothing was greasy, all the fried was crisp and perfect.  Don't come here though because I don't want to wait in a longer line.  Go over to Parkway and leave this one for me.

It's been a few years since we've visited the Hotel Congress.  A few years is too long to wait for a visit to this historic little place.  We were in town for a concert at the Rialto Theater next door and stayed at the Hotel Congress so that we would be within walking distance of the Theater and not have to fight traffic or ultra happy concert goers afterwards.  What a great plan!

The Hotel Congress is conveniently located in downtown Tucson right across from the old train depot.  Although parking at the hotel can be scarce, there is ample parking at the depot.  There is also a really nice restaurant in the depot that we will have to sample on our next visit.  We were also pleased to see the underpass under the railroad tracks has been remodeled and now it is quite convenient and safe to walk from the hotel to many of the bars and shops along 4th Ave.

Before the concert we stopped by the Tap Room, the hotel bar, and had a drink before the show.  The Tap Room is small, but nice.  A row of booths parallel the bar and a vintage juke box stands in the corner next to the door to the patio.  They had about half a dozen or so different selections of beer on tap, including Guinness and Four Peaks Kiltlifter.  If I remember correctly, the draft beers were $4 each.  They also had a pretty decent selection of vodka's and tequila's.  

I really dig the antique switchboard and front desk.  They have cubby holes for each of the rooms and you actually get REAL keys here!  I give them an extra star for this factor alone.  Not only is it a novelty in this electronic day an age, but how many times have you walked back to your room on the morning you are checking out, only to find out your key card no longer works?  Then you get to walk all the way back to the front desk, have them reset the card, and then walk all the back to your room.  Well, you don't have to worry about that here!

The rooms are cozy (i.e. small) but very comfortable.  Each room has a closet, a bed, a dresser, a desk, and an end table with a rotary dial phone.  The shower in our room was small, only 3'X3'.  The water temperature was a little fussy, but I don't remember that from before, so we'll see if it's still acting up on our next visit.  The Hotel Congress has tried to stay very true to what it was back in the day.  It's nothing fancy, so don't expect a 5 star resort, but is wonderfully comfortable.  I've read some of the reviews and have to say that yes, I did hear the train at night, but it wasn't intrusive.  They do only have evaporative cooling, so you have to keep your window open a little in the summer.  We were quite comfortable with the cooling and the ceiling fan on during the night.  There is a nightclub downstairs and it gets pretty busy when school is in session.  But if you stay in the rooms not directly over the club, you won't hear the music or the people.  We've really fallen in love with the charm of the Hotel Congress.  When you walk through the doors you are instantly transported back in time.  We can't wait for our next visit back in time.  Oh yeah, ask the desk clerk about room #214. *wink*

Have an infatuation with Mexican food? Crave perfectly roasted chicken? Adore delicious cocktails? Love really amazing locally owned restos in crazy cool spaces? If you answered yes to any of the above, I have the perfect spot for you: Rostizado! 

This roasted chicken-centric brain child, from the delightful men of Tres Carnales fame, have carved themselves out a neatly packaged niche in the Mercer Wear-house building. With smart, sexy cocktails (that do take a bit of time to arrive at your table, so be patient), and a truly unique menu (there is no guacamole and salsa here, this is grown-up Mexican with thought and flavour) that is unlike anything else in the Province. 

I love the decor, the chill couch-lounge with vintage red TVs. The staff is incredible (especially those sporting 'man-buns', wink, wink) and the stand-outs food wise, for me, the sandwiches for lunch! - either the rosti pollo or rosti puerco. Do get the rosti papas (best roasted potatoes EVER!) and roasted cauliflower as sides, so good! And I quite liked the roasted romain hearts salad. If you like mushrooms get the queso fundido. And of course, the roasted chicken! 

As this is still a very new restaurant, there are bound to be bumps and bruises, and learning curves. That's why I gave it 4, not 5 (because I know it will improve, I can't wait, and my re-review a few months from now will show that!) And I urge you disregard quick-to-judge early reviewers that may "loose their internet cool" after minor meal mishaps that they may portray to look like Moby Dick size mistakes.

Loews Philadelphia gets all my stars and I don't think I had one complaint during my entire stay. All the staff was really accommodating. When we checked in, we were originally put in a double room and asked to instead be put in a queen - not a problem, not even a hint of attitude. We called guests services about 38947239 times to request more pillows (ended up with 15 total) and each time, the person at the other end of the phone was chipper, and even gracious to send up more pillows. And concierge was very sweet and helpful, directing us to a good brunch spot as well as doing some research for me on what places would be open during Labor day and offering some suggestions on how to spend the day. 

Beyond the staff, the hotel itself was super swanky and I liked the sleek and modern decor. The hotel is a converted bank and was really cool and trendy throughout. Everything was clean which is muy importante and my #1 qualifier with hotels, and our room was spacious with some nice pluses like super comfy robes that I couldn't get enough of, a decent blow dryer (not those shitty travel size ones that most hotels have) and lighted make-up mirror, PLUS two extra mirrors outside of the bathroom! I don't think people realize how much weight those extra mirrors hold. It wasn't the case in this instance, but if you ever have multiple girls in one hotel room, multiple mirrors are a lifesaver! Overall the room was great -- especially compared to the Marriott across the street. We were invited into a double room there for a short bit and the place was poop compared to the Loews. 

The location was also a win. You are right in the center of everything (view from the top floor is amazing), and lots of the obligatory touristy stuff is within a short walking distance. Liberty Bell, Magic Gardens, Love Park, etc etc. are all withing a 10-20 min walk, and Reading Terminal market is pretty much steps outside the hotel. There are plenty of restaurants and shopping too, so all your needs are covered in the close  vicinity. 

Like most reviewers have already mentioned, parking here is stupid expensive and we parked like a block away for 3nights/4days for a total of $51. 

Oh and I thought of one complaint. The pool. Not that Philly is really a destination where one would typically think of relaxing by a pool, but this one was pretty lame. Its an indoor, two-lane lap pool, definitely not something to lounge at... and there is no hot tub :(  there is however a pretty good gym (or so it looked). 

Anyway, the Loews definitely gets my vote!

I'm from SoCal and have been to very, very hipster places (including PDX), but Milktooth might actually take the cake. It's in a converted seven-bay garage and is influenced by all types of cultures - Spanish on the wall directing you to the bathroom, traditional Jewish cuisine with a twist as well as miso soup on the menu) But, I really enjoyed it even though we waited a little over an hour. 

We had the: 

*potato & rutabaga latke (acorn squash butter, green harissa cream, scallion) - this was SO good. I don't think I've ever had a latke, but it was tasty. Not too oily. The flavors will the butter, cream and scallion were perfect. 

*cranberry walnut & geneva & raclette grilled cheese (black truffle honey, local sunny duck egg) - Whew, I'm glad I shared this dish because it was very heavy. Extremely delicious but if I ate the entire grilled cheese myself, I'd definitely fall into a food coma. 

*indiana hot chicken wings (dried chiles & crystal sauce, bleu cheese dressing, carrot & celery slaw) - this was SERIOUS business. I've had seriously hot nashville chicken, but damn this was SO spicy. I loved it though!

The only thing I didn't love was the camellia drink I had (apple, matcha, pistachio and steamed milk). It was grainy from the pistachio maybe? and just an interesting but not that tasty combination of flavors. Also, a small cup was $6!!! Ridiculous.

It's not much of a bar, but it's Isla Vista, but on the right night it can be wonderful...

As romantic firelight glowed on the mountains, and darkness reigned in Isla Vista (and most of Goleta for that matter), my lover and I searched for beer, that most sweet and soothing of beverages.  Finding the stores closed, we found the Study Hall alight with lanterns and flashlights.  In we went, cash in hand to purchase Guinness and Newcastle.  We sat together at the bar, regaling each other with past tales of glory from our misspent youth in Austin.  When news updates came on with where the fire currently burned, the bar went silent as though we were listening to the worst news that could be imagined.  In solidarity with our fellow alcoholics, we sipped silently.  The fire burned on.

I love Lilly's. It is my go-to Vietnamese spot uptown. But I have had a series of bad experiences and I think it may be time for a break.

I know I usually go for lunch and they are always slammed, which is great for them, but I have gotten some really, *really* bad service. To tell you the truth, I can't tell if it's the lunch time rush or if it's personal or whatever. There is a server who is always there and I don't think she likes me very much. K asked if I ever gave a bad tip and I never did, so I don't know where it's coming from. Maybe I am reading too much into it, but she'll ignore me and go to greet other people or crack jokes and laugh with other customers while always looking at me with zero expression on her face.

Today I wanted some pho but it was lunch time and I thought that picking it up and eating it at my desk might work out better for me time-wise. I called and ordered and was told that it would be ready in 25 minutes. I showed up in 23 minutes and walked up to the counter. For a good 10 minutes, no one greeted me or said anything, not even a "someone will be with you shortly." I know they were busy, but the server had time to see people come in through the door and ask how many they were but she could not even acknowledge me and the other guy standing by the counter? Come on.

Finally, Lilly came out of the kitchen and addressed us. Then it took an additional 5-10 minutes for the food to come out. It's like they didn't actually start preparing my pickup order until after I came in and spoke with Lilly, even though I called and was told a specific amount of time and I showed up with 2 minutes left on their time. What was the point of me calling ahead? If they had told me they were slammed and that ti would take 45 minutes instead (which is about how long it took), I would have made the informed decision to wait that long or go somewhere else. But don't tell me one thing and deliver another thing.

Yes, it's time for a break.

--------------------------------

Update:

I received a message from Lilly herself with an apology. And my sister, who loves Lilly's even more than I do, came in town for Thanksgiving, so I went back with her at around 5 pm. Dinner time but not the busiest part. Oh. My. God. So much better.

So I changed my mind about the break. I will just try to get my cravings met when it's not lunch/dinner rush whenever possible.

Also, I tried the pork bahn mi for the first time and fell in love. The flavors are much more complex than a traditional bahn mi that you would get from say Dong Phuong.

My fellow Pirate mateys went here after a long day of Gasparilla Invasion/parade 2014 fun! We hadn't had food since breakfast so we were a bit famished at about 6:30. We were glad to get a very friendly waitress who was happy to get us soft pretzel sticks as an appetizer. They were warm and soft and served with three sauces. Mustard, a white warm cheese and a chipotle ranch. Yum! Then my son and I ordered the Saturday special which was a half rack of hot BBQ ribs and country fried chicken. We split this thankfully since it was a very large serving. The BBQ ribs were delicious and saucy. The chicken was breaded just right and it was very tasty. Our service was great the entire time with a very friendly server and a pretty nice atmosphere. They have sports TVs on every where with smart quotes on the walls for decoration. One of my favorite things was the seating. We loved that our table was lined up to sofas for the seats, cool and cozy idea :)

I like about every food option set before me, so walking in and seeing an amazing-looking menu board of soooo many yummy choices. It didn't help that my lunch mate said "it's all really good." So, I eenie-meenie-miney-mo'd and ended up with a lovely turkey sandwich from the daily specials. 

We sat outside and enjoyed the sunshine. The tables filled up, but it never felt packed or without privacy. The food was served up quickly and was served with just the right amount of conversation. 

My dining partner knows the owners and was able to share part of their story - how they planned to hang in Indy for a year on their way to foodier markets, but fell in love with the community and put down roots (no pun intended) to bring their fresh feasts to hungry Hoosiers. 

I love the story. I love the food. In fact, we now have a standing date... now, to start thinking about what to order next.

Classic New Orleans steakhouse, circa 1930's.  Looks like Huey Long ate here.  It even has private booths with velvet curtains.  Steaks are great- love the porterhouse for two.  As far as sides are concerned, avoid the mushrooms- they seem to be canned.

All in all, it's a step back in time- LOVE the authentic early 20th century feel.  I believe Crescent City Steaks was the original competitor to Chris' Steaks, which was eventually taken over by Ruth Fertel, hence the name "Ruth's Chris."  The steak is good to incredible, depending on the night.  The lack of consistency is worrisome, and I'm hoping it's more consistently excellent instead of average.

I love this bar! Cool jams, super sweet bartenders, great prices, wavy bar, icicle lights!!! 

Don't be put off by the entrance, it could use a little sprucing up... Inside is magic.

Cash only!

I did not love Red Kings 2. The food we ordered (Dan Dan noodles and Chicken with Cashews) was extremely oily. I also felt like we were sitting on top of the table next to us, and it did not help that one of the patrons kept sneezing towards us. The food is moderately priced. I think there are better options in Chinatown.

mmmm...a choc-work orange, so good.  Flavors to please everyone in the family from the gourmand to the 6 year old.  

This ice cream parlor does traditional bar service in the location of the original McKenzie's Bakery location (and they've left the old neon sign earning eternal love from many New Orleanians).

Great place to wind down, relax, chill, you get the idea! Its recommended for those who love art and reading, as UE has plenty of space to do that. They are good at holding events there, and its a cool place to hold small meetings. Their sandwiches and baked goods are great, as well as their smoothies. They also have a decent craft beer selection as well. Only bad thing is the parking, well sometimes. I could say the same thing for most other nearby places. Check out this place next time you're in Dutchtown!

Samson Kabob House is one of my favorite neighborhood BYOBs - service is fairly fast and friendly, the food is flavorful (but not too salty), and the prices are reasonable for Center City.

Favorite items include the steamed dumplings, the hummus, and basically all the kebabs. The dumplings are served in a savory, slightly tangy sauce (that tastes great with the homemade flatbread. 

For entrees, I usually get the fish kebabs (tender, spiced salmon skewers), and if I'm really hungry, I'll get the Samson kebab platter, which comes with chicken, ground spiced beef, and chunks of lamb. There's something addicting about the food - once you start eating it, it's difficult to stop! On the side, the rice is super fluffy, and the lentils are delicious.

Service is friendly and usually pretty fast (though they do get a bit overwhelmed when large parties come in), and the restaurant decor is fun. My coworkers like to come for group lunches, and I love having quiet weekend dinners here!

i know.  i might be considered crazy for giving peter chinn's less than stellar review, but i wasn't that impressed.  mainly with the atmosphere.  i remember cheeseburger charley's in that location very well.  and, when i walked in today, i had to actually question the guy working (who was sitting in a booth staring at the wall--zero customers in the place at 1:00pm on a saturday) if it still WAS CC's.  his answer?  "i don't think so".  so, i guess the jury's still out on that one...

i really was assuming that their specialty was just tacos.  not burgers, burritos, etc etc.  they even still have the same CC menu board, just took off a few burger items (though, they still have plenty) and replaced them with tacos.  i asked what kind of sides i could get--fries and onion rings.  now i love both of these fried delicacies, but with korean tacos?  no thanks.  

anyway, i was getting the order to go so figured the atmosphere, or lack thereof, didn't matter.  i ordered the spicy pork and the kogi taco.  i like that they added a small container of spicy sauce (not sure what it was called since i discovered it after i got home), and the tacos were very good.  but, not the best i've ever had or anything.  

i still prefer john ko's korean bbq at local taco--and his location is better for me.  but, if i'm ever in the vandy area, i might stop in and order to go again.  i will never eat in there.  think i would lose my appetite.

Love this place! I'm assuming anyone reading this has at least heard wonderful stories of how In-N-Out delivers low prices, great tasting burgers and fries with honest ingredients, and this location is definitely no exception.

Of the several times I've come here, it's always packed, but the wait times are always reasonable. I was hungry and devastated to see my number was about 30 from being called, but it probably only took about 10 minutes. Even with customization, my orders were never messed up, and of course tasted heavenly.

Workers were all smiles, everything seemed clean, and the workers were pretty attentive, wiping down tables immediately after people left. Can't really complain! If you're an In-N-Out fan, don't worry, come through. This is a great location. If you've never tried...you're seriously missing out. Don't wait!!

I was so pleased with breakfast here. I am not a big breakfast person, so it takes a lot to wow me.  I was wowed.  At our server's suggestion, we paid the slight upcharge to get the cinnamon raisin toast instead of white or wheat and it was worth every penny.  Homemade, full of plump raisins and lots of cinnamon sugar, it was heaven on a plate.  I also had what may have been the best biscuits of my life.  I ordered biscuits and gravy and while the gravy was delicious, I think the biscuits were so good they would have been fine all by themselves.  They were so buttery and really thick and dense, but somehow not too heavy.  I had a side of hash browns and they were fine. They were thickly shredded and well browned, but unseasoned.  A dash of salt and ketchup and they got the job done.  Our server was not unfriendly, but she did just enough.  We laughed when we asked for more napkins and she brought back one.  We are a spilling, sloppy family and had already cleaned up one mess.  So back she went for more napkins.  :-)  

The atmosphere is not upscale, but nicer than your average diner.  Our daughter loved hunting for all the roosters in the decor.  We found them on the walls, on a clock, on the bathroom doors, and even as purse hooks inside the bathroom stalls.  

Yum...I cannot wait to get back there and have another biscuit!

2 Words:

AWE SOME.

Burger Up offers selections for vegetarians, vegans, carnivores of red meat, and carnivores that avoid red meat (turkey).  The burgers have special sauces and varying selections of toppers to make each burger a special occasion.  

The appetizers are also tasty and delish.  I tried the fried oysters (something I would usually avoid in a landlocked state), but they were actually very delicious.
