Part of the reason that event planners such as myself like to host events at the Hutton Hotel is because they are just THAT good. Seriously.
The location is central and close to everything. The staff is always friendly and the service is excellent. I also love the chic' interior design and always refer all of my out-of-town guests to book here. 

Their Director Of Events J. Curtis Hinton is very patient and offers up fantastic solutions for your event. You may utilize/book their conference rooms or ballrooms for virtually any size event.

If you're looking for me this week, you know where to find me!

Gerard Craft is proving himself as one of the most reliable & exciting restauranteurs of the Midwest. With Pastaria, his love for all things Italian is on full-display, and it's pretty impressive when you keep in mind the oversaturated Italian food scene in St. Louis.

For Neopolitan pizza fanatics, Pastaria should be at the top of your list. They've perfected the craft of the wood-fired pie, and it stands among the very best pizzas that I've had to date. For purists, go for the Margherita, and don't look back. The crust has a wonderful, bouncy bite, with the authentic char on various sides of the crust that balance well with the SM tomatoes & mozzarella. Going forward, I'll probably exclusively order pizzas when I come here - they're that good.

Ironically enough, despite what their name indicates, I wasn't overly impressed with the pasta...I tried the Cacio e Pepe, which was the recommendation of many, though I found it to be a bit bland. The noodles, however, were obviously fresh & perfectly al dente - I just wish there was more flavor to be found.

Nonetheless, Pastaria continues Mr. Craft's streak of phenomenal restaurants, offering something new & modern to traditionally business-centric area that is downtown Clayton.

This was when my boyfriend and I started to be convinced that Indy cuisine is underwhelming and overpriced. Just like we felt about Hoaglin's To Go, we found Siam Square overpriced and pretty darn average. My portion, which was priced in the teens, was TINY. Did I mention tiny? And my boyfriend ordered Medium spice and was disappointed at how mild it was, saying it wasn't spicy whatsoever. The service was fairly pleasant and the atmosphere was cute, but for these prices, I was disappointed like crazy.
And again, I had to compare it to Cleveland Cuisine. There is a place I love here in Cleveland with double the portions and half the prices.

I love Granite City! I've been several times-Happy Hour, lunch, dinner, Mother's Day brunch, Father's Day Brunch, and it's usually really good!

I was sad this winter during Covid, when I sat on the covered porch, but the fireplace wasn't on. The heaters above didn't necessarily keep us warm. 

Overall, go to Granite City! It's delicious!

No matter how crowded it may seem when I've walked through the door, I'm always greeted with a sense of calm.  It's the ease of the service, the mood of the music, the ever changing talents of artwork on the walls, and the soothing coffee drinks.  For serious, I've never been let down by their luscious concoctions.

If you can grab a table or even a comfy chair in one of the middle rooms, you're sure to fall in love with it, too.  And I don't know who the hell controls the music selection in there, but oh my damn...they should be programming their own radio station at this point.  Amen.

As with the Cherry Hill branch, the best thing about Turning Point is their french press coffee.  Really great!  We went today for breakfast.  I ordered 2 eggs over medium.  Kudos for cooking the whites and not the yellows, but the heat was too high, therefore, the edges of the eggs were brown.  I didn't eat that part. Overall, not bad.  I don't know, why, however, eggs seem to be so difficult to master for many diners and breakfast places.  I also ordered 2 pumpkin pancakes - this time of year, I love to try everyone's pumpkin pancakes.  The one pancake was underdone and gummy.  The other one was better and I ate most of it, however, it was made with nuts and seeds, which I didn't expect.  It wasn't horrible, but I would prefer no surprising crunchiness in my pancakes. Amy's still gets my vote for the best pumpkin pancakes around!  Turning Points service was good.  I would go back if only for that coffee...

A quick review of our carry out experience here at Caleco. It was a busy Friday evening on the street as there was a big Cards home game. Somehow inside things were calmer and quieter. We steered our way towards the large fish tank and the nearby counter to place a carry out order. Yes you can call it in but we were already in the area and just popped in. 

Tonight we wanted to try a St Louis style pizza and ordered a large thin crust with pepperoni, sausage and white onions. It only was a 20 minute wait for the pie to be ready. We walked down to the stadium area and back to see what was going on while waiting. 

We brought our pie back to the hotel and enjoyed it with a bottle of red wine we already had. The crust was thin and crispy. The cheese was a mix of several cheeses giving it a thicker taste that what we normally experience and less stringy. I hear some people don't care for it but we loved it. The other ingredients were fresh and tasty. 

We devoured the pizza in no time and were left wanting more. One of our favorite pizzas on our trip.

The United Artists Galaxy Theatre is certainly one of Central Indiana's older "contemporary": theaters with stadium style seating and a sound system that reminds you how much technology has advanced in the last 20 years. 

That's not a compliment. 

It's a go to movie theater for promotion screenings, however, because it also tends to have larger auditoriums and is a great choice for those screenings expecting high attendance. If there's one thing I love about it, it's that they do offer very limited "single" seat options. That is, I can actually go into the auditorium and find a seat where I don't have to sit next to someone else by getting out of my wheelchair. The majority of theaters tend to have companion seating. 

The seats are older and tend to be less comfortable than what you find in most theaters. They aren't horrible, but they definitely aren't plush. Prices tend to be a tad higher here due to tax issues related to the downtown stadiums, but the prices are still on par with most area theaters. 

The staff is friendly, though they can be a bit "in your face" at times if they are unfamiliar with you. This is definitely one of my least favorite theaters in Central Indiana, and I can't say I'd recommend it for a film that utilized high special effects. They do offer special film series offerings throughout the year, especially during the Summer months, and despite my reservations I would note that it's still pretty consistently crowded.

I'm severely lactose intolerant so I love the fact they have 5-6 coconut milk based ice creams. Tonight I tried Red Velvet Oreo and it was great. Family all enjoyed the flavors they had especially the Candy Cane. Prices completely fair. Tip: at night the place may or may not look open & busy - don't just drive by. It's simply the way the building and signage is. One of my fav ice cream places in the entire Tampa Bay Area.
Homemade pasta! This a gem with a rich history. I for lasagna and it was served with bread. Definitely a carb overhaul but who doesn't love carbohydrates

The Tie Dye Grill is a quirky '70s-themed eatery on the east side of the thirteen-hundred block of Shadeland Avenue. There is ample convenient parking directly adjacent to the south side of the building.

The establishment has a single medium-sized dining area with booths and tables providing seating for approximately sixty-two patrons. The kitchen is largely open to the dining area. The walls are covered with posters and other '70s memorabilia. There is a single TV mounted in the southwest corner of the dining area tuned to a '70s music channel.

When I arrived at mid-afternoon on a Monday there was one waitress and two cooks on hand. The waitress extended a friendly welcome and encouraged me to take a seat anywhere.

The menu is comprehensive with appetizers; soups; salads; hot dogs; a variety of sandwiches including paninis, subs, and burgers; a full list of sides; and kid's meals. The selections all have cutesy '70s-themed names; e.g., Lava Lamp Wings, Crimson & Clover Chicken Salad Plate, Purple Haze Portobello Mushroom Sandwich, and so on. I ordered the Garfunkle French Onion Soup and the Brown Chicken Brown Cow burger.

It was with the food that things began to fall apart.

There was no soup in my bowl of Garfunkle French Onion Soup. The bowl was instead completely full of soup-sodden bread cubes with some caramelized onions under a layer of gooey cheese. Top to bottom, there was not an actual spoonful of soup anywhere although I guess I could have pressed some out of the bread cubes. The only discernible flavor (and that not particularly pleasant) was that of the bread. I keep referring to them as bread cubes and not croutons because they showed no evidence of ever having been fried or toasted.

The Brown Chicken Brown Cow burger was cooked exactly to my specification. However the gravy was watery and the overall dish very soggy and quite lacking in flavor. Further, I had seen the dish delivered to the pass right as the one waitress began taking orders from a table of five, including two young children. By the time she was able to negotiate their food and drink orders, turn in those orders, and then bring me my food, it was all room temperature.

The theme is an entertaining novelty and the prices are quite inexpensive, but the food is simply not worth the trip to this eastside establishment.

A group of 12 came here on a Friday night and the staff was very friendly, welcoming, and attentive to us throughout the evening. If you have any questions, just ask and they love to help you! The restaurant is more spacious than I expected for a strip mall place. 

You're given a menu and an informational sheet that defines common words from the menu. Point of interest: they have 3 different kinds of imported Ethiopian beer to choose from.

We tried a cabbage sambusa and a beef sambusa, which are similar to an Indian somosa (fried dough with a savory filling). Both were great but the cabbage had more flavor. All other dishes came on top of a circular piece of fermented sourdough that you are meant to eat the food with - you can request rice or French bread if you don't like it but it has a very mild flavor! 

The lamb was not de-boned so beware. I would recommend the "tibbs" - either chicken, beef, lamb, or goat meat fried with peppers and onion in a delicious sauce. The vegetarian sampler platter was a great variety of authentic spreads and the perfect appetizer. The baklava for dessert was the best I have ever had! So perfectly warm and sweet.

There was a variety of other customers there, one family who brought their adopted Ethiopian son to eat there for the first time, it was awesome to witness! It seems good for takeout - I noticed quite a few people walk in and get their food for takeout within minutes of arriving.

So I officially started my vacation today (yay!), but had to spend the first afternoon of it at the dentist (boo). I figured to treat myself as compensation I would go have a long lunch a couple beers on a patio. I found myself at Joe's Place for the first time, and am very glad I did.

The service was excellent, even with just the bartender running the whole place. My $5 lunch special pizza was far from gourmet, but it was large enough for two and there were lots of topping options. The side salad was enormous, and more than just a pile of iceberg.  

The patio was completely shaded, and off the street - ideal for a too sunny afternoon. The part that put it over the top was the customer service and welcoming atmosphere. Besides the bartender/server I mentioned, the guy at the smoker (Bill?) when he found out I was spending the first hour at my vacation at Joe's, bought me my next beer. How surprisingly nice!

All in all, a great experience, and I will definitely be back. I recommend you bring a friend, split lunch and a side or app, and both of you can get out of the place with a filling meal and even with a beer and tip for under $10 a piece!

Oh, I almost forgot, the music selection was a major plus: old blues and and country. Loved it!

I've probably been to a dozen or so concerts and shows here in the Grande Exposition Hall at the Silver Legacy.  There are some good seats and some bad seats but the BEST seats are reserved for the "high rollers" for the Silver Legacy.  So you might wanna be a gambler there if you really want to get super close.

Most of the time we have the "bad" seats and still find a way to enjoy ourselves at most shows.  The security staff does a great job in keeping the crowd from getting out of hand.  They also have huge screens if you just are unlucky enough to get stuck behind that 350lb 6'7" guy with the pimp hat.  You can still catch most of the best parts of the show.  

They have lots of bars out front too.  The alcohol prices are a bit gougey but not sports stadium level.  Last concert we went to was 311 and they even had the smarts to do a 311 drink!  Love that kind of creativity.

Most shows wont go past 10 because they need to get people out gambling.  Parking at the Silver Legacy sucks...I suggest just parking at the Circus Circus and walking the nice walk from that parking garage.  Unless you are driving a smart car, then go ahead and park at the Silver Legacy.

3.5 stars

The service was spectacular. Upon arrival, the girl at the counter was very nice and asked if it was my first time. When I replied yes, she asked if she could tell me what the have to offer. Why of course!

So they offer pretzel crusted chicken tenders, dark meat and white meat, spicy vs mild. They also have some sweets that I didn't indulge in (but baked on premises!) I also got their mac and cheese, and jalapeno corn bread. 
So the way they price things here is based on weight. And if i remember correctly it's either $7.50 or $8.95/pound I can't remember.. I'll update when I check! 
But as you can see, it's kind of pricey. For my chicken,  cornbread and mac n cheese it came to $15.46 (and I got 5 pieces of chicken tenders). 

I'll give it to them for the mac n cheese. It was awesome flavorful, with a good crust on the top!  The chicken was A-OK. It was decently juicy, but not very flavorful! Kind of bland.  But the crust was nice and crispy! They also have a handful of dipping flavors for 50 cents a piece. I opted for the pesto parmasean which was super awesome. 
The cornbread was pretty good. A ltitle on the dry side, but I really appreciated the amount of jalapenos in there! I love jalapenos :)

I'm not sure I'd be back just due to the pricey-ness and OK value of food. Maybe if I'm in the area :)

My first visit to Sam's was back in 2014 when I came to Florida for my sister's wedding.  I remember the weather was just a tad on the chilly side for January, but we still sat out on the deck and enjoyed the sunshine.  The thing this place has most going for it is the location - right on the water - which is awesome.  The food was your basic bar/pub/tiki type fare and paired well with pretty much whichever alcoholic concoction tickled your fancy that day.  My most recent visit was last weekend whilst visiting my sister (who is now pregnant!) and pretty much mirrored my first experience.  I would love to come here when it's warmer and I have more time to just sit and bake in the sun with a cold adult beverage.

I love that this store is so close to home! It's my go-to Pet Store and helps me avoid big box chains that I get lost in.  Animal House Naturals is non pretentious, has tons of organic and healthy options for my dogs and is always stocked with the best products. 

They are spotless, helpful, friendly and run fantastic specials. Highly recommend for any types of good pet food, toys, beds, leashes and more.

Tucked behind Starbucks and next to Neiman Marcus is this gem of a fine chocolate shop. The pieces in here are truly a work of art - almost too pretty to eat. Almost. Because not only do they look beautiful, they taste fantastic too. Around $2ish each and worth every penny. When buying an assortment you get a beautiful blue box that they come in which only adds to the classy. I thought I'd never say this but...better than Godiva. And you can feel good about buying from them since they are a local business. I would share what my favorites are but I haven't had any pieces that I didn't love. Stop in for a piece or two...or three. Leave the diet for tomorrow. It's worth it ;)

Cool unique location. I loved my meal - had the chicken pesto - and was very impressed with the dessert!! Service was good and we didn't have to wait to long on a Saturday night.

I would recommend this place! But I'm not really sure what to compare it to because I haven't eaten out much in the downtown St Louis area (I was only in town for a few days). If I came back I'd probably want to see what else was out there.

Hands down the best Italian restaurant in Delaware! Love Luigi and the service here. The pasta comes out fresh hot and flavorful and I'm in love with the penne amalfia. Really huge servings and the price is a killer deal. It's a small unassuming spot but we absolutely love it here!

Very cute spot with friendly staff. I'm a very slow orderer when I go to new places and the cashier was super patient with me and helpful with recs :) 

Overall loved the ambience, food was good. I really liked the iced coffee I got with the house made caramel syrup. Not overwhelming sticky sweet, just the right amount. Very tasty and didn't need to add cream or sugar at all. 

The eggs Benny were good though seemed a little cold when it got to the table. Everything tasted great, only wished it was a little warmer. Loved that the gravy had a lot of black pepper in it so had a nice little kick throughout the dish. The ham was so, so flavorful and salty - such a memorable part of the dish though it's so simple!

 Hubs got the plain biscuit which was good! Again, tasty but room temp when I love me a hot fresh biscuit. 

All in all super cute, tasty, would rec if you don't have to wait a crazy amount of time and if you aren't expecting hot biscuits.

I am in love with this farmers market. I love the diversity and the atmosphere and livelihood every Saturday morning. 

This is a much bigger farmers market than the one in U-City that I go to. I really enjoy meeting the local farmers, the small business's and the independent owners.

Its dog and child friendly and they offer free yoga for anyone that is interested.

I was lucky enough to stumble across GLOW candles and purchased the Half and Half scented soy candle. All i can say is that I can not live with out it and need my house to smell like Half and Half all the time. The candle is seriously the best thing ever. Show that stand some love guys.

I look forward to actually waking up really early on Saturdays and adding this farmers market to my daily routine!

Located right off of Ulmerton, you'll find a small little spot that serves up Thai food, fast. The parking lot is very minimal, 3 spots total so we had to make our own spot. 

I called in my order and food was ready in 30 minutes. I got the beef pad woon sen, ordered the pad Thai chicken and pad Thai tofu for my boyfriend and friend and also the chicken Tom yum soup.

My friend said the tom yum soup was good but there was too much onion. I think if they chopped the onion shorter, it would be better.

Pad woon sen was just okay for me. I'm usually to have snow peas and onions in mine so I was not used the carrots, green beans cabbage. I've had better.

I tried some of the pad Thai and the flavor was pretty good. Not the best but I would say the pad Thai was best dish.

The portions were pretty good and because I love pad Thai, I'd probably be back for it and maybe try a different dish. I was sad they were out of wings but it's starting to become a norm now, with this pandemic.

A small and cute boutique with a nice selection of jewelry and clothing. I stopped in with my boyfriend who politely said he'd meet me outside when I was finished. It's definitely a shopping spot for ladies. The shop was set up nicely with racks of dresses and shirts and jewelry displays. They also had soaps and toiletries which smelled lovely. They have artwork on the walls, all of which is available for sale. (I bought one myself!). 

The shop was staffed well with nice, young, pretty girls. They were all friendly and personable, introducing themselves by name and wanting my name as well. It made for a personalized and friendly shopping experience. 

Not sure if this is a new spot in St Pete, but it would be good for someone who is looking for a one of a kind outfit or a gift for a friend.

I live around the corner and haven't taken enough advantage! Taqueria Corona is a super cute and cozy restaurant. There aren't many places like this on Magazine, where you feel like you're eating dinner at home. They have an open kitchen and you can eat at the bar and watch the food being made. 

Get the guacamole to start. Simple and delicious. Chips are thin and crunchy, just the way I like it! I usually get the tacos. Fried fish tacos are my favorite! Not tiny either, two pieces of fish, great flavor. Two tacos easily fill me up. The burritos are MASSIVE. I'm pretty sure anyone who finishes one will be stuffed. Easily shared or taken home for left overs. I tried the tostada for the first time the other day. I really liked it. I love the crunch of the hard shell. The beans and sauce provided enough flavor and juiciness without making the tostada soggy. Don't forget to ask for the hot sauces! They'll bring you a rack of three to choose from. I've enjoyed everything I've had here, including the margaritas. Portions are generous in size and it's super affordable. I'll definitely be coming back!

I don't love ice cream.... But I LOVE JENI'S. Usually when I try ice cream flavors, they are ok. Or I'll think they are good. But I have a few bites and am just over it. Not here! I struggle deciding because they are all so excellent! And I eat it ALL never gets sickening. Ice cream is usually too sweet and tastes like sugar mush with whatever "flavor" they say it is. but Jeni's flavors are so legit. So fresh, and while they are sweet it's not overwhelming in the least. It's a natural sweet. They all pair so well. So fresh and perfect!!!! I will come here often once we move down here. And my kids are going to loooove it!!!

After having been with AT&T for 6+ years, it was time for a change. My phone was toast (a Samsung Blackjack II that had some water damage via spilling juice on it,) and I was ready to make the jump up to a phone that could handle being a phone, texting, AND data. I had previously been to the AT&T store up in Broad Ripple and was unimpressed both by the customer service and by the plans offered. I'm not even sure I was shown any plans or options or really anything other than the sales person's phone and how "cool" it was. Now, enter the Sprint store. I walked right up to the counter, was shown service plans, offered a few options via an easy to read pamphlet, and was then shown over to the phones to take a look at the different options. The salesperson was very up front with me about which phones are good, which are bad, which people like, which people don't like, and offered me some good solid advice on the difference between a $50 android phone and a $200 android phone, explaining exactly what the $150 extra was buying me, which I appreciated. Of course the plans that I was shown on top of the all-too-fancy phone that I had chosen wound up being fairly expensive, I don't feel like I was cheated out of any money or that I don't know exactly what I'm spending money on. Sprint does a very nice job of making things simple for the consumer, which I love.

The next day, I realized that my contacts hadn't been switched from my old, sad phone to my new, shiny phone, so I went back into the store. I had to wait about 15 minutes to be helped, which wasn't a problem. My only gripe about my whole experience with this Sprint store was that while I was waiting, I wanted to mess around with some of the other phones... but a lot of them weren't working! Had I wanted to buy one, I'm not sure that I would have if the store copy wasn't even working! But that aside, I had a great experience and am not looking forward to any troubles with Sprint.

This whole place is a bit of an abortion.
Too bad because the original fish stand down by Interbay started out really good.
Now it's taken over the food operation at the city owned Sail Pavilion. As such it's a confused mess.
It doesn't run the alcohol. That's run by the Sail.
But if you wanna eat, take a number from the hostess and w onait.
They don't have enough chairs and tables.
If you order a drink, you might find yourself wandering around looking where to sit since the tables are for food.
The food comes out of an ugly concrete bunker too far away. Who designed this mess?
Terrible. The lighting at night is frightfully fluroescent and ugly. Feels like you're eating in Walmart.
Servers are pretty young and clueless. What else is new?
Oh,  and drinks are overpriced.
$8 for a draft beer, plus tip. Serioiusly?
You better love sports because that's all on the TV's and the sound is turned up. Ugh.
Reviews of fish items were so bad i stuck with the burger. To be fair, it was great. Large. Tasty. The garlic fries were also good. But who can't do a decent burger?
The place has all the charm of a football stadium concession stand .

Devon does not disappoint. I've been here for lunch, restaurant week and dinner.

I love the venue and I was so excited to bring the bf here. Food was fantastic and even though I'd been here before, it was just as good as I'd remembered it to be a few years back. 

The amount of food we ate was overwhelming and perfection in every way imaginable. While I enjoyed EVERYTHING from the yummy biscuits to the delicious shrimp and mussels.. I will NOT forget the Butternut Squash Risotto. OH MY. that's all there really is to say about that because it gave me LIFE. 

Our server was a gem and she made the evening perfect by being so attentive and personable. She really knew her stuff when it came to the wine list which was impressive and was genuinely happy to let us try different wines to find a great pairing for the evening.

To finish this perfect dinner, we had a chocolate lava cake (with a candle for the bfs bday.. yay!). Definitely a favorite of mine and I would love to come back and try out a happy hour.

I'm a huge fan of take out Chinese, it may not be very authentic, but it sure it tasty. Tokyo is one of the best. There is also a great upside in that they deliver in the Town and Country area. And on top of that, they also offer a great selection of sushi.

The food has always been extremely tasty and they have all of the staples. Hot and sour soup, egg rolls, General Tso's chicken, orange chicken, sweet and sour, its all here and you can pretty much guarantee that you will find something for everyone. The sushi selection is also great, with all of the sushi staples, plus a few specialty rolls.

The delivery service is fast, and ordering can all be done online. I've never had a problem with any orders. The pricing is extremely good, and $20 dollars will get you more then enough food for two people.

I love ordering from this restaurant, and I highly recommend that if you are in the Town and Country area, put this on your delivery list.

STL certainly is spoiled for the amount of donut companies. I generally lean towards John's Donuts since it is near Soulard when I am in town. But I needed a place for donuts for a brunch on Thanksgiving morning. I called several venues and only Donut Drive In would be open on the holiday. There is a lot of options here at very reasonable prices given the size and quality of the donuts. 

I love the donut holes here. I will definitely be coming by here to pick up my donuts for Christmas morning as well.

Thanks Donut Drive In.

This place is worth all the hype. Appetizers and entrees were delicious, fresh, and creative takes on Lebanese food. The $58 Taste of Suraya is a deal. It's really more food than you can possibly eat. The pita is an amazing big hollow puff cooked in the wood burning oven. 

The staff is very pleasant and efficient. In fact, there are tons of people working here! It's a beautifully lit warm space. Lovely decor. Big, tidy bathrooms. 

The only weak link was the desserts. We ordered two and one was OK and the other way too sweet and just kind of weird. Unfortunate because there are many simple middle Eastern desserts that are delicious. One needn't be so complicated. Coffee good. 

Also, no coat check or coat rack. No place to put one's raincoat, gloves and hats on a nasty winter night. So you're left awkwardly draping it over a small chair and sitting on it. Not pleasant. Even the Melrose Diner has a coat rack! 

Highly recommend.

Tria is awesome! My birthday was last Tuesday and we went there for happy hour. Wow they have heavenlly wines! I loved the red wine that was on their happy hour menu. They have great little snack items too and are well priced. We had a group of 9 and the bill was hardly even $200. We had a fantastic time and the nutella sandwich which was brought to me as my birthday treat was super cute. My only micro-gripe is the service. I know we were a large group and our number kept growing(which I realize is annoying seeing as I am a server) but they could have been nicer to us. The waitress was a tad bit snooty but that might just be because of the type of place it is(hipster heaven). The decor was beautiful and cozy, and all in all the group had a wonderful time!

The good: Great ambiance. Be sure to come early as they run out of things near the end of night. I've had a chocolate chip cookie with sea salt. Cookie was very good but I prefer paradise or sweeties on the cookies. The caramel cake was fantastic! My boyfriend had a chocolate cake that he loved! We've been twice and I will be coming back

The bad: it's always busy, and seating is limited. The price tag on coffee, tea and two slices of cake was more than $30. If you dine in, I'm sure it's worth it, but when you order to go, it seems like a high price.

What a great store.  First time I went in there today since we moved up here a few months ago, and I love it.  I spent over an hour cruising all the aisles and I cannot believe how many styles out in there.   So many combinations of shirts that you cannot find anywhere else what a gem.  I am so excited to have gone here today and I left with a lot of fun clothes.  Everywhere I went in the store staff was great and especially the cashier Deb, she was so funny and we had a really good time.    SHe even got me to open up a Kohls card whoops, don't tell the hubby.   Lol.   I can't wait to see what other styles they get, I have been shopping at another store at the mall for years and online I think Kohl's is  now my favorite  LOL.    Love it.  Very clean, well stocked.  Yay.

I came here to buy my spin shoes a few years back. The guys working here were very knowledgable of their products and so helpful for what kind of shoe I needed. They adjust your clips and tighten them up whenever you need them too also. 
They have everything you could possibly need for your ride. From bikes all the way to personal tools and wear. I mean EVERYTHING! I have a friend that brings his bike to this place all the way from New Port Richie for maintenance. Thats a hike all the way out here. So that by itself says a lot about this place!!!
I needed new wheels for my inline skates, and the guy was nice enough to point me in the right direction even though they don't carry them at their store. I really like their customer service! Its always been top notch! That's always a BIG plus for any shop. 
The best part is that they also give military discounts here. I always love supporting a  local business that returns the favor by supporting the troops! Way to go guys and thanks!

I worked retail for ages. In various capacities. Sales associate. Assistant Manager, acting store manager, merchandiser...

And the thing that can make or break a store beyond anything else (even store layout/organization/cleanliness) is customer service.

Nothing worse than entering a store only to be ignored. The girl I held the door open for was greeted. I mistakenly thought they were greeting me and started saying hello back, only to realize? They were greeting the girl coming to sell stuff... 

And never again did I think the staff was speaking to me or did the staff speak to me. Moreso felt they were silently judging.

I had the opposite experience at the Greenwood location, so it was truly strange.

And the funny thing is? It's like Pretty Woman. I had cash to spend, but no one wanted to help me or even acknowledge me. 

That metallic backpack purse I was wearing? $500. Boots? Over $300. Rails Button Down. Cheaper BDG jeans. My point? I don't mind dropping cash. 


I shop full price retail and resale shops. Mix and match. I have laid down hundreds per visit at the Greenwood store. Also brought them designer duds (Free People, Kate Spade, For Love and Lemons, etc) and didn't complain about the compensation (see Greenwood review for my stance on that)

This store sours the bunch. I just can't. I walked around for maybe 20 minutes. Some stuff had massive pilling (especially in the athletic section)... but if you don't like it? Just don't buy it.

My main complaint and what will make me never return... and possibly to any of the local Plato's (they're all owned by the same person)? The customer service

Exceedingly friendly staff and service. Amazing food with a plethora of varied cuisine! Our server said "house made" almost every other word, because so much of their stuff is made in house. What's not to love about a small restaurant that serves top-notch food and is extremely welcoming?

We had a group of about 15 visit the restaurant on a Tuesday afternoon in early November, which was the day that some of downtown Reno lost power. The restaurant literally got power a minute or so after we walked in, and they said they were open for business. We were seated by the owner and a wonderful server, who were smiling and friendly and explained the menu and specials. They also informed us that the food would take a while to make, but that didn't stop them from still providing great service and checking in on us multiple times. 

We started with chips and guacamole, which involved fried corn tortillas (left in large circles so you could break them to your desired size), and they were homemade! The guac was divine and had a hint of wasabi, something that was totally new and delicious to me! I'm typically not a wasabi fan but I loved it!

I settled on the nachos, which were made of those fabulous chips and piled with carnitas, shredded lettuce, jalapeños, pico, cheese of course (but not the fake stuff!), and to top it off: red chili sauce, chipotle crema, and cilantro pesto! These nachos went down in my "best nachos ever" book.

All of my friends who got sandwiches RAVED about them, so that's absolutely what I'm going to try next time!! For those who are looking for healthier fare, you'll be pleased to know that their sandwiches are served with a side salad and not fries! 

Another item that looked highly intriguing was their coconut cilantro rice, which is another must-try for my next visit. Man, it looks like I'm just going to have to try everything on the menu!!

Decent little spot here! The fam and I stopped in for a bite last week having no preconceived notions about what we were to expect, other than we all love Mexican food, and try to eat it whenever we can!

The restaurant is nice, clean, and welcoming. The waitstaff is a bit aloof, and our waiter only periodically visited our table, each time we had to ask for him to come over, but when he did he was friendly enough.

I did ask for some extra salsa a couple times, and never got it. So there's that, but they were busy and I realize this spot hasn't been here THAT long, so maybe he was just new and still getting the kinks worked out.

The table chips are the same old unseasoned, bland chips you get at pretty much every Mexican restaurant in the South, but their salsa was a clear winner. Excellent flavor, not overly spicy, not bland, not overly chunky, but not watery/ketchupy either. Noticable herbs and spices mixed in with onion, cilantro, and actual pepper seeds. Very tasty. Cheese dip was also good.

I ordered a burrito I wish I could remember the name of. I want to say that it was like "Arandas" or something like that. Either way, it was MASSIVE! There were 4 different kinds of meat in it (carnivores-dream), and it was very, very good. I think it was pork carnitas, steak, chicken, and chorizo. Each one was cooked and seasoned very well, covered in cheese dip, and all tasted delicious together. The rice and beans were your standard for a Mexican restaurant, but serviceable.

One detraction is that their bar drinks and margs are QUITE pricey, with an average of $6 per. While I understand they do run occasional specials, that's just too much for a single drink. We did not get any drinks because of this, so can't say if they are good or not.

Overall, we had a good meal, I left with a takeout box (which almost never happens) and it was very affordably priced! We'll likely go again when next in the area.

The Rules of having a Great Experience at the Well:

1. Arrive Early
2. Go on Pint Nights where pints are $2.75 or Fridays for Bluegrass
3. Order Domaine Dupage or Loose Cannon IPA.
4. Order homemade walnut bread with Humboldt Fog chevre.

I mean, really, you must follow these rules. They're very specific...because any sort of wavering will deter you from returning. That is of course if: you don't like smokey tiny rooms the size of your walk-in closet that are too-loud and stuffy. 

Showing up at opening on a weeknight...yeah..go ahead...accept your existence of being a yuppie who likes to go places other than your balcony. It's okay...really...you like to drink beer. There's nothing wrong with it. 

The wait staff here is just...plain...kind. They answer your inquiries about what song is playing. They just like you. Really...people like you. I promise. 

Plus, they won't make you feel bed for ordering the good beer (ahem...local brewpub who can't stand it when you order beers that aren't their own...). In fact, they love you for it. And, I love you Wellington for having Domaine Dupage on tap.  You're not going to find better beer on tap for that price anywhere in the city. Everywhere else it's either $2 domestics or $5-6 micros. Cheers to this anomaly!

The new bar food menu is refreshing to see. Cheeses, meats, soups, salads. A bit too decadent maybe for Broad Ripple? Ahhhhh patooey...call it "chevre," simply out of spite of what's down the block! 

If you're running late and you show up at 6, be prepared for smoke -- a lot of it. And somehow the Wellington convinces me I like to watch folks play darts. 

Then, on Fridays in the basement the bluegrass...the coziest party in Broad Ripple. Just arrive early to get a table...if not you'll be that casual couple that thought they just could pop in, walk down stairs to find 50 people stomping, clapping and quaffing, and you're left only to retreat to the same ole, same ole.

If only we could convince them to open the basement on pint nights for those not inclined to smoke....

O, and don't be alarmed there's a security camera in the joint...it's gotta be for these amazing tables that seem like they're right out of a Victorian mansion. Good form!

So it's the day of NYE and just about every restaurant in the French Quarter has a line of 20 people out the door. Lucky for us, we came across Desire at just the right hour because we were immediately seated - almost window-side - in a packed house. 

With 127 reviews and counting, let me break it down for you...

Start with oystas! The raw oysters were incredibly fresh, chilled, and served with plenty of lemon. And they their house-made cocktail sauce has strong bite - or should I say a giant smack? ...because that was spice-ay! 

We also got the barbecue oysters. They're fried, glazed in a wonderfully sweet and smokey barbecue sauce, sitting over individual shells and topped with crumbled bleu cheese. I didn't snap any pics, but you gotta check out this photo snapped by another yelper... http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/JvawJ9bSr22xn4R9oLvl_w?select=VL23qeOnZHumSnISqQ0uXw

You can't get wrong with the gumbo, with its rich, thick roux. Probably the best I've had in a while. I also ordered the crawfish ettoufee. it was good, but I had plate envy for my friend's shrimp and grits. 

The bloody mary I ordered was alright. Not the best. It was a tad too thick and had the consistency of ketchup. The flavor and spiciness were there, but I should have ordered another shot of Tito's and thrown in some more Worcestershire to thin it out. 

Service was great. I appreciate how it was so busy, and yet our server kept reminding us to "take our time" and "enjoy your food." Love the Big Easy mentality. 

I'll totes come back. But probably stick with a dozen or two oysters and a nice cold beer.

This is a Bloomingdale's Outlet store, located in the upstairs rotunda of the Shoppes at Liberty Place. (Next to Claire's & Victoria Secret). Just opened this weekend, I popped in on my lunch break today & it was madness. Decided to come back after work and it was much less crowded but still had a steady stream of customers pouring in. The store itself is small, with the majority of products being women's clothing. They do have smaller sections for shoes, men's, kids & accessories. Prices are high, much like regular Bloomingdale's stores, although they were offering a scratch off coupon upon entering the store giving you between 15% & 50% off your purchase. A nice discount which ends after today (11/14). The checkout line was long & moving slow, the inventory was definitely picked thru and some areas like accessories were sparse. 

If you're a lover of Bloomingdale's, I'd come back after the newness wears off. Otherwise you're better off going to Nordstroms Rack across the street, where its bigger & has broader selections.

IF YOU DO NOT EAT HERE FOR BFAST UOU MESSED UP. The praline bacon biscuit was so well put together. The biscuit was obviously homemade and perfectly crunchy yet soft. Loves the atmosphere and dining area. Kept everything cleans me sanitized. Also I dream about their donuts, especially the cookie dough one. If you're looking for donuts look no further

May 17, 2019 Friday - 4:30 PM for a drink
2 adults

Atmosphere - 5 stars
Food - 5 star
Service - 4 star

Background - I have been watching the build out for some time and been waiting for this place to open.

Atmosphere - Sixty plus taps.  That is what is great about a beer bar.  Furniture is mix of styles, kinda crazy, but in a good way.    The bar matches the length of taps, the line bar was three people deep while we were there.

Food
  Drink - Sixty plus choices is awesome.  I had one beer from their taps, Homestyle by Bearded Iris Brewing.  I was a little disappoint in the flavor.  I also filled my free growler that they handed out when you entered the store.  We will see how that Stone Brewing's Stone ///Fear.Movie.Lions Double IPA tonight.  

  Food - I was surprised they actually serve food, so that is a plus.  My wife had the kettle chips that were not anything special but the pizza looked great.

Service - Greeted by the staff warmly.  I know the place is new and a lot of training is going on but my growler was not filled to 64 oz. line.  Most places fill it beyond that level to remove the air which is a beer killer.  Bonus for small little sample glasses, love the idea.

Future - Of course, and the Beer Club UYE is already setup.

What's not to love about Trident. It's a perfect little neighborhood bar with some really good eats. I find myself here a couple times a month for happy hour. The nachos are good and so is their mac and cheese. Also, these are some of the yummiest chicken tenders I have had in a long time. All of these items you can find on the happy hour menu!

Let me start by saying I already know I have to give this place another try. I came here with coworkers who absolutely love this place. It's a really nice hip place inside...very refreshing. We went at lunch time so the place was packed...the line was basically at the front door. The line moves rather quickly so do not let that discourage you. One of my favorite parts about this place is how you order. There's no pressure if you've never been here before because you order from a computer screen....like wawa....and you even pay on the spot. They advertise that they grow locally and it's all natural foods which I appreciate. So you're probably wondering why the 3 stars. Well honestly....I wasn't that impressed by flavors. I feel like I may have ordered the wrong combination....I chose to make my own....and perhaps I just didn't pick the right sauce. I am definitely going back to try something else!

I don't give five star reviews often but when I do, Donut Drive-In tops my list. I absolutely love everything about this little dive of a donut shop from the vintage, neon sign to the ironic name (as it's not a drive in or a drive thru). I've been coming here for years and have NEVER been disappointed. Their goods are fresh and delicious AND they stay open late on the weekends! If your order is less than $10, be prepared to pay cash. Also, if coming on a Saturday or Sunday AM, be prepared to wait in line (but it's worth it).

We were EXTREMELY excited to join the Plantation and Swamp Tours. We chose Cajun Encounters because of the raving reviews as well as the lowest price for a combo tour 2 Plantation + swamp tour and we could do the tours in different days.

We took the Plantation Tour first.. it was fun and low key.. Stacey, our driver, was a local NOLA and she seemed to LOVE her job. She was really informative.. she kept us entertained during our 50 minutes bus ride to Laura Plantation. I will review the plantations separately.

We did feel a bit ripped off realizing that each plantation actually only charges $18/person ..so the $70 price tag for the 2 plantation tours + pick up service.. seemed a bit overpriced.

However, Stacey was GREAT, we requested her to drop us of at Central Grocery after the tour instead of our hotel and she oblige. She even showed us Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie's house at the French Quarter.

The next day... we took the Swamp tour.. and our driver (he didn't introduce himself, don't know his name) WAS HORRIBLE! He was on the phone constantly and he didn't navigate or give us any story about NOLA at all.. the 50 minutes bus ride was so boring!

Then, we went on the swamp tour.... our tour guide was friendly and nice HOWEVER he obviously didn't have enough experience to be a swamp tour guide! He's just a local young man who is likes to talk and talk and talk. When I joined a swamp tour..I wanted to see and know about the swamp. I don't care about American Idol or any hollywood actors and actresses and I can watch E! or ET to get updated of how screw up they could be. I don't need my swamp tour guide to ramble about hollywood all trip long!

It was not the season.. we didn't see lots of gators like what people claimed. We only saw one tiny gator and the tour guide failed to entertain the gator with marshmallow and he also didn't stay long enough to allow us to watch the gator. Then he enjoyed talking about hollywood so much that the boat got stuck between the trees.

The only thing I enjoyed from the swamp tour was feeling the breeze when the tour guide speed up the boat! Also.. our boat didn't have a cover and hello it was 12PM, 90 degrees and on an open swamp and we were there for about 2 hours!

After the boring tour.. we were all hungry and tired and HOT... but we had to wait for 45 minutes because the bus was LATE. The bus was FULL and the only empty seats were at the back of the bus..that's ok EXCEPT..,the A/C was LEAKING to the BACK SEATS so the seats were all drenched and my bf and another tourist had to experience water dripping to their shoulders during the trip back to our hotel.

For about $50/person... the swamp tour certainly failed to impress ..what a rip off!
I love bakeries and there are not enough independent ones around.  They had a healthy cookie made with agave and it was SO good.  We also had a decadent hazelnut and chocolate cookie which i enjoyed.

I tend to not like po'boys and sandwiches with too much bread. With that said, blues city deli makes great sandwiches! I even love how their bread tastes!

I got two sandwiches for me and the bf one day. The line wasn't out the door when I showed up so I actually got my sandwiches really fast. When I was ordering, the guy behind the counter was super helpful. I told him it was my first time here and he gave me a few suggestions on sandwiches -- what's popular, what i may like, what would survive the drive back to the bf's place. When I got the sandwiches, the girl had a big smile on her face. I'm really fond of people smiling so that and hte nice weather put me in a fairly good mood for a while. Good job blues city deli!

And then there were the sandwiches. They were both really good. I got something with turkey, bacon, and honey mustard. The turkey was meh but the honey mustard made up for it. I liked the crunch of the sandwich and the bread was really chewy and nice. I'm used to sandwich breads being a bit crumbly and bleh so this was really exciting. The other sandwich I got had beef and other stuff in it. I don't remember what I got, but it was really good and I ate it way too fast (in fact I ate my half before the bf got to his sandwich halves).

All in all, it's a great place for sandwiches... no, if only it were closer to home.

Whether you are taking your kids out for just a fun dinner or having their b-day party there, do it during the week. If you want to torture yourself by going Friday - Sunday, so be it. The pizza is on par with Peter Piper, maybe slightly better. There's a lot of games, some understandably a bit worn out, but the kids love it. 

Down - they don't serve beer. 

Up - You can just hang out and let your kids go do whatever because they are very observant about not letting kids leave without their parent/s. Everyone in the family gets stamped with a number. 

Last, the bathroom is like a urine scented sauna. Awful.

Food- Really good, they had a special tomato based vegetarian meal I loved. My friend loved his benedict. My boyfriend wasnt crazy about the kitchen sink (too much going on)

My negative here is that the food portions were massive.. which typically is awesome but it was overwhelming for me. My meal couldn't be stored(soup based) so more than half was thrown away which felt wasteful. They also gave us plastic straws.. 
Both the large food size and straws seemed weird considering they boast being very eco friendly and specify on the menu that that they do not distribute straws unless asked

Service- Great service, our waitress was extremely nice and friendly

Atmosphere- I liked the atmosphere, nice open concept. Nothing crazy but I liked it!

My brother took me here and said they have awesome coffee and avocado toast. He was right. Awesome spot, cool hipster vibe (that's ok lol), lots of seating, nice atmosphere and decor. They also sell their own coffee, mugs and other stuff. Staff was friendly. We had two poached eggs on avocado toast. So simple to make but yet so amazingly delicious. Perfectly poached eggs, avocado sliced and seasoned, and a nice thick, hearty, toasted slice of bread. So freakin good! Had an iced coffee and loved that too! Parking can be annoying but after a few minutes we found a spot.

Great food, the cake is A+ and the little patio outside is perfect for some Covid friendly safe meals. We got many meals to go and were very happy with the chicken salad, soup, macaroni and cheese, fruit plate, chicken sandwich and strawberry cake. Loved it!

This cafe is so cute! They have pastries, sandwiches, and cafe drinks. It has a lot of European treats like tiramisu, baklava, and macarons. I had something that was like a tiropita (Greek cheese pie) -- I forget exactly what they called it. And a cappuccino. I love that their mugs are clear, it just feels elegant. My husband had a ginger lemonade, which was extremely heavy on the ginger. I'm not sure he was the biggest fan, but if you love ginger then it might be for you. Otherwise the cafe is pretty open and has a good amount of comfy seats. There's even a room that looked like you could reserve for small meetings if you wanted -- don't quote me, I'd inquire about that first.

After hearing non-stop wonderful things about this restaurant we finally decided to try it out for my birthday dinner. 

The inside of the restaurant wasn't as grandiose as I had expected based off of social media content. But the food and beverage was everything and more. 

I ordered several cocktails off the menu including the Love You Matcha, A Reno Ten,  Basil Watermelon Margarita, and the JaeTea  and every single one of them was perfectly balanced with tons of different layered flavors and unique combinations to make drinks that were completely different from each other but that all pleased my palette. 

With the restaurant being mainly tapas style, we decided to try tons of things off the menu. Some of my favorites included the pork belly sliders, duck wings, and the smoked & charred flatbread. 

Everything we ordered was exploding with so much flavor, presented beautifully, and perfect for sharing. 

But let's just talk about these desserts. We ordered the chef's choice dessert platter and the chef did an amazing job picking out the stars of the show. The bourbon caramel brownie was so good we ordered more of them to-go. 

Overall, I want to eat here every day to be able to try all of the absolutely fantastic things on the menu. I highly recommend putting yourself in the very capable hands of the chefs and staff here and letting them guide your experience through their menu.

Plant-based comfort food, buffalo cauliflower wings with a delish dipping sauce, and local kombucha from Circle Kombucha- yes, please! My go-to is the Chili Mac bowl with cornmeal tofu as the protein option or the Shepard's Plate with the same protein choice. But honestly, you can't go wrong. Even my non-vegan friends love this place (especially the cauliflower-big crowd pleaser). A must-try in Indy!

What an awesome brunch spot. No wonder the wait is ridiculous. I got here on Sunday afternoon with 3 others and waited close to an hour. It was pretty hard to choose something from the menu, nothing really popped out to me. I thought I wouldn't like this place. 

We started off with the guacamole and chips which was amazing and fresh. I decided with something on the chalkboard they have, I guess the specials. It was a country breakfast platter with eggs, thick cut sweet and spicy bacon, home made biscuit and fried red tomatoes. 

What I love is the farm to table aspect, it really takes the food to the next level when you use fresh ingredients. The platter was absolutely delicious in every way. The jam was sooo good! 

I'll definitely return when I'm in the area.

Grain and Berry is the perfect healthy treat post workout, or anytime really.  This was my first time here and it did not disappoint.  They have plenty of outdoor and indoor seating, perfect for the summer.  The restaurant is clean and smells like the fresh bananas located all over the counter.  

I especially liked that they had combo options on their menu, which allowed you to combine their toasts, juices, smoothies, and shots.  I ordered the everything avocado toast which was delicious.  I loved that there was a layer of cream cheese at the bottom.  For a smoothie, I ordered the green whisper which was very refreshing.  The prices were fair, the staff was friendly, the food came quick, and the packaging was durable for to go orders.

Overall 4.5!

Crawfish cake Benedict (4.5 stars): with rich hollandaise and fluffy crispy English muffin. Really loved how savory it was

Concord grape pop tart (5 stars): I'm such a sucker for fancy pop tarts and this lived up to its hype! Flaky pastry and full of seasonal fruit flavor

Savory Dutch baby (4 stars): loved the okonomiyaki twist! It was a bit on the sweet side but fun

Drinks were also on the sweet side but good for brunch

Wait was about 40 min on a Saturday at 11am for 2. Great timing for us to walk down the street for some pre brunch coffee and pastries

Now this is some gooooooood fried chicken, I absolutely loved this place. There fries are solid, their honey glazed biscuit is awesome and their friend chicken is great!

The best part is they're open late, so you can grab some chicken at any hour of the night since it's located right on Bourbon you'll most likely be out drinking and what better way to soak up the alcohol with some awesome fried chicken

Costco is great!  So many options, bulk items, great organic selection but would love more, good deals on nearly everything!

Plan on spending more than you'd like - there is always something new that grabs your eyes!

There is usually plenty of parking but much less open on weekends.  The best time to go is an hour before closing - there is hardly anyone in the store and no lines to checkout!

I'm excited to have a Costco closer to Eagle later this year!!

I have been to Fulton Alley a few times, but have never bowled (I hate it) so this review is really on the bar experience, which has been superior thus far. The bartender, Chris knows how to make ah-mazing French 75s. Perfectly balanced in every way. I have had $12 and $13 French 75s and for charging $8.25 this one is right up there as far as taste and quality goes. I have also ordered drinks off the cocktail menu and have not been disappointed, but a good French 75 rings close to my heart. 

The space is absolutely beautiful. I love the colors and the lighting is just perfection. 
The staff is gracious, polite and helpful from the front/host desk to the bartenders to the management. I love that someone like me, who hates to bowl with a passion can still come to Fulton Alley and have a five star experience. 

On a side note,  people look at me like I'm a freak show when I say I hate bowling so before you chastise me I just want to point out that the olympics featured bowling in the 1988 summer games and it was such a disastrous display of a sporting event it never appeared again in the olympics. Try to argue with that, I dare you.

Ahhhh the park where I first learned to ride a bike. We used to come here all the time growing up and as a family. We loved it because it's small enough that you can see all around it, but big enough to allow kids of all ages to play on the different equipment and run around free. It's wedged in next to a neighborhood and the park even has a paved trail that goes around it in a loop (hence it being the best place to teach a kid to ride a bike!). 

They also have a covered picnic table area which makes it a great place to have a picnic, meet up with friends, etc. Now go get outside!

Came here to celebrate a friends birthday.  There were 6 of us, so we got a booth with curtains that you can close and we felt like we were in our own little world.  

Not having Greek food before, I didn't know what to expect, but I was pleasantly surprised.  Being the beer girl that I am, I decided to try something different for a change (plus no Sam Adams).  I went with Athena which is Creamy chocolate martini blended with Godiva Liqueur (more like an after dinner beverage) and also Sappho Absolut vodka, Apple Liqueur and lemonade (what can I say, I like to drink).  

We ordered the Momos Spread Sampler to get the party started.  You get your choice of three spreads and they are all served with pita.  We ended up ordering 2 of them so that we could sample all of the yummy goodness.  I love humus and pita, and just eating all these spreads was like heaven.  We tried Baked Brie Cheese, Crab Cakes, Steak Kabob Salad, Gyro and all sorts of other goodness.  The best part is that it is tapas so that we were able to share them all.

Great evening with good food, friends and beverages.  My kind of evening!

This is a fabulous gym.  Considering the cost, it provides a lot of fitness opportunities. I look for a gym that has a lot of classes at various times so that I can fit in exercise before or after work. As my work start and end times change from day to day, though, I need a gym that has classes at various times throughout the early morning and mid to late afternoon.  I found that the class schedule here meets that need. The trainers are excellent.  The spin and row teachers are really exceptional.  Try the We-Fit class, but expect a huge challenge, even if you are fit.  The facility is very clean, but this is a new enterprise, so time will tell if the business will continue to keep things clean and fresh.  I love that the women's locker room contains a blow dryer and extra hair ties.  These little things make a huge difference. Thanks for thinking of them.

The South comes over to the West side, and I've fallen in love!

I sat at the bar and ordered an old-fashioned to start, and it was delicious. Simple cocktail that was not too sweet and just the right amount of bitters. After some recommendations from the bartender, I chose the Ricotta Cheese as an appetizer. I really enjoyed this, and I craved for more. The bread comes grilled, and the cheese is easy to spread with a light hint of the black eyed peas for flavor. I ordered more bread because four pieces just wasn't enough!

Next up, friend and I ordered the Grilled Trout, Pork Belly, and the Collard Greens. These dishes are meant for sharing, but honestly, I was hoping that I could just eat them all for myself! Grilled trout was cooked to perfection, and the Pork Belly was a nice take on pork and beans. The collard greens were a nice surprise with generous chunks of pork shank. Seriously, the flavors from all of these dishes were on point.

I am hoping the menu doesn't change because I will be back! And I am super excited that it's opened for lunch!

This is a wonderful, local, family owned grocery store with a wide array of options for dietary restrictions and normal diets alike. Tons of vegan and gluten free alternatives - from cheeses and breads to cookies and ice creams. I've found things here that I've never seen in other places, especially in their spice section! They also carry the usual staples. Some awesome discoveries we've made here include palmini - a pasta made from hearts of palm, The Bean & Beet burgers, and garlic chips from Sam's bakery. They also carry a Florida made tempeh - Arto Moro Tempeh - that is outstanding!

In addition to the grocery, there are affordable beer, wine, and cider options - both individually canned and packs. Lots of local breweries as well as international. 

They also sell pre-packaged snacks and meals towards the back right of the store. While a bit pricey, they are *so* tasty and a nice treat when you're in a rush or feeling lazy. We love their Cajun macaroni salad, curry tempeh, blackened tofu, no egg salad, and kale slaws to name a few. The only thing I'd avoid are the Brussels sprouts as they are consistently undercooked. 

As a huge bonus, everyone who works here is extremely friendly, and remembers the local crowd. I'm often asked about different products as I'm checking out or even given recommendations on similar ones to try next time. The only downside is things are a bit expensive, but you're paying for high quality products so that's to be expected. We usually go here for specialty products and get most of our produce and staples from more affordable places like the farmer's market.

Would recommend this spot for locals and tourists alike!

I had a great time at Sunday brunch with my friends. We had a great seat by the window and excellent service from our server, Page. 
I enjoyed a Bloody Mary, but they did have $2 Mimosas, so that was a great deal.  
We got all of the appetizers. Everything was delicious and came to the table quickly. I especially loved the sausage pancake "corn dogs". 
For my meal I got the breakfast tacos And a side of bacon. I was pretty full already but excited to see that the side of bacon came with five perfectly cooked slices. 

Throughout the meal, several employees stopped by to help in various ways, everyone was helpful. Overall this was a great brunch, decently priced, and I can't wait to go back.

Only one other review that's over 3 years old? Uncalled for!

This is such a cute little jewelry shop. They carry all kinds of handmade jewelry like bracelet cuffs and necklaces.  The stuff they carry is extremely unique and I could see how a lot of this stuff would make great gifts.

Jen L. was right when she said that there is something for everyone here. They have cute little post earrings that would be perfect for a little girl who just got her ears pierced. They also have pretty little rings that any girl would love.

Layla's is, simply put, a great classic honky tonk bar. The elements of such a bar are simple but hard to pull off: classic honky tonk music played by expert bands, an intimate atmosphere that's the opposite of the 6-story tourist traps around it, and some down-home folks who just love to drink and mingle. You'll get it all here. 

I walked in to listen to the band and ended up sitting at the bar and drinking local beers while admiring the enthusiasm the crowd had for some good music. there were more boots and cowboy hats in here than any other bar on the strip, if that tells you anything. They have an upstairs, too, but the long back bar is all you need to make your own good time. 

I would easily recommend Layla's to anyone trying out Nashville and looking for a classic experience. It's a honky tonk to remember!

One thing: thank you. Thank you to Silverspoon for their bacon, the most amazing bacon I've ever had. And an even bigger thank you for the serving size! I was super reluctant to order a $7 side of bacon knowing that most places charge you an arm & a leg for 3 measly pieces but since I love bacon so much, I gave in. Thankfully, I was FAR from disappointed- I must've gotten a quarter pound of their amazing, delicious bacon & could NOT have been happier!!!! I was elated. I also had their French toast which was good but it was served with way too much butter (next time I will ask for it on the side) & not enough syrup (next time I will ask for more syrup). duly noted.

This was the first time going to a salon that specializes in curly hair and I LOVED IT! As someone extremely particular about who touches my hair, Theresa was very understanding. I received the Deva Curl Cut along with highlighting and loved every minute of it. Theresa explained everything to me during every bit of the process and taught me ways to keep moisture in my hair incorporate it at home. 

The decor of the salon was great, so chic and awesome. While the prices were high, it was definitely worth it.

This was our second choice after finding out Rio Mar was closed for Mardi Gras week. We had a hell of a time getting here since it was on the other side of the parade from where we were staying.
   Nonetheless, we had a great meal. 
    Service was spot on. Professional but not overbearing or obvious. 
    A little disappointed that they were out of two ingredients for one of their signature cocktails, but it WAS the day before Mardi Gras.
   The bread and butter at the table was excellent. Crunchy outside, soft inside.
   The beets salad was so much better and different from similarly named items at other restaurants. The greens literally tasted like they had been picked from a sun warmed field minutes before.
    G's Choucroute was a meaty fiesta. He loved it. My crab ravioli was lovely with a delicate Meyer lemon sauce. 
    Bread pudding for dessert was just how we like it - sans raisins.
    Truly a memorable meal. Way better than most hotel restaurants.

This quaint, little place hidden in the middle of the housing area and located next to a church is definitely a place to try if you haven't yet.  We came here for a retirement luncheon so I didn't really know what to expect.  We had pre-ordered our lunches ahead of time.  We had the patio seating right in the middle of the fireplace and some trees and bushes.  It was quite a lovely setting even though yesterday was a little too warm.  They had the fan blowing for a little breeze which was nice.  Our waitress was very attentive.  I think we had at least 27 people there and she was able to get everyone their drink orders in a timely manner and seemed happy to serve us.  They got the order out fairly quickly once our manager arrived and gave them the go ahead.  

I had the grilled chicken sandwich with fries and a pickle.  It was delicious and I will definitely come back.  The only thing I didn't like is the fact that there are actually 2 Saint Denis Streets in that town and my GPS took me to a complete opposite street which was nothing but a quiet residential area.  The one that this place is actually in is called RUE St. Denis St. but even on their website, it doesn't state RUE.  So be mindful of this little confusing thing.  Otherwise, the service and the food were both fantastic!

I have never been in a tattoo and piercing parlor except for Metamorphosis and I think it was a great bar-setter.

The staff: all very friendly, knowledgeable, and cool.  They're exactly what you would picture: the cool girl with a sleeve, a nose ring, and a few other piercings who can hold a conversation and instantly be your best friend.  They were very into keeping your new piercing clean and sterile.

The shop: classy.  There were chandeliers.  Instant class.  In all honesty it was very clean and I felt comfortable the whole time.  It was very well lit.

I wasn't the one who got the piercing, but Metamorphosis made a great impression on me.  My friend loved the work they did and I loved everything else about it.  I would highly recommend this place.

This place reminds me of a bar called Violet Hour in Chicago which I love. This one just didn't do it for me. The food smells and atmosphere got a 3.5 but the drinks were only a 2. I just didn't think either that I tried were all that good. They sounded much better than they were. I had the Corpse Reviver and my friend had the Fish House Punch. Both were kind of meh for the price. The food did look and smell terrific though so if I should find myself in Philly again perhaps I will go back and try it.

I absolutely LOVE this place! It's the first place I've ever had oysters at, 8 years ago, and since I just crave them so much I have to make trips to nola. 
Its not just the food, its the entire experience, its the service, the vibe, the people!!! 
This place runs by a mother and daughter who love dancing to music while opening fresh oysters with a knife. They smile at you non stop, they make you feel great. 
The market has its great vibe all around, people are friendly, talking to each other having great time eating crawfish boil and oysters while sipping on beer from the next door vendor. 
Ysann took amazing care of us, and anyone else there. Let us try a crawfish before we purchased a boil plate, showed us how to eat it, just so sweet and caring. 
She heard it's our anniversary and gave us extra oysters.! 
I will always be back there, it's my staple spot in NOLA. 
Thank you Yissan for the great returning experience :)

This is the biggest MD Oriental Market I have been to in the area.  Yes, it has that distinct smell that my little kids always LOUDLY comment on, but all asian marts do!!  They have a very nice food area in the back to order take out, along with a good size fresh produce area.  Everything was so organized and spacious aisles (unlike many asian supermarkets).  I was on a mission for fresh produce at a lower price and fulfilling my Filipino craving of food!  My goal was to look for egg roll wrappers, rice sticks for Pancit, longanisa sausage and lechon.  Of course, I found everything here and then some....  Kids love this place, as they enjoy the free "aquarium!"  Yes, fresh seafood is available, along with their butcher shop.  Prices are great and they will accommodate to how you want your meat/seafood prepared before purchase. I love going here and leaving with everything I need!

Finally got to try my most anticipated summer opening of this year!!! Here's everything you need to know! 

Service: For me, I tend to value service a lot when I eat out especially because I can for the most part cook the food I like to eat, service makes the experience from great to amazing if done right.  At Southgate, the service was great.  The hostesses were very accommodating and helpful, as this was my first time eating there, they were very helpful explaining that they do take reservations, what their hours were so far, and when they planned to launch the full menu.  With a group of about 10 people, I knew we were going to be a bit of a hassle to seat, but they did an amazing job of having us feel welcome and even sat us at one table and then moved us to the chef's table after it had opened up.  The waiter, which we had actually recognized from elsewhere was super attentive and helpful as well, he seemed to have that balance of not being pushy when it came to ordering and moving service along to being completely absent when we needed to request things.  The other owner guy (having recognized him from the philly.com article) also gave us an extra dessert which was a nice surprise after apologizing for long wait times (which for us we didn't even have to wait that long!) and that attention to small details let's me know they care about their business

Drinks: I. Love. These. Drinks.  From the various cocktails I had gotten to sample from different friends there wasn't a single one I wouldn't order again for myself, and some of them had alcohols I didn't even like.

Food: For dinner I got to try the wings, koreancini balls, pulled pork sandwich and the shortcake dessert.  First off, the wings are probably the best I've had in philly so far, the only thing that would prohibit me from ordering more is the price.  The koreancini balls to me were probably the most disappointing thing I ordered all night.  We had ordered on plate to split amongst our table, and the ball that I ended up with came to me unseasoned and bland, it tasted like fried fluff and by the time I got to my plate, there was no dipping sauce left on my plate because I ate with savages and the late bird gets nothing at that table.  My pulled pork sandwich came and I thought it was great, my only mistake was probably letting it sit while I waited for the rest of my table to get their orders.  In that time I guess the juices of the pork and slaw soaked into the bottom of the bun a bit, making me wish that that bun was toasted on a flat top for a bit +/- a tiny bit of butter.  I also REALLY LOVED THE FRIES. I could eat buckets of that stuff.  My only wish was that it had some sauce to dip it in, because naturally fries are the perfect vessels for sauce delivery and it felt weird not having any.  So, we asked the server and he offered us some of the sriracha ketchup that came on other things, and it was AMAZING!  Ideally if there was a combo meal where I could get wings and a plate of fries and a beer for ~$12-15, I'd be back at least once a week if not more.  Finally the dessert was a very fresh and clean finish.  I don't particularly care for the super sweet desserts of this world, and this was the perfect balance for me where it was just sweet enough for me to want more.

Overall for a soft opening this was a strong showing.  Service is right where it should be and I'm sure most of the food kinks will be worked out over time.  And I can definitely see this place becoming a local watering hole soon!  I'll be back.

You just can't go wrong here. Every time I leave Snap, my thoughts are "gosh, I should have paid at least $4 more for my meal." The atmosphere is inviting and hip, the employees are top notch pizza artisans and the food rivals "fine dinning" pizza establishments throughout Philadelphia. 

Choices for the make your own option abound, but doesn't suffer from the over abundance syndrome that the Cheesecake Factory or other poorly ran establishments fall for. I love the BBQ pizza I make: BBQ sauce, chicken and bacon, poblano peppers, provolone and mozz. After its baked, I finish it with corn salsa, arugula and cilantro lime sauce! PS- add a first layer or the herbed butter to any pizza crust! Makes a huge difference. All of that is just $7.49!!!

The Nutella pizza reminds me of an old childhood favorite back in the South. No visit to Snap is complete without it. 

The presentation is one of my favorite aspects. The wood blocks distinguish your creation from the traditions metal pans that everyone else uses. It's classy yet simple.

Be sure to visit Snap over any other pizza place in the area. Your stomach, and wallet, will thank you!

We had an alumni event here and I really enjoyed it. It's dimly lit, very cozy inside - it's decorated kind of like an old library. It was a great quiet,casual spot if you're looking for a low key place to have good drinks. 

They have a few beers and wines, but we focused mostly on the happy hour cocktails - moscow mules, old fashioneds, etc. Everyone loved theirs, no complaints!

The company I work for in Somerset ALWAYS brings Top Hat in to make our blitzing days here on the sales floor more bearable.

Everything I've tried of theirs has been delicious, and they always have a new special every time they come in! I've tried their caramel latte, frosted mint mocha, and their cinnamon bun latte (all made with almond milk) and I've loved them all. They even create beautiful latte art!

I look forward to trying more of their concoctions!

Oh my Gosh, this is one of THE best meals that I have ever eaten at a restaurant, and I have returned over and over again to savor the moment.

Mr. B's Bistro is located on Royal Street at Iberville, and it is another member of the famed Brennan family's fine dining establishments. This is a very classic white tablecloth, tuxedoed waiter type of restaurants, but amazingly it is not stuffy or pretentious.

Once you arrive at your table, the waiter appears with a loaf of freshly-baked bread and lightly-salted butter as he takes your drink order.

Having been at Mr. B's many times in the past I went straight for my favorite things on the menu. To start I had Mr. B's Crabcake, which was a pan-sauteed jumbo lump crabcake served with their classic ravigote sauce. The crabcake was mostly big chunks of lump crabmeat with very little breading or filler. Following that I had their incredible seafood gumbo which was a classic New Orleans gumbo with Gulf shrimp, crabmeat, oysters, and okra served in a dark roux sauce.
