And now for my entree (pardon me while I wipe the drool off my mouth).... I ordered the legendary Mr. B's Barbequed Shrimp which is their signature dish. Head-on Gulf shrimp barbequed New Orleans style, served in the shells with Worcestershire-spiked peppery butter sauce and French bread for dipping. The recipe for this amazing dish can be found here:  http://www.mrbsbistro.com/recipes_shrimp.php

To finish this amazing meal, my lovely friend and I split an order of the Brennan family's Creole Bread Pudding. The recipe is rich in eggs, cream and butter, served warm with Irish whiskey sauce. Oh, and THAT recipe can be found here:  http://www.mrbsbistro.com/recipes_breadpudding.php.

Seriously, one of the best meals on the planet!

I really love Claudio's cheese selections and the gentlemen behind the counter are typically very insightful and helpful with rounding out selections and tips for what to serve with or augment and make a fantastic cheese/charcuterie board. The olive bar and imported pesto sold by weight are also must haves as they are unrivaled on 9th St. The baked lemon ricotta with Dalmatia fig spread is a party in itself!

We enjoyed this place. Came for a late dinner but still had great service. I ordered the Pho with chicken and vegetables. Was very tasty and the portions are huge. My husband ordered the pork strips with rice and he loved the pork. He is a big pork guy so he must have really liked it since he kept talking about it. Overall a nice experience and we will probably go back.

This review is for brunch only.

My old man was in town and we needed a brunch spot pre-Eagles game that would have both excellent food and delicious drinks. We decided on Supper for Brunch... yes Supper for Brunch. Due to its proximity to the Broad Street line and its cool atmosphere, this was an excellent choice. I went with the Dixie Biscuit and Old Man River got some weird mushroom toast dish. Yeah he always orders the weirdest thing on the menu, and he certainly did not stray from that yesterday. 

My Dixie biscuit was comprised of the following elements: country ham, scrambled eggs, pimiento cheese, and a side of grits and pickles. I of course added the sides to the rest of the biscuit like any country gentleman would do and it was delicious. Very interesting take on a breakfast sandwich and it did not disappoint. However, the name is a bit misleading- there was no Dixie in my Dixie Biscuit as I explained to my dad. The pimiento cheese was some false impersonator of real southern pimiento cheese which should have been made with Duke's Mayonaise and much thicker than this spread. The country ham was not nearly salty enough and you could barely tell that it was in the biscuit. And the grits were closer to polenta rather than the stone ground beauties you would find in the South. With that being said the final deliverable was still delicious, but if you're from the South don't expect to find any hint of Southern cooking in this dish.

The bloody mary was lacking the blood. It had little flavor, tasted a bit watered down, and had no kick to it at all. For $9, it was not even close to worth it. So for a total price of $49 before tip this meal was good, but not quite worth the chedda. Certainly check this place out for the cool atmosphere (loved the light fixture/sculpture) and fresh food, but don't have too high of expectations.

Classy lounge to wind down after a long week. The bartenders are all friendly and make the drinks quickly. This place stands out from the other bars in the area because you can tell the drinks are considered an art instead of a quick tip from customers. I tried the Cask and Ale Old Fashioned on my visit here. I loved it! I do suggest asking the bartender for extra cherries because I only got one. Like previous reviewers have mentioned, the drinks do run between $12-$13. I did not get a chance to try their food but next time I will be tempted to.

There are a few small tables along the back wall facing the bar and some big tables outside for everyone to enjoy their drinks. The area leading to the bathroom shows black and white pictures from the Prohibition era, clearly displaying the theme of this lounge.

I was super stoked when I first heard about WCT- a taco truck! Here in Indy!- so I made it a point to try them at the first opportunity. The first time I went happened to be when there was a big event in the Rip- the mayor was there and all, and I probably was the only person who was like "get out of my way, I want tacos!" I liked the tacos, spicy as they are, because they bring the flavor. I don't have any quarrels with that- but I don't like their attitude, especially when they were on Mass Av and I drove there in December, because they announced they were opening at 10:30. I got there around 11, and they weren't open yet. I went up and asked what was up, and one of the guys said really snottily "We're still cooking the meat, so just wait around." It's cold, and it wasn't like I arrived before you were supposed to open. I did wait and get my tacos, but the love affair was over. I catch them as it's convenient for me, but I don't stalk them like I used to. (Also, I've since learned that because Indiana actually doesn't allow food trucks to actually *cook* in the trucks, there has to be a physical kitchen they use. Theirs is on 49th and College. No excuses for not being open on time!)

My son had a good three word review for this place, when he misread the name on the menu. 

Cheeseburgers and Parasites 


Actually it wasn't that bad, but it wasn't great either. The problem for me, was that if a particular food item is displayed in your restraunts name, it better be damn good. These burgers weren't paradise, they were simply average. They have some decent burger toppings ( I myself got a bleu cheese and onion straw burger, which was decent but not wow) but I was surprised to see that the CheeseBurger in Paradise burger was simply a cheeseburger...served with a pickle. 
To go along with that, the fries were blah, McDonald's shoestring sized yet not even as crispy, laying somewhat limp on the plate. I prefer steak fries, I like girth ( ...that's what she said!) 

Upon being sat, the song " Cheeseburger in Paradise" by Jimmy Buffett, was playing over their stereo system. I had a brief but rational worry that this song would be played on a loop as I ate. Thankfully, it wasn't nor were we subjected to JBs entire catalog but the CIP song was peppered liberally in the song rotation , so that we heard it at least 3 times while dining. 

The tikibar decor was cool but not terribly impressive. The service was very good, although it was pretty dead even for a Monday night. My son loved the paper umbrella that came with his kids drink and I could tell that his older sister, who proudly orders drinks and entrees off the regular menu, was seething in jealousy yet too proud with her "adult" status to ask for one.. 

I didn't use the facilities but both offspring reported that they were "freaked out" by the peeping fish placed strategically in the bathrooms. We didn't get dessert but their Chocolate Nachos sounded intriguing , until I saw the faces of a couple nearby, who got the dish. It didn't look pretty. 

Overall, it was an average experience. I would not go out of my way to either return to CIP or to avoid it. When there are so many places to choose from, CIP needs to distinguish itself from all the other restraunt chains. My advice would be to "beef" up those titular average burgers and to get those rude fish out of the bathrooms, that like to watch people make toilet.

Was in town for the weekend to attend a soccer game; great front desk staff; lovely lobby, clean rooms, comfortable beds, but small pillows! I misread the time for the typical complimentary breakfast; thought breakfast was served until 10:00. I made it to the lobby around 9:40 and was informed that breakfast was over at 9:30. However, the kitchen staff was nice enough to give me a few bagels, some yogurt, and fruit, which was appreciated. The next day, I was sure to get down to the lobby in plenty enough time to make my waffle! 

Loved the space in the rooms for the most part; includes a desk area, sink and counter space near the mini-fridge; but absolutely did not care for the small bath area; hardly enough room to turn around! Also, didn't like that the sink was in an open area outside of the toilet/shower space. Not gigantic deals though, specifically since we only stayed two nights. The staff and the cleanliness more than made up for my issue with the bathroom layout. :o) 

Masks requited indoors, which works for me! Social distancing requested.

Expensive, but worth it.  Tons of flavors and the ice cream is nice and creamy, not gritty.  I love the amaretto or amaretto/cherry flavor with cherries and dark chocolate shavings.  

My father said it was comparable to Baskin-Robbins (the ULTIMATE complement!).

I was here for a handy craft fair, and both the building and the grounds were lovely.  There were artists set up all throughout the building and the lawn, and there was a large tent set up behind the building to accommodate more booths.

I can't review Buona Via on the quality of the food, the ambiance of the restaurant or even the attentiveness of the servers. I can't review on any those things because even though we fully intended on going to Buona Via for dinner, we didn't even get through the door, or successfully into the parking lot for that matter. 

My wife and I were going to Buona Via for Dinner because we had a Living Social deal we wanted to use and we're still hunting for a new "go to" Italian restaurant since our previous one drastically changed it's menu. 

We pulled into the parking lot, into a spot (there were more than a dozen open spots) and parked the car. Immediately we found ourselves being yelled at and told that we couldn't park there. It was the "Valet" who insisted that spot was valet only. So even though we were already successfully parked, we decided instead of dealing with it to pull around to the other side of the restaurant and into another open spot. We got out and started to walk in, when we were again confronted by the 'Valet" and told we couldn't park there because it was valet only. 

Growing tired of this stupidity I asked where we could park. The response I received was that I could give him my keys and he'd park my car... even though I had already successfully parked it twice, I needed him to park it for me. I had no intention of giving this guy my keys so I inquired where I could park without giving him my keys. His response was nowhere, apparently the only way to park at Buona Via is by handing your car over to a "Valet"

Now to further expand on this completely pretentious load of shit, Buona Via is a standard Italian restaurant in the suburbs, this isn't some high-end restaurant in Center City where a Valet is expected. On top of that the "Valet" at Buona Via wasn't exactly someone whose first impression screamed "trust me". Yeah he was wearing a red jacket and tie, however I am confident the last time this guy wore a tie he was being referred to as the defendant, as in 'Will the Defendant please rise".  

So back to the review, the defendant ... sorry, valet,  says to me "If you don't want to give me the keys I guess you don't want to eat here". If was the smartest thing he had said all night, and I told him so. 

Fuck Buona Via and fuck their stupid valet, there was no way I was eating there then or ever in the future. Which is really just that much more foolish when you consider the entire reason a business makes an offer through Living Social, Groupon, etc is to get customers exactly like me. A fat guy who loves to go out to dinner, has no problem grabbing several bottles of wine with dinner and when he finds a place he likes goes there over and over and over again. 

In conclusion just skip it and go somewhere else. There are plenty of other Italian places in the area that will make you feel like they actually appreciate you business. Not to mention ones that are damn good and less expensive for the same menu items. Search my Yelp history to find those places and please take this advice, GO SOMEWHERE ELSE. You'll be happy you did.

I love Macy's...I love their sales and the holiday decorations!!
It is always crowded but it is worth it...
Especially during the holiday season with the Christmas music...

This is a review of the Knitting Factory as a venue for live theater, which I didn't know they were capable of doing until a week ago! It's great to see them really expanding the type of entertainment they're offering. 

Here goes...

When I saw Avenue Q was going to be playing in Reno, I was giddy with excitement about an opportunity to see a live musical performance here in Reno. Then I realized it was at the Knitting Factory, a black box type venue known more for hosting music more than any other type of performance art, and I was all of a sudden hesitant. I had no fear the actors would put on a great show, but I wasn't sure if the venue could keep up with them. 

Three cheers to the Knit for setting up seats with great viewing angles of the stage. There wasn't a bad seat in the house, and we were just about front and center. I loved the show and my time watching it, but as I've experienced here in the past, the sound leaves a little to be desired. There were many times when it was hard to hear the voices of the actors on stage over the music, and I don't know if that's a sound board error or an acoustics issue. Either way, I found myself leaning over to my fiancee, like an old man losing his hearing, asking her what they'd just said. Sometimes she knew, and sometimes we both guessed until we figured it out through context. 

While the guessing game and acoustic challenges were annoying, I'd say my experience at the Knit was A-OK and I would not hesitate to see another live theater performance there again. I'm glad they're bringing a variety of acts to the venue, and I look forward to what comes next.

I was extremely excited to know that there is a vegan spot in East Falls. For the longest, I've been looking for a tasty location that has a healthy options and boom..Terron.

Although I only have tried 1 item from the menu, I love the fact that there is a vegan restaurant that serves creative plant based options. In regards to the overall experience, I called in to place my pick up order and within 10-15 mins, my order was ready for pick up. Smooth process! When I arrived the location was clean, open and they had outdoor seating options available.

Now onto the food! The Philly Magic Cheesesteak was tasty. This is one of the first vegan steaks, I've had so it's hard to compare to anything else. I was surprised by the flavor and similarity that it had to steak made with beef. I wasn't really sure about the presentation, the box reminds me of school issued lunch and the amount wedges were rather slim. Because of my health conscience journey, I will most certainly be back and I would highly recommend! Happy Eating!

I've been wanting to try VV for several months, I finally had the opportunity to do so and I know I'll return. The things I loved about it were as follows:

Amazing customer service by Jill. She had some help running food out but she was the most knowledgeable about the restaurant. She gave very good wine recommendations and knew this current  list. She seemed to be passionate about this place and her role in it. 

I loved the modern industrial feel with lots of open space, and the uncluttered display of bottles to go. While the bar is not large, it seemed to be a popular place for locals to meet up after work. And with options to taste up to 40 different curated wines before deciding on which to further enjoy, I'd be a regular here for sure. 

I love the business model too. Where else can you sample this many distinct wines to aid in the decision to bring some home? Even restaurants that have vast cellars keep the wine by the glass list relatively short. Then if you did find something you loved you'd have to find it on your own. I found the prices to go to be pretty moderate, I think some bottles were under $15 and with the highest one being just shy of $100. I kind of regret not tasting that one;) 

I'm sorry to say I did not love the food, nor did my dining companion. It wasn't bad, but just not up to the standards of the wine I tasted. I think we enjoyed the fig flatbread the most.( half price during happy hour or if on Yelp, half off with check in) Jill also recommended the chicken one but we ordered other items. The poutine was decent, long fries which were very crisp in a tasty brown gravy, maybe too much gravy to fry ratio. Nice size serving for the price too, I took half of it home. The salad was plated beautifully and the beets themselves were perfectly cooked. It was also the most generous amount of burata I've ever seen on a restaurant plate. But the overdressed greens kept this from being great. The mussel small plate was a good size entree for smaller appetites, but broth was very salty. The lager base was ok, but had the broth been tastier, more would have been needed. The shellfish itself seemed a bit dry from lack of broth, and not the plumpest or tastiest we've had. I had the skirt steak main, the meat was done to a perfect medium, nice, and even in this cut was still pretty tender. But the onions were not really caramelized as they had been for flatbread, the broc rabe was very good, just slightly charred but only 3 twigs. The rice was ok. To me the dish was competent in components, but they did not really enhance each other. Lastly the chocolate cheesecake was just ok. The homemade whipped cream helped a little, but I'd pass on this unless you like less dense versions of this dessert. Of everything we tried, I'd probably only reorder the flatbread or poutine. 

I think the wine tasting part of this experience is 5 stars. I tried 10 wines in total, half of which I'd consider full pours of if not a to go bottle. For the whites my fav was the Chablis(sadly this was not available to go) but I also enjoyed trying the NY Chard and pitting it against a twice as exp Napa one. For the reds my clear winner was a Portuguese blend that I almost purchased, a reserve from 2013. Second place was a Cab Franc, recommended by Jill. 

A return trip will be focused mainly on the wines, and I plan on checking their website to see as new things are added. I'm not giving up on the food here though, but will likely not try to make it into a meal just yet. 4.25 first real wine tasting post Covid Yelps

Hot damn!  I love this place.  Where else can one go and not feel guilty about spending a pretty penny on 5 glasses of wine?  Okay, I may be a lush, but it's hard to resist not trying several wine selections from Tria's well-chosen (and adorably named) list... also it's hard to not to indulge in one of their decadent dessert wine, port and sherry selections either.

Mind you, my friends and I were there for at least three hours. (So consuming five glasses of vino in the course of three hours isn't bad, is it? IS it? sheesh) - and in that time, the staff was super helpful, available and friendly.  It was some of the best service I've had in Philly in quite some time.

Loved the location, the ambiance, the space (much roomier than the original on 18th), the big windows - .  It has a decent bar area, that seats about 10 or so.

The cheese list is delectable (I only wish it was more extensive!) -I loved that they didn't skimp with the baguette slices (and they gave us more without having to ask) - Also, I liked that they offer up a spread with your chosen cheeses.  We went for a chèvre, a gres des vosges and a super bold cheese with paprika (name escapes me now) - and they respectively accompanied it with a cherry spread, a truffled mushroom paté and sage honey.  Yummers. 

As our three hours rounded out, we also indulged in some bruschetta - try the smoked mozzarella, roasted tomato and prosciutto (can one ever get enough bread and cheese? that's the question) - and salads (which they generous split for us, no hassle!)

I can see how the place can fill up - awesome service + faboo wine/beer/cheese list and a place you can stay three hours chatting, drinking and eating away without a care in the world?  Sign me up.

I love the Wiccaco Market.  I live around the corner and I think it deserves justice.  I will give it four, because it's not open on Sunday.  The hours are a little off, but coming from Las Vegas, where everything is open 24/7, I find that charming.

They have an incredible selection of groceries, deli meats and beverages.... the cheapest kombucha tea around!

I love the owners... one day I came in, and they gave me some bananas for free! :)

Cecilia is great too..... she's so friendly and always has a nice little anecdote and a smile on her face.  Mom/Pop shops make the world go round.

When I worked in Carillon, we'd often stop in for lunch because it was convenient and a nice alternative to Panera. 

Nature's Table reminds me of fixing lunch at home - only someone else is doing the fixing. I can't explain what it is, it's like they're using the same brands and fresh ingredients you'd use at home.

Popular items include smoothies, wraps, bowls, sandwiches and ohhh their soups - they taste homemade! 

I love their mango unsweetened iced tea and chili best of all, but their breakfast sandwiches are pretty tasty as well. Everything is good - beware of their soft chocolate chip cookies - soooo good, yet soooo bad.

This was my first Drybar experience. 
Wow. 
The stylists work hair magic. Pure silky magic. 
The styles and products are all "cocktail themed". 
I purchased a bottle of Triple Sec. 3-in-1 Texture. Volume. Refreshes. And OMG..... it smells like heaven. In a bottle. It's so good that they sell candles that smell like it. 
Buy one. 
I went with the Southern Comfort style. SoCo is the way to go! Volume and curls. I love this place so much. 
I cant wait to return!!!!
Always a great staff. Lovely service and even better food. The apps are always my go to. I love the drinks option and the drink deals are always a great perk.

My family and I wanted to order simple take out and have a drink while we waited. We ordered our food, paid, and then went over to order a drink from the bar. We were blatantly ignored as we were seated at the bar for more than 10 minutes, and 3 staff members/bartenders walked right by us without any acknowledgement. We were finally able to place our drink order after flagging down someone who appeared to be a manager. For what they charge there was very little alcohol. Presentation wise the drink was lovely! Taste and value... not worth it. We finished our drinks and continued to wait for our food. We ordered salads. To go. Only to be told they thought we left?!? The place is not that big. If we weren't directly next to the order here sign/window we were at the bar directly across from the order here sign/window. We ended up waiting over 45 minutes- for simple salads..they weren't that busy at all.. which is what we couldn't get over .. or what the issue was.. and the dismissal of our presence at the bar. Once we finally received our order- it was made incorrectly and the guy didn't even apologize or offer to fix it. At this point we just wanted to go home as to who knows how long we would have been there waiting on the correct order. Overall that could have been overlooked if it customer service had been welcoming and well just more customer oriented. Sadly, the trophy fish doesn't not earn a trophy from me. Our first visit was not a lovely experience, which is disappointing as it could have easily been a weekly favorite with the live music, ambiance, and seafood!

Car Wash USA is a high-quality wash (really more like a mini detailing) for a high price, i.e. you get what you pay for. You will spend around $20 to get your car washed here, but you'll get a pretty detailed interior and exterior cleaning of your vehicle. 

When you pull up you tell the guy what kind of was you want (I usually get the classic, which is about $19 with tax) and then walk through the building. You can watch them prepping your car to go through by spraying it down and then following it in a small windowed hallway as it goes through the wash. I love my car so much, so I especially enjoy marveling at it as it slides through the wash. 

You can then pay the cashier, cash or credit, while they pull your car around--when it comes out of the carwash, it's not done; this is where the real work begins. They spend about another 15 minutes vacuuming, polishing, doing the windows inside and out, etc. After you pay, you wait in the inside waiting room or out on the patio for the guy working on your car to wave you over when it's done. I usually tip them $5-$10 depending on how dirty the car was, for a total of $25-30 for the wash. Again, certainly not cheap. 

The staff is not really that friendly here, but they get the job done, and that's what matters sometimes. I usually prefer places with friendly staffs, but I'm so picky when it comes to my car, that I will put up with a compromise when it comes to getting the job done right. 

So if your car either likes to be pampered or if it's dirty to the point of almost needed a detail, I recommend coming here and trying it out.

Honey, you so sweet
Sugar, gone a long way to catch you
You so sweet
All I gotta do is add a little lemon
You my favorite drink
You make me think
Honey, you so sweet

I enjoyed a great BYOB champagne brunch here this weekend. Delicious! Did not love the scrapple, but that surely isn't Honey's fault--it's scrapple's fault for being sawdust + "everything but the oink". Big fan of the latkes and the homemade corn muffin.

Thai Place is my favorite...well...Thai place, in the suburbs.  It's almost as good as some of the spots in Philly.  The pad Thai is amongst the best I've had, mainly because there's a Smokey flavor to it, and I love burnt food.  I usually get takeout, but the dine-in experience was good from what I can remember...except the one time when one of the chefs must have called out, because I saw the waitresses cooking in the back. Hence, service was unusually slow that day.  Overall, I highly recommend this place, and I'm already a regular here.

We finally made it to zeppoli! Every time we called for reservation they had been on vacation and finally I was able to get through to make a reservation. I had heard so much good things about it and it was on my list of collingswood Italian restaurants to try. I finally got to cross it off my list! 

This place is tiny and popular. Reservation is a must. BYO. We bought a bottle of wine with us. The food is really good. I'm in love with the pesto and next time would love to try the gnocchi. We also ordered a whole fish which was a special and a rabbit dish. The fish was descent but have had better. Stewed rabbit was okay. We both felt that it wasn't seasoned well. 

Service is okay. The servers are very nice but not very attentive. 

I would definitely come back but only for pasta and maybe to try the appetizers. The pesto is making me drool.

another visit to honey's...and i continue to stand behind their well-deserved 5 stars! while i've dined here many times, i hadn't been there in quite a few months, so when my parents told me they were coming into town for the day to do some shopping and wanted me to meet up with them in old city, i suggested we start with brunch at honey's first.

the wait was typical for a sunday morning, and when our name was called after 45 mins or so, we were happily seated at an outside table on such a beautiful day. our friendly & punctual server brought us our waters and coffee, then took our orders: my mom and i both got omelet specials - the mushroom, tomato, jalapeno & avocado for her, the roasted tomato, scallion & goat cheese plus added veg sausage for me - and dad got the challah french toast. us jews love our challah! 

it goes without saying that everything was excellent, but i'll say it anyway: everything was EXCELLENT! in fact, my dad couldn't stop talking about the latke, as well as many of the dinner items he eyed up on the reverse side of the menu, all day. methinks the folks will be inviting me to meet them here again soon....lucky me!

I love the Howlin Wolf.  They put on fantastic shows from Burlesque to brass bands and everything in between.  It's a great atmosphere and always a good time.  The staff is always nice and friendly and I always end up having a good time here.

The Howlin Wolf den is also located right next to the main Howlin Wolf.  In this dimly lit bar, you can get a drink before you check out your favorite show, you can order food, or you can even see one of the shows that play regularly in the back of the den.

The last time I was at the Den, I had a cuban sandwich with fried pickles.  It was so good!  Way better than your average bar food.

My recommendation would be to check this place out for the "must see" events that they have here, get some food at the den and have a good time.

Smokehouse Burger: Tasted similar to a Beyond Burger. There wasn't enough sauce on the burger so it was a little dry. 

Crispy HipCity Ranch: The texture of the chick'n looked and tasted like real chicken!

Nuggets: Very crispy but dry. There was a hard to describe plant after taste. Loved the HipCity and sriracha aioli sauces. 

Sweet Potato Fries: Very good - nice crispy outside with soft inside. 

Kale Lemonade: It didn't have the tartness that is typically associated with lemonade.

I absolutely love this place.  I've frequented here multiple times and always get fast, friendly service with my latte's made perfectly.  I love their variety and the rareity you can get an Affogato.  Perfect!

If you love beignets, you've come to the right place. This is the best location in my opinion of all the Cafe Du monde. It is located in beautiful City Park with ample setting inside and out. It is far less crowded and much more clean then the French quarter location. They are very heavy handed with the powdered sugar and beignets come out perfectly light and fluffy every time. Plenty of coffee drink choices including the original cafe au lauit as well as frozen coffee drinks and hot chocolate!

Run of the mill yogurt place, really. No special flavors in particular, but the toppings are great and you can have basically whatever kind of toppings you want on your yogurt. The service isn't necessarily exceptional since it's a basic froyo place, but I don't really expect a lot if I'm pouring my own yogurt and putting on my own toppings.

I can't speak to the smoothies, but they've got a wide variety of options for smoothie lovers. They just seemed a little expensive to me.

Busy place and now I know why! It's a great place to get your breakfast/brunch.

Ordered the green eggs and ham and it was actually quite filling. The square egg was fluffy and soft. Brioche bun was delicious and has a slight crisp which I loved.

The nice surprise was actually the sourdough bread with olive. It was about $10 (or $12 I can't remember). It's actually sour but not to the point that you get a bitter aftertaste. It's so clearly hand-made since the air bubbles inside are uneven. The bread has a nice crisp on the outside and it's very soft on the inside. Also quite chewy! I rarely taste such darn good sourdough bread...I hope the overhyped LA bakeries can take a lesson from Helena Avenue Bakery. 

Definitely coming back if I visit SB again in the future!

Why 2 stars? Because this was some of the snarkiest service I've received in a long time.

   ---   ---   ---

I hate to kill a place based on one, young employee that probably doesn't even work there anymore, but... this just couldn't go any other way.

You know those people that sense a younger, laid-back customer, and feel that they can be a bit snarky because of it? Hey, I'm all about that... and that's what I thought I was experiencing here at first. But then after about 6-7 comments, I was pretty sure that she was just incredibly rude, and not worthy of employment.

Condescending, impatient, treated me like a child, complained loudly about other customers, etc, etc, etc. If only I could remember her name, she would be "on blast," as the kids say.

Now... back to not killing a place just based on one bad customer service experience. One of the things I love about traveling new places is trying their local coffee shops. Apparently New Orleans is not a coffee city, as it seemed CC's and PJ's were the best two options. Both served terrible coffee. Like gas station quality. 

New business idea: hipster coffee spot in NOLA. Feel free to steal that one from me, because you'll have no competition. 

Or, I'm just a dumbass that managed to miss these places after much research.

REPEAT CUSTOMERS! We LOVED this cafe so much that we ate here twice plus ordered a box of pastries for the next morning! My husband and I both tried as much as the menu as possible: the croissant egg sandwiches (perfection), House coffee and latte, the bacon onion quiche (he LOVED it), lemon pastry, cherry cheese pastry, chocolate hazelnut, plus a to go order of pastries (the apple turnover, almond croissant, chocolate hazelnut). Totally obsessed with the pastries. 

Don't expect Starbucks level speed, but it's worth the wait. All the employees are lovely and treat all the customers very well. 

We visit the area every year on our "adult spring break" and I'm already looking forward to returning here next year.

Loved our first, albeit brief, visit to the Children's Museum. I can really see this museum appealing to children of all ages -- and I'm talking kids at heart, too. Sorry kids, but I need to get in on some of this building block action, too. 

We spent most of our time in a play area upstairs with a large water table type area, a music room, a sand table, and a little kids area for safe crawling and exploring. Our 10-month-old (crawler and confident stander) had a great time exploring. He doesn't wear shoes yet so his socks got totally soaked near the water table (we had a spare set -- make sure you bring extras if you have a shoeless little). He especially loved the bird houses that chirped when you opened them and the log you can crawl through, all in the little kids area. It was just his speed. He also loved his ride on the merry-go-round and we enjoyed the clever little parade they have at 5 o'clock to herd everyone out of their quickly and festively. Free parking rounded out some of our favorite parts of this visit.

We were there over winter break so it was fairly crowded. We didn't get to try out the slide and we only stuck to that one area since both the kids in our group are right around 1. Our visit lasted for about two hours but it was just enough time for our kiddos to work out some energy and have a good time exploring. I think an older kid could definitely see and do more. 

We went with a friend so were able to get in for free using their guest pass. I think the family membership is definitely the way to go. It's an easy drive/park to get there and I think any kid would be happy as a clam to go back there again and again. Keep in mind, if you use a babysitter and want them to be able to use the pass, make sure you choose the correct package -- you need to show your ID to use the family pass, so it can't be transferred to someone who isn't you, even if they're taking your kiddos!

I totally get the cult of Federal Donuts; the lovechild of Zahav and Percy Street BBQ.  

The old corner shop is in a warren of narrow old streets in Pennsport, and the space itself has a tiny charm that could easily be a time warp to the 18th Century.  Standing in line or waiting for an order creates a sense that time has slowed down, and even the dust in the sunbeams may have danced for our forefathers. The combination of Korean style double fried chicken and deep dive dough balls is a natural fit for preparation, but I am not yet comfortable eating both at the same seating. The double dose of fats challenges my guilt. 

When we arrived mid-Saturday afternoon, all of the fancies were gone, but the 3 daily offerings were available.  Folks were gnawing on their chicken bones at the counter, blissful in their enjoyment.  We ordered a half doz mix of Vanilla Spice, Maple Brown Sugar and Strawberry Lavender to take with us on the drive home.  They were individually bagged while hot, and placed in a larger paper bag, and ultimately triple bagged in a plastic take out carrier.  

Opening the package, the heat and moisture has made the paper sacks damp, but still held in plenty of the essence of the dough wheels. We tried a Vanilla Spice.  It was covered in sugar and cinnamon, cake-like, and uber sweet. The bite and chew was pleasant, but there was no crispness due to the water vapors.  Very tasty.  A very good donut.  Over the next day, the rest were devoured, and although the taste varied with content, the general experience was the same.  A nice round piece of cake with a hole in the middle. 

Federal Donuts deserves another house call earlier in the day when the fancies are in stock, and again for a unique fried chicken experience, which seems as varied as the sweet fat tires. 
After those ingestions, an update will be in order. 

Until then, the consumed donuts themselves were not life altering, but were certain A-Okay!

With this harsh winter weather, my skin was in dire need of some TLC. After reading a lot of reviews, I decided to try out Rescue and thank god i did. I'm pretty sure my skin thanked me after my facial with Joanna. 

First off, I loved the vibe and service inside. I walked into a beautiful place and was welcomed with all smiles and taken care of immediately. 

After walking in for my appointment, Joanna made me feel very comfortable. During the facial she gave me some advice and really gave MY skin what it needed. I appreciated the time she took to figure out what i needed and she was absolutely right. 

After my facial, I was glowing and felt wonderful. I certainly plan to make another appointment soon with Joanna! Thanks Rescue!

This place is fantastic. I love me some good BBQ, and I think this place is my favorite. Everything I've ever ordered on the menu is perfect. The ribs, the tips, the pork, and the wings all rock. The hot sauce is possibly the best BBQ sauce on earth.

Shades of Egg just rocked my world. The way they had the sunny side up egg cooked on a layer of salty, satisfying cheese really made this sandwich for me.  The sprouts, greens and avocado made this beast a little healthier, too.  I love that you can choose what bread you want it on.  The coffee was great, and I even found a cool magazine to read while I ate.

So this is going to be a lengthy review. 
I hate to love this place, but damn the food is amazing. 
However, the staff is extremely rude, and in the pizzeria, they aren't Italian and they barely speak English.
The bakery portion however is incredible. 
Now I've gone in and eaten and it's hotter than hell in there and they got my order wrong twice before finally getting it right but once they got it right, it was the best chicken cheese steak that I ever had. 
I've also called out for delivery and it took over 2 hours to get to my house (less than a mile away). Also, it was so expensive and the order was wrong. When it finally got to my house too, it was so cold.  I was furious. They refused to refund us or help in any way too. Trust me, I called several times to complain. 
So it's tough because the food, when it's right and served at the right temperature, it's some of the best food you can get.  The rolls are amazing. But the service absolutely sucks and DO NOT trust them for delivery.

We took my dad to Blue2O for his birthday. Both my dad and myself, love seafood, so reading the reviews and lacking knowledge of any other good seafood place (now that Bookbinders is closed) we decided to give this a try...
The drinks were just okay on their own merit, but considering the price, I am not sure either of the drinks was worth it...
I was shocked at the selection of oysters... for a seafood restaurant I expected a better selection...
The main courses were fine in and of itself, but none of them justified the price..
All in all, it's not a bad place per se, but for a lover of seafood, but it is severely overpriced for what they provide...

Back in Jimmy John's heaven!!! 

I decided to try something different this time and ordered a No. 16, Club Lulu. Why did I have to deviate? I should have stuck with what I know, No. 12 and 7. Hate to say it but the bacon was too chewy for me.

Neverless, Jimmy will always be in my life. No words could ever convey my love for their sandwiches.

I love El Charro; it's one of my favorite Tucson staples. I come here with my family to celebrate a lot of special occasions, and we bring many out-of-town visitors here. The atmosphere at this location feels a bit more upscale considering the decor. The service is usually pretty decent; I've never had any problems, but I've never been blown away by it either.

The food is always good. The chips and salsa are tasty and they keep them coming. It's hard not to fill up on chips. For appetizers, the guacamole and the cheese crisps are great. I stick to a handful of entree items, but I love anything with the carne seca, especially the chimi with red enchilanda sauce. The chiles rellenos are excellent, and the enchiladas banderas are also delicious. I love the chicken tortilla soup as well. I don't prefer their rice though; it has peas and carrots in it, and I detest peas, but whatever.

If I get a drink, I will usually do a house margarita, or we'll order a pitcher for the table. We rarely get dessert, but if we do, it's the tres leches cake. Yum! I've tried the flan before, and it wasn't very impressive. Tres leches for the win!

Great spot for a slice, salad, and a beer! 

But let's dive a little deeper! The spot:
During current COVID times, you can only order food to-go or sit outside in their large outdoor patio. The tables are spread apart and when they clean their tables, they put a clean sign on it. Which in my opinion is very smart and eases the mind. Great ambiance at night, they have lights and a fire pit. They used to be open late night, but their hours have shortened. They have a specials board by the ordering window, be sure to check that out. Street parking is available, mostly metered, but they have a small parking lot behind the building too. Staff is friendly and customer service has always been great. 

The food: 
The vegan ranch is everything! Grab the rabbits salad full of all the veggie goodness and top it off with this magical sauce they call vegan ranch (doesn't taste vegan either)! It's pretty addicting and pairs nicely with your pizza too. I'm a fan of their creative monthly pizza specials, you can always find them on their website. They have inexpensive daily slice specials and they're pretty big. The Ol' dirty is my favorite: salami, ricotta, olive oil, and pepperoncini - it's the perfect flavor combo and it's not too heavy. The crust is perfectly thin. I highly suggest grabbing the slice and salad special, you won't regret it. It's a great deal!  I love that they offer meat, vegetarian, and vegan options - an awesome variety of pizzas for every craving. 
Bonus: You can also get gluten free crust on any regular 12" pizza for an additional $4. 

Lastly, don't forget the knots! If you like garlic, you'll love these warm soft pillows of doughy garlic goodness sprinkled with fresh garlic on top (which you can omit). They're served with their house red sauce and your choice of two other sauces...I suggest the vegan ranch and the creamy basil cashew spread. All vegan! So delicious! If you're feeling like something sweet, the dessert cinnamon knots are equally magical. 

The drink: 
They serve beer, wine, and cocktails. Since they have scaled back on service, they only offer a smaller menu of drinks. But on the positive side, you can still enjoy an adult beverage while waiting for your order or while dining in the patio. 

Overall, a great spot for tasty food and a pretty chill place to enjoy and relax.

BOISE, ID: Best gas station in Idaho!  I love this place.  For instance:

1. On the airport grounds, so you never have to worry about getting prepaid rental car fuel

2. Plenty of gas stalls

3. Amazing selection of treats, drinks, and alcohol, including local items

4. Clean as a whistle, including super clean bathrooms!

5. McDonalds inside.  I don't eat there, but it's a plus for those who might

6. Carwash

Basically, a king among gas stations.

Was taken here for lunch by a friend that works at the New Orleans Museum of Art as a good local place. It was, in a word, good. We started with tasty bites she grew up with: pork and rice, fried like a croquette and served with pickles and a herb mayo. Little balls of porkie goodness. Next came a sandwich...fried chicken topped with fab coke slaw on a bun. Also, yum!! I love dining local.

It's been over a year since I moved from Edmonton so this review is REALLY late, but I still have fond memories of Lucky Supermarket! My husband and I loved coming here nearly every week to buy our groceries (produce, meats, Asian sauces and dried noodles). We always found the staff to be friendly, especially the people behind the meat section. There was also this one guy in the produce section who always had a smile on his face. He was pretty awesome. The supermarket is spacious, bright, and kept quite clean. Prices were quite good for the majority of items compared to its big name competitor, although we would buy our dairy, western products and most canned foods next door at Superstore. Coming from Vancouver I really took for granted the availability of Asian ingredients in the city, so I really appreciated the range of ingredients and products that were not always easy to come by living in Edmonton. Moving back home to BC I knew I would miss Lucky terribly, but imagine my surprise and delight to see a "Coming Soon" sign one day while driving through Surrey, BC. Lucky's coming to BC next year! So, soooo excited.

Ordered from drive thru. Super quick and friendly service. I had to order their new chicken sandwich. It looks just like chick -fil-A. Let me tell you. It was amazing! I think I may like it just as much or maybe more. I truly hate that I love it so much. Lol

I've been here for conventions, volunteer events and for a stay-cation with old Marriott points (excellent rewards system- look it up) and I've been wowed every time. 

It's fun for conventions, as it has views of Victory Field and Lucas Oil (and I love when people from out of town get to take advantage of that!). Every event I've attended here has always run smoothly and without confusion. The hotel feels luxurious and I've been well taken care of each time.

The rooms are comfy and I've never had a problem with it being too noisy, despite all the events they host. The parking can be quite expensive, so be aware of that beforehand. 

Definitely recommend to your visitors!

Been here multiple times, and I've never had an issue. The most recent visit was for the end to a boozy day in the city. Pina coladas were on point, and even though they're from a machine, wayy more alcohol in them than the Margaritas in Center City that were more expensive. Shots are full sized, the waitress was attentive and kind, and the location is ideal for the area. 

Along with the drinks, and the rowdy weekday nights sometimes, I've also always loved the Spanish fries, which stick to the paper sometimes but there is so much extra cheese you can hardly notice! Come for half-priced burger and sandwich Wednesday for an early dinner, or any night of the week for half price quesadillas and drink specials. Will eat here again soon and try something new after all these years!

Our waitress was great, helpful, always smiled, and always checked on us.  The restaurant is nice, and has a nice dog friendly patio.  But, I am sorry to say that I am a pizza snob. I'm from chicago, and I love pizza - deep dish, pan, thin crust. I love it with tons of sauce and flavor in the crust.  It's fine for me to ask for more sauce on the side. I just feel like the crust was nothing special to me. 

It's hard for me to find that in FL. I have found a couple places, but I can not say that this is the place.

Tracy definitely understood the assignment!! I actually was headed to another nail salon and I came upon Clayton Nails. I pulled up the yelp reviews and saw the ratings were good so I decided to walk in thinking I would have to wait. They took me right in and Tracy was my nail tech. I told her I liked fun nails and she happened to have on a shirt w a rainbow on it. I took my inspiration from her shirt and here we are. I Love my nails. They have won me over and this will be my nail salon home from here on out. She was fast and efficient and gave me exactly what I wanted!

Chiang Mai Thai has simply the best Thai food in Indianapolis - at very reasonable prices. 
We went there with friends for dinner on a Friday night, and I was surprised how empty the place was, given how crowded restaurants tend to get in Broad Ripple, especially on the weekends. Service was good, the menu is extensive - it definitely has items other than the usual suspects at Thai places. My partner ordered the ginger lover, and I had the mango curry - they were both excellent. My mango dish was a combination of mangos, green beans, green and red peppers and tofu, in a tasty spicy coconut-turmeric base. 
I highly, highly recommend Chiang Mai - I hope the slow evening was just an anomaly. I will certainly be back to support them.

This is my favorite location because of the outdoor seating. Love the boozy iced coffee. Today it came with nutmeg on top (ew) which it shouldn't, according to the drink menu. But that's not a big deal. Food is always tasty! Especially the cochon it's always cooked perfectly!!! Today I got the burger and switched it up. Going back to the cochon lol

This review is long overdue. I love brunch at Horn's eatery and so do many others based on how long the wait can get on a weekend. The wait can get a little long, I think we waited for 30-40 minutes on a Saturday around 11 AM but once we were seated the service was fairly quick and food came out in a timely manner. It's definitely worth the wait though. My boyfriend and I brought our dog and sat outside and the staff were super friendly. They brought our dog water and pieces of bacon for him to snack on. I highly recommend getting the oyster Benedict. You won't regret it. They are also very generous with their portion sizes. Their Bloody Mary had a nice kick to it. 5 stars!

There is no better feeling than leaving Aldi with a sh*t-ton of groceries for less than a hundred bucks.  

This place keeps the costs low by doing a couple of unique things....the first is you have to "rent" a shopping cart if you want to use one...so be sure to bring a quarter.  Don't worry, you'll get your quarter back when you take your cart back to the front of the store and connect it to the other carts.  I freakin' love this because it is MY BIGGEST PET PEEVE at other stores when lazy-arse people leave their carts right next to their car when the cart corral is RIGHT BESIDE their car.  It really grinds my gears. 

The second thing that saves you dollars is they do not give out plastic grocery bags for free.  You can buy paper bags for 6 cents each or bigger plastic bags for 10 cents.  They also sell the reusable bags for like $2 I think.  You are welcome to bring your own bags from home, too.  After you check out they have a nice big counter where you can sort and bag your items before you head out to your car which is nice.  

They don't really have nationally-known brands here with the exception of Coca-Cola.  Every item I have tried is high quality and comparable to main brands, however.  The quality is high enough that you most likely will not miss your brand name items.  

Their produce is ridiculously cheap and makes it really easy to eat heathily on a budget.  They have a great meat selection, dairy aisle, bakery section, canned goods, dry goods, beverages, and a lot of hygiene items as well.  

I like keeping my dollars!  And I like high quality foods!   It's a win-win.

They have lost me as a customer...might return to Honda one day, but I'll be using a different dealer for sure! 

Not only did I have some service-related issues on my second leased car (including multiple visits on what ended up being a simple low fluid issue) but what happened at the end of my lease was just sad. We came in to talk about buying our beloved 16 CRV, asked for a price comparison on a new lease (new safety features as we start a family) and were given a number on each that was significantly higher than my monthly payment on my previous two leases (almost $500 a month) - is that any way to treat a loyal lessee? 

We've purchased a used RAV4, and our next Honda (or any other car) will come from somewhere besides Conicelli. I don't know if it was the salesman in training or some other issue, but the transition between my first and second lease was much smoother (with the experienced salesman who obviously wanted the vehicle off the lot)

I love the freshness of this place. The juice. The food. The açaí bowls. Everything is fresh. You can literally smell the fruit when you walk in the door. 

Pros:
The juices are delicious. You can literally watch them make it. I've tried multiple and I have not been disappointed yet. 

The avocado toast is amazing. Sliced avocado versus smashed would add to the texture but overall delicious. 

Nice wide tables to stretch out. Allows you to sit at the table with a stranger and not be next to them. 


Cons:
Seriously lacking on the greeting. Whether at the cash register or picking up to go; it takes what feels like an eternity before someone acknowledges you. Today, I timed it, almost 3 minutes before anyone acknowledged I was there. 

The knives. Your avocado toast is DELICIOUS! But it is no match for the knives. 

Today, I'm giving 4 stars because the food is everything the company promises it will be. But the lack of greeting is a turn off

Lovely place for dinner. We will be back!

Started with these appies:
- hummus: must have (so delish and the pita was so light and tasty
-apricots: these were not bad but not my fav, prob cuz I'm not a fan of mixing sweet with dinner dishes
-pastrami: must have (so tasty, the mix of salty with the cheese and the figs was the perfect blend and I don't really like figs but u cuz taste them slightly
-meatballs: these were also tasty although I much preferred the pastrami dish

For our entrees we shared the sea bass and grilled chicken. Both were so tasty but my fav was the sea bass. Highly recommend!  Not a fan of the rice that comes with but the salad and grilled veggies were good

Came with a larger party of 5 on a quiet Sunday brunch morning. First off, the building is amazing! I'm truly in love with it, we sat on the second floor with all the bright windows empitamising the openness. It's a perfect mix of modern (gray everywhere, my favorite home decor color), with older style of subway tiled bars and hexagonal tile floors. Yes, I had to spend time and Google the history more while we were waiting. I only wish I could have experienced it in its heyday. 

Not sure who our server was, but she was great. We stayed for a while as we ended up staggering drink orders (a beer to start, then a whiskey, the one bloody Mary, then another etc). She let us take our time and catch up too, not hurrying us or being annoyed. 

Between us all we had duck sliders, macaroni and cheese, traditonal burger, the German and the pork belly tacos. My impression was everyone enjoyed their food. The burger disappeared, we made our friend make the Wendy's "$2.99" joke with the sliders, the German had great flavor and the macaroni and cheese was ooey and gooey with real Bacon crumbles on top. The ketchup is house made and delcious. The tacos were good just cory was expecting soft tacos not fried, but he survived. He already said he is getting the depot burger next time.

I have been craving some creme brulee which they didn't have in their dedicated and fancy sounding dessert list, but they did have a creme de pot (so custard) with house whipped cream and some sort of black sprinkles I missed the name of. Whatever they were, this was a perfect ending to my meal and I wouldn't hesitate to order it again.


The bloody Mary's were excellent, also house mixture. But the happy hour looks to be a good deal, about $2 off drinks and apps it looked like. I think while they have spendier items, they also have a good deal with cheaper options that aren't just olives or fries like you see elsewhere in town. 

I had been putting off visiting thinking it would be pretentious and break the bank, and while between us all we splurged for this meal, you come back and not spend much while still getting a lot of quality food. 


Also they have the bean board games (the name is completely escaping me right now) out front that we all had fun with too. Ideal for killing time if waiting per chance? As well also a huge luxury couch with games upstairs too.

It's obvious everyone loves this place and what's not to love about reasonably priced, authentic and bomb-ass Southern food? This is by far my favorite place to take visitors. There's no denying that the 2-hour wait to be seated on any given night is a pain, but it's soooo worth it - why else would people stand around sipping watermelon mojitos? Come check it out and let the food speak for itself.

Honestly, hard to have a bad seat in this place. It's only about 18,000 seats so has always felt full to me. The atmosphere is GREAT! I love going to games because the fans are awesome (even when the team isn't so hot...). Unfortunately with it being down in Chester you pretty much HAVE to drive. Buy your parking passes ahead of time and park at the stadium. Some of the lots nearby charge $30!
Such a cute spot nestled on a small street! I love their buttermilk donuts and the vibe of the place.

HATERS!!! 

Apparently yall haven't figured out the true joy of the Esplanade Mall, which works for me!  The best part of Esplanade Mall, because it isn't that busy, is that when Lakeside stores (Gap, Bath & Body Works, Victoria's Secret, etc) are all sold out of stuff you can pretty much bet that they have it at Esplanade.  I also LOVE that it isn't crowded and I can go to Macy's and Dillards without fighting the teen queen crowds (especially on sale days).  I also love not tracking to Harahan or braving Canal Street traffic and parking to get to the Children's Place.  Again this is all perfectly fine with me that you don't like or frequent the Esplanade.  

I was a bit sad when Zea's moved out to the old Chevy's (I liked Chevy's) but having the Target there is going to be HEAVEN (cue the choir!)  The Target in Metry is always sold out of stuff especially when its on sale and I will LOVE that the haters may not frequent this location either I can only hope that the bandwagon doesn't fill up and yall figure out my super secret heaven that is the Esplanade Mall.

I love their selection of different produces and products. From Walkers (Lays) roasted chicken chips (which are absolutely atrocious), prickly pears, Japanese sweet potatoes...etc. I feel that in general, you can't find these things at other intl markets. The workers are very nice and were helpful when I was looking for certain items.

I've had such horrible experiences at other nail shops I rarely try a new one but my gf highly recommend this gem and they didn't disappoint. The tech listened to my concerns and was extremely through and lovely to work with. The shop was very clean and was practically odorless (normally shops smell of acrylic) I will be back :)

A solid 4 stars for me. Although I am not a "beer-lover", the idea of a brewery in Wesley Chapel gives me hope that we are expanding the adult experiences in the neighborhood. 

It's bright and open with lots of seating for either outdoor and indoor dining. Great place for groups! Our server, Asia (I can't remember the exact spelling), was just wonderful and attention. We did flights at our table and for a "said beer-lover", you have quite a few options to choose from. There aren't much ciders on the menu for those who don't fancy beers. Bummer. 

I think where I deducted a star was the food. The appetizers was great! From the wings to the cauliflower; equally flavorful and greatly enjoyed at the table. But the entrees fell short; I didn't like the fish and the burger was average. It gave me the impression that their expertise was appetizers, and main entrees was a new addition to the menu. Either way, I would go back but will stick to the shareables.

I was a guest at Hilton and this restaurant was located onsite. First impressions: I was not asked what I wanted as I sat, not even water, just an empty glass at the table. I had to ask an employee cleaning a table to help me get the waiter. So not a great first impression. When I placed the order, it did arrive quick which was a plus. I had the crawfish etouffee. At first sight, I was disappointed at the quantity for the price. Was really small and I was done eating in like 2 minutes. Lol. However the taste was alright. I also had to ask about the dessert, waiter did not offer or ask if I was interested in dessert. However I loved the bread pudding. The cold Ice cream and warm pudding made for a nice melt in my mouth. If you like pecans, you'd love the crunch as well. I loved the ponchatoula punch. Well balanced and sweet. Rating 3 stars because I don't think I got a bang for my buck with the entree and the customer service was less than ideal.
We loved this place! Great racing track for kids and adults. The staff was friendly and the games were on time.

This is the perfect place for a low key, affordable quick dinner with friends, especially if you plan to go shopping nearby after!

They have a wide variety of options on their menu but I have primarily only had their sandwiches [I really like sandwiches], their variations on the club being my favorites. You can easily customize a meal if needed. 

You order first and then pay and then it is delivered to you at your table with a number, super easy. If you want to browse the menu before getting up to the order area, they always have paper copies by the door. They also have a really slick to-go ordering system at a separate register. 

What is most awesome about this place? The free ice cream, yesss. Who doesn't love free ice cream? It is just a simple vanilla chocolate soft serve though. I almost always opt for the swirl in a cup to maximize amount, haha. 

They also have two types of ice, regular and crushed, which gets some people super excited, I guess.

I decided to give Love Nail&Spa a try after eating at Kyoto's. I was seated at Winnie's station and she immediately started working on my nails. I show her a hello kitty design I found online, WOW, she did a perfect job. She also throw in a incentive(shhhhh, don't tell anyone:)) for me which I was thrill. Don't ask me what it is, is a secret:) 

I returned to Love nails a second time few weeks later to get refill and a spa pedicure for me and hubby. I request to sit at Winnie's station. Don't get me wrong, the other esthetician are nice too, but since Winnie done the perfect job last time, I figure to stick with her. Again she did a perfect job on my refill. And we love the spa pedicure at Love's. 

Really love the staff at Love's nails. My 2 year old toddler act up every time we were there. Both times, staff came over to entertain her. They even let her soak her little feet in the pedicure station while Daddy gets his feet done. AWESOME!!!

P.S. If you forget to bring cash to tip, no worries, there is a no fee ATM inside. Don't forget to get your loyalty card stamp, once is full, you will get $5 off.

Came here on both Friday and Saturday night of Jazz fest weekend. On Friday the Wolfman was playing which was an unexpected treat. And I can't remember who was playing on Saturday but I was all the way up at the front getting dizzzown. 

The setup is a little different, but that is part of what gives it charm. I especially love the big windowed nooks that allow for great people watching and for making crazy faces at unsuspecting passerbyers. The bathrooms are well kept and I never had to wait long to use them. 

I only drank abita purple haze so I'm not a good judge of the bartenders mixology skills, but there is indeed quite the selection of beer. 

The area that d.b.a. is in is one of my favorite in new orleans, the french marigny. When I hit NOLA I will definitely be coming back.

I'm embarrassed to admit how much I frequent The Eagle.

Actually, no I'm not. I love this place :) Whether I'm stopping in to pick up my grilled cheese for lunch or swinging in after work for a drink with my co-worker friends, I am always pleased with the atmosphere, service, and food/drinks. 

Let's back it up to that grilled cheese. Pears and apricot spread may have you backing away from this one, but trust me: you gotta give it a go. They are known for their fried chicken (which is AMAZING) but do something different and opt into this childhood favorite next time. Your tastebuds will thank you.

I'm more of a beer gal but I recently went with a friend who tried the Mule and I was all about that little cocktail after that. I'm here to tell you that no matter what you get, you're going to have a great time. Stand outside on the patio or snag a table indoors, you'll want to make this your crew's hangout in no time!

Um, yeah.  Still friggin' delicious.

Justin and I stopped by Pi before the Neko Case show at The Pageant (located conveniently across the street for all you concert-goers) this week and *finally* tried the deep dish pizza.  Now here's the thing--I grew up eating Chicago-style deep dish and I think I'm supposed to have some sort of loyalty to it because it's my home 'za, yo.  Kinda like so many St. Louisians inexplicably love Imo's.  Anyway, the point is, I've never been a huge fan of the belly bomb that is deep-dish pizza.  Too doughy, too much freakin' cheese (yes, indeed--there IS such a thing!)--I've just always preferred thin crust.

Well.  Smack my ass and call me a convert.

"It's the crust!"  I kept saying.  "No, it's the sauce!"  Justin countered.  Whatever it was, the deep-dish pizza at Pi is by far, hands down, the best thick crust I've ever eaten.  And I have eaten my fair share of it, people, usually begrudgingly.  No more.  I'd happily hightail it back to Pi to build another custom 'za... This time we enjoyed a pizza with the prerequisite tomato sauce and mozzarella, to which we added zucchini, tomatoes, feta and garlic.  Now, when we got the pizza I thought I spied a mushroom (which Lulu W. so aptly calls "slugs with gills" - yuck), but upon closer inspection it turned out to be a whole roasted clove of garlic!  Ohhhh, foodgasm.  So yeah, basically, this was the best pizza ever.  The cornmeal crust is crisp enough to stand up to the delicious sauce and just-right amount of cheese, and you can actually eat more than one slice (this I've not done before).  

Yup, I'm changing my tune on the whole deep dish issue.  Sorry, Chi-town.  You still rule my heart, but Pi holds a special place in my belly.

This place is awesome in the summer!!! I love sitting outside on their porch with a cocktail in hand. The environment is so fun! The food and timeliness of drinks / service could be faster. If looking for a cute cocktail or date spot - must check it out!!!

Ending up going to The Love because I'm intrigued by any menu with biscuits, and we were able to get in during their Brunch menu. The set-up they have for outdoor dining is well designed, and protected away from next door dinners. Although we did not get cocktails, we did get appetizers -- candied bacon strips and biscuits which are similar to the size of mini-muffins but taste more like baby buttered biscuits. For our entrees, we got the ricotta raviolis and Nashville Hot chicken. Both tasty in their own right. I'd definitely return.

I probably should be embarrassed how many times I have been to this location since it opened in October, but I can't help it. I love Tijuana Flats. This location is small and the hot sauce bar is half of what it is at other locations, the staff isn't quite up to speed on everything, but the food is always good.
I like to go on Tuesdays for Taco Tuesday. I'm also a big fan of the burritos and nachos. You can easily split the nachos between two people, they are huge. 
I'm so happy a TFlatz opened near my house, that I really can't complain. I will happily get up to get my own drink refill just don't go anywhere my favorite chain Mexican restaurant.

I love this place. 

We went here to buy a bottle of wine and returned a few hours later with company to eat some cheese and hummus and drink more wine. 

The house is awesome.  It is a gorgeous old building and there is no better setting on the south side to enjoy a bottle of wine and some tapas.

The retail store on the ground floor features some pretty decent bottles of wine. You can also buy any of the bottles and enjoy them upstairs in the lounge or bar for an extra $7.50. Even Rickey Henderson couldn't pull off that steal. You can actually buy a good bottle of wine for $15, pay the extra $7.50, and enjoy it in the house. The same bottle of wine most restaurants would sell for $60. 

The third floor bar seems to be the perfect setting for a private event and you can reserve the entire space for free. Say what? 

As a lover of Indy, I am actually jealous that this place is in Greenwood. It puts many Indianapolis wine bars to shame!

I've thought long and hard for the past 3 years about my most recent hair decision - that is longer than I've thought about any one of my tattoos, or purchasing my car, or going to college out of state. I say all of that to make the point it was a big deal that I finally just went for it and...drumroll...permed my hair.

To preface the rest of this review, I will say I had zero color on my hair when I did this, which allowed the perm to take really well. I showed my stylist, Tisha, dozens of photos of perms that I loved and plenty of photos of what I did not want (I was terrified of looking like I stepped out of a 1980's rom-com). She knew exactly what it was I was going for. She incorporated lots of different size rods throughout the perm to give it a really natural look, which totally worked. I didn't expect it to turn out exactly like I wanted...but it did!! And I am so excited about it.

The whole appointment took about 2.5 hours and consisted of getting my hair washed...A LOT. As she styled and dried my hair, she gave me the full scoop on how to care for my perm (what shampoos/conditioners to use, how to blow-dry it,  how often to get a trim, and when she thought I should come back to touch it up.) I'm so thankful she did, because I'm already finding that curly hair is a heck of a lot different to care for/style than my natural locks. Her perms cost $140, which is a price I am more than happy to pay for her experience and expertise (she's been doing hair for over 30 years and did perms when they were in style).

I left the salon giddy about my new hairstyle. I'm so glad I finally did this and I am SO thankful I came to Tisha for it. It turned out better than I could have ever hoped for! Thank you, Tisha!

So here I am, the hot-shot, "You should eat here," kind of guy. Well...not so much. I've been driving by Siam Cafe for t-h-i-r-t-y years. That's 3-0 folks. Now I'm wearing a dunce hat. How many other hidden gems do we drive by and think - "Nah, couldn't be."
Mistake rectified. What a nice place. Super nice people that make you feel at home. I had chicken satay & spicy noodles with tofu. Medium heat. I'm always somewhere between medium and hot. I heard a diner behind me ask for hot sauce. What could that be? Sambal Oelek? Siracha? I've been served minced Birdseye chili pepper before. That can ruin your day if not handled properly.
It was just perfect. Just what you'd expect. The lovely basil noodle & veg. The tofu was super tender. Can't wait to see what their soups and their green curry noodle are like. Better than Nina's at Thai Esane? (Nina's game is strong y'all, and she fine too.) Maybe not better but different and also good. It's an adventure folks, we're lucky to be on it, don't whine.

Really fun place.  It looks so nondescript from the outside, you can barely tell it's open, but the inside is very nicely laid out and bright.  High ceilings, lovely bar.  Service was great, as were the margarita and sangria (and at $8 a glass a little pricey).

The menu is so varied, it was difficult to decide what to choose.  Appetizers sound delicious but come with a huge serving of chips and very small servings of the actual dip.  The entrees are very substantial, but also a little pricey for Mexican food.

The food was fine -- there's better Latin/Mexican/whatever elsewhere -- but it's such a festive and fun atmosphere that I'll definitely be back, even just to sit at the bar with friends having drinks and appetizers.  Great new addition to the neighborhood.

This has been one of my favorite stops in St. Louis. While in town for a work conference my manager arranged a family-style dinner at Reeds. We were seated upstairs in a dimly-lit room that conveyed cozy despite us having ample space. Our group had a case of the giggles and a touch of the ridiculous about us so it's best for all involved that we were seated away from the main dining area downstairs. 

Everything I tried was amazing (really), so I'll just go ahead and walk you through our menu:

+ Bacon-fat-fried cornbread with thyme butter and honey: we could have stopped here with a pan of this cornbread and I'd have slapped a five-star rating on it

+ Veggie toast: I can't remember what all was on it, but it was so tasty. My coworker was kind enough to split his with me because the toast for the table had mushroom and bone marrow, neither of which I was interested in ingesting. I'm not a vegetarian [as evidenced by my ode to that bacon fat cornbread above], but I'm sure if I had spoken up when we received our menu for the evening they'd have happily made me the veg alternative. 

+ The best salad of all time: kale, roasted squash, pepitas, bacon, feta, and maple juniper dressing. When I read the description I was kind of "meh" because in general I'm not a big fan of kale, maple, or things that taste like gin. This combination though - I can't. They brought us an enormous bowl and we had more than enough so I wish I'd taken more. The chew of the squash with the crispy, salty bacon and the sweetness of the dressing was perfection. Hot tip for other kale salads: chiffonade your leaves so it can be chewed in a reasonable amount of time and effort. 

+ Roasted cauliflower: simple, delicious.

+ Polenta with goat cheese, honey, and toasted walnuts: basically a dessert before dessert. The polenta was perfectly creamy and the nuts added the needed crunch. It came in a huge bowl and I could not stop laughing at how it jiggled when moved. 

+ Chocolate tart with brown butter caramel, hazelnuts, and fresh whipped cream: so rich, and so delicious. I have a major sweet tooth but I couldn't finish my slice. If I hadn't had the polenta I probably could have done it. I was full by the time dessert rolled around but I wasn't about to pass up such a lovely end to the meal. 

A beet salad and porchetta were also served but I did not partake - they both looked beautiful but I was maxed out on food and I don't think I'd be able to handle the fattiness of the porchetta. We also had our choice of wine. 

Reeds helped set the stage for a perfect dinner with my coworkers - they took what was sure to be a good evening and made it excellent.

Need a bite before heading to the airport?! Stop at this First Watch and have a delicious healthy meal before you get on that plane!! The place is very cozy, I love their ambiance! I like their menu so much that  it takes me a while to decide, so I love their "2 for YOU" where you pick 2 choices which are super generous! Sorry pictures don't show the food, I didn't want to miss my flight and I forgot. Next time!! Here's some photos of their cool dining room.

My trip to the mall is never complete without sharing a sweetgreen bowl after shopping. I absolutely love their warm wild rice bowl. I substitute the chicken with tofu. Your first bite is a forkful of arugula and crunchiness of the crispy rice with that tanginess of lime. It's heavenly and so refreshing. I ask for medium dressing and it's never overwhelming.

Olio is a great new addition to the city scene in an off the beaten path location that deserves a hotspot.  I love to see a business invest in an area that others might see as sketchy, which is how our great city continues to improve.  
Olio even took a step further, using an old gas station and garage to build their bar and restaurant, repurposing quality materials and classic architecture.  The result is a hip, fun, and intimate landmark.  The bar side, Olio, is the old storefront of the space.  A glass door and large panel windows add light and dimension into the otherwise smaller space, creating a bright but cozy space.  Pro bartenders plus a thoughtful cocktail, wine, and beer list create an outstanding selection.  Many drink options are from spots around the globe that are new to me, such as Lebanon.  I love to try new drinks and learn about global offerings, and the staff here knows how to sell and explain these items.  
The limited menu of small tastes is perfect with a glass of wine.  I love to just sample some cheese and cured meats, but have also ordered various dips, tartines, and salads.  They use bold and textured ingredients like high quality seafood, Mediterranean and North African spices, creamy legumes, spicy & crunchy house made nuts, and tangy goat cheese.  They are creating food that tastes and feels good to eat.  So far, I am only missing out on trying the brunch menu, and I am eager to try that.  
The prices are reasonable- certainly not inexpensive, but priced just right for the quality and service.  They do have limited parking in the front lot, which is great if you are lucky enough to nab one.  They also have valet, which is a nice touch for those not familiar with the area or maybe a little nervous about the burgeoning neighborhood.

this is a very nice theater.    I have seen numerous movies there, and I LOVE  the surround sound.      Tickets are not really expensive, and it is a wonderful way to spend an afternoon.  They have above average "theater food", and the little white castle  type burgers are nice.
We are repeat offenders here. My husband really loves the scallops and my go to is the short rib bolognese. The staff is friendly and the food is great.

Voted on eater.com as one of the 21 new ice cream destinations in the country! 
 
Located in the old Quizinos location at Houghton and Broadway is the Screamery.  It is a welcomed addition to that side of town which is lacking in dining options.  I  have to admit I am not a big ice cream person, BUT I had this ice cream almost two weeks ago and I have not stopped thinking about it.
