I love that they are a part of the local hand crafted food movement.  They are the first in Tucson to make their own pasteurized cream in house.   And they only use organic ingredients including milk from grass-fed cows and free-range chicken eggs.  As you walk in you are greeted with the ice cream features displayed in the freezer.  There were three girls scooping away and one working the cash register.  To the left of the entrance was some delicious cucumber and fruit infused water found in many spas that really hit the spot.  It was a super nice touch.  Behind the cash register is a large chalkboard menu describing the 16 flavors.  You can also see the 15-gallon stainless steel pasteurization machine, which allows them to control the ice cream creation prcoess down to the base.  Think of it as ice cream science.  

Flavors: Cotton candy; Game Day uses stout from Thunder Canyon, chocolate covered pretzels in a chocolate ice cream; Housemade bacon almond brittle in a Makers Mark, bacon, vanilla ice cream; Sonoran chocolate with chile flakes; ice cream infused with lemons and handmade vanilla cookies; Smores; Sweet Cream Honey Comb with local honey; Chocolate; Vanilla uses vanilla beans from Mexico; Strawberry with roasted strawberries; Peach;  Dairy free coconut fudge; Coffee Toffee with local coffee; Ooey Gooey Buttercake; Mississippi Mudpie; Salted Caramel with fleur de sel and Aunt Michelle's cracker cookie; blackberry merlot.  Salted caramel was a game changer.  Hands down the best salted caramel ever.  Dream worthy.  To be noted you can get two flavors ina  single scoop serving.

The also have sundaes, floats including a cheerwine float, hand made waffle cones, regular cones, milk shakes and hand crafted bottled drinks.  You can get buttercake, chocolate chip cookies and brownies as sides.  

Check out the farmhouse!  EIGHT scoops with a cookie, brownie, and buttercake  bottom with your choice of toppings.  

Bonus they are open to 10 on most days, and 9 on Sundays.  Keep your eyes peeled they are always adding new flavors.

Finally got around to trying Bab Cafe downtown. Having lived two years in Korea, I love Korean Food, especially bibimpap. I did not expect authentic bibimpap, but this was a disappointing and way over priced experience. The menu is extremely confusing. Even after previewing it online I was still confused when I was at the counter to order. You have to pay $3 extra for the hot pot. And for a $14 entree, all you get is a wooden spoon.  The wings took forever to prepare and were not worth the wait - excessively greasy. Service was also disappointing as the guy who ordered behind us got his food way before ours - such that he was almost finished eating by the time we got our order. I hate to give any place less than 3 stars, especially one this popular. But the truth is I will never return and I can't recommend it; hence the two stars. For a MUCH better option, Kwok's is just one block away - better food, service and value.

Butcher & Bee was my FAVORITE meal in Nashville. The food served here is a fusion between Middle Eastern and Southern food and it is one of the best combinations ever. You can tell that a lot of thought went into creating each menu item as each bite is perfection. Between my cousin and I were completely over ordered but still managed cleared the table; we had the Whipped Feta, Roasted Potatoes, Avocado Crispy Rice and Cauliflower Fried Chicken. All the dishes had varying levels of flavor and textures but didn't make you feel heavy after eating. Must order items are the Whipped Feta (served with honey! cucumbers and pita) and the Roasted Potatoes (served with slices of chilies!). 

Amazing food, beautiful atmosphere and of course the best hospitality. LOVED.

I love this park!

My son has a summer birthday and I knew I wanted a park with a splash pad to help beat the heat.  I called the city and the parks and rec employee recommended Ballast Point Park.  Great recommendation!

It's only $50ish to rent the shelter for the whole day.  They have grills at each shelter and they are in close proximity to the playground and splash pad.  There are also bathrooms at this park - a must for toddlers.

The playground is pretty large and has some fun slides.  The splash pad is pretty nice too.  This park also has a restaurant with fresh seafood and ice cream.  The views can't be beat here as it is right on the water!

Ballast Point is a beautiful park with a lot of amenities to enjoy!  Check it out.

I am from Arizona and always looking for a place to eat that reminds me of home! Not only do they have great pan dulce but the food was equally as great!!! I had a carne Asada torta and they had a salsa bar with all the fixings! The bread was smashed panini style but still the same fresh bread from the bakery I'm used too! I loved that I was able to speak Spanish as well and they were so nice! I will be back!!!

I came in during a weekend, so there was a little bit of foot traffic, which may have made my experience a little less than where it should have been.  BUT I loved this place, they had a kitten and yarn and paper and all the nice stuff. I really came in for some floss (which I got - great selection) and was hoping to grab a cross stitch kit of NOLA, but unfortunately a customer came over and started browsing right beside me and I am a stickler for the 6ft rule so I walked away. A bit bummed about that, but not the business's fault. They did have a wide selection of cross stitch kits from what I saw. Really neat place to come and browse and check out.

Any time we are in St Pete this is our first stop! From the fresh pastas to the authentic cans of tomatoes for sauce it's everything my Italian heart loves! I've come here several times over the years and always walk away with something new and delicious. A few favorites are the frozen lasagna, the soups and of course everything at the bakery especially the tiramisu!

love Texas Roadhouse. I have never had a bad meal here. This place is always crowded and always slammed with hungry people. The reason is because everyone loves the roadhouse. I mean what is not to love? They have steak, ribs, chicken, beer, peanuts, sports, and friendly waitresses. This place has it all. My family and I love going here and I usually get the Sirloin steak meal deal. I get 10 ounce steak, baked potato, and house salad. Can't go wrong with it. We will be back and I don't need to tell you to visit because I know you will! 5 out of 5 all day long!

Came here for dessert for my moms birthday and we loved it. The server was nice and attentive. There were real roses on the tables and that was hella cute. We got the bread pudding and pecan pie, both were amazing and I will have to come back for more.

If you're trying to figure out if Carnival is the cruise for you: here it is in a nutshell - it's a cheap way to relax and have fun but don't expect luxury -food or accommodations - on any level. This is the Walmart of cruises.

Food: not so great. 2 stars for the food. Overcooked fish/meat and overall very bland. Every meal was that way. Even the desserts were not appetizing after one bite and I have a huge sweet-tooth. If you love quantity over QUALITY then you will like Carnival. Food was way better on Royal yCarribean. If you are a person who loves to eat but likes better quality food than Walmart, then this cruise line is not for you.

Atmosphere: FUN! The reason Carnival deserves the third star is that whether you want to be on the party active side or the serenity quite side, you will have fun. I have been on two carnival cruises now and both times my boyfriend and I had fun. For some reason the people who choose carnival are just easy going fun people. I think the cruisers on Royal are either quiet or family-oriented or something but the atmosphere on Carnival is more lively and younger. I saw a lot fewer seniors on Carnival than RC. More couples on Carnival too - which I like. We were on the ship Paradise and it was an older ship but it supposed to be dry docked in 2015 for refurbishing. They kept it spotless so I was fine with it.

Entertainment: average overall. The comedians were funny. The DJ in the club was MISERABLE. I was hoping for more on board entertainment during the day since we had two full days at sea. Not a big deal since we spent all day at the pool.

Unassuming orchard tucked into a suburb on the Southside of Indy...a hidden jem! We love the fresh apple cider, the variety of apples and plethora of goodies like jams, picked items, veggies and honey. This is a family owned spot that has both charm and taste, plus a roaring fireplace on chilly days.

Each fall they host a weekend festival with food trucks, booths, kids activities, love bluegrass music and a pumpkin patch...we go every year as it is only getting better! We always find some new booth of a local small business that we then promptly become fans of forever thinking where have these guys been before?! I'm not sure how they get their booth sellers but they do an excellent job.

The cider is one of our addictions so do try it if you stop in...it is fresh and tangy with the right amount of sweetness. My favorite fall beverage both hot and cold! We always have a jug of it in the frig while the orchard is open.

Stop in and enjoy the charm and tasty cider and apples, you won't regret it!

If you want perfectly cooked chicken, beef and pork do yourself a favor and have your next meal at Redwood Rotisserie. I love this place so much that we often order thru Uber Eats to get their amazing Rotisserie meats. This specific evening I had the Midtown which is their chicken sandwich. Had I realized I could get tater tots I would have so I had French fries my side. 

The best item on the menu is probably the tri tip. They also have awesome appetizers such as Pepperjack Cheese sticks and Chicken Wings. 

Besides the delicious food the staff was helpful. Every person working assisted our table at one point in time which shows awesome teamwork. They didn't concern themselves with who had which table. I appreciate this in a restaurant staff. Next lunch or dinner you have please consider them first.

Why 2 stars? Because the menu change is for the worse.

   ---   ---   ---

I really love Oxford Exchange.

And I really loved OE Market.

But this new Mexican theme is just.... rough. Here's how it works:

As we're used to know with a lot of taco/burrito places, you pick the type of tortilla, the protein, and the veggies in a 3-step process.

One problem right off the bat is that only the most sophisticated produceista would know what the ingredients are, and what they taste like. I'm a pretty darn adventurous eater, so it's not so much the mystery, but more that I have absolutely no idea what any of these items are. A brief description on the menu board would go a long way. Here's the current process without menu descriptions:

-Walk up to counter

-Have absolutely no idea what you want because the menu is confusing

-Ask the girl behind the counter about 2-3 ingredients

-Feel unsatisfied as you still want to ask about several more items, but don't want to be that dumb that you don't know basically all of the items

-Feel pressured to hurry up and make a decision

-Eventually make a choice, albeit rushed and uninformed

So the ordering process isn't great, and I'm sure the employees get tired of defining what "Ancho Creme" and "Bustered Shishitos" are. But how's the food?

Maybe combining the preceding two ingredients with pork in a corn tortilla was a bad choice? But this was probably the worst tasting meal I've had in at least two months. Unfortunately, the flour tortilla was no better.

I just don't get the angle unfortunately. It's near UT, so they want to appeal to college kids... but the menu says hoity-toity. Still, the tacos are affordable at $3-$4, so I guess that makes sense. What doesn't make sense are the $10-$12 juices that are still being sold here. I tried one because, well, I figured a $12 juice had to be pretty amazing. Instead, it was unfortunately the opposite. Kind of watery, and hard to finish. I would have felt that I overpaid at $2.

I hate giving negative reviews, but I just can't really avoid it in this situation.

This is the place to come for funny socks and terrific jewels to adorn yourself. They have quite a few designs around the state of Indiana and Hoosier loves.   The cards and stationary are staples at this shop, but there are so many other treasures like, adventure bags, candles, and other home decor items.

Oh my gosh this place ... I just love it! Every single time friends come into town, we always make a stop at Goody's for their amazing ice cream. But really, to be fair, their sundae is what I go for. OH! MY! YUM!

The old house & lovely patio areas are definitely part of the charm. Great place to visit on a warm, summer evening.

I was highly impressed (and pleasantly surprised) by Urban Village. I had reservations at a popular joint across the street but when I walked up to the outdoor, daydrink scene... I had to ask how long the wait was because the vibes were just too good!

Then.. the food. My boyfriend loves a good bar, brewery or sports bar (aka lots of fried food, burgers, etc. - quite the opposite of my taste) but we had the most AMAZING beet and ricotta salad and the buffalo cauliflower was out of this world (and gluten free)! 

A new favorite for sure. Highly recommend.

P'sghetti's located in Ballwin, Missouri was a Jimmy's John restaurant.

The marinara sauce for the spaghetti is really yummy to me. My husband love the chicken Parmesan, meatballs, and salads.

The staff are friendly with fast and efficient service experience.

The private parking lots had plenty of parking. I will return.

Gloria ~

This place was so amazing. I loved everything about it from the atmosphere to the food to the drinks. We went at 2pm on a Thursday and it was packed but we didnt have to wait at all, just got sat at a tiny table which irritates me but it ended up being okay because i got to check out the dish the lady was eating next to us. We started off with 2 of the manson cocktails and both were yummy. I got the steak and shroom pie and the boyfriend got the hot chicken pie and both were so incredibly tasty. The hot chicken was certainly hot and my shroom pie was loaded with shrooms and they were both good sizes where we had leftovers for drunk munchies. Great place and great food!

This place was fantastic.

We went because my husband was craving a burger, and I wanted to try a local, non-chain restaurant.  What a wonderful surprise!

The best part of the place was the amazing service we received.  Our waiter was constantly checking on us (in a non-obnoxious way) and refilling drinks.  More impressively, the owner came to our table multiple times, remembered our names, and even comped us dessert.

I had the fried pork chop sandwich, and it was wonderful.  I went with the super spicy sauce, which had the right amount of kick for me.  Apparently most people find it too spicy, so even after the waiter insisted that I order the sauce on the side, the owner came out to make sure that I didn't want to switch to the normal spicy sauce.  Whatever.  Oh, the fries were perfectly crisp, and I loved the spices.

My husband had his cheeseburger, and he enjoyed it.  He had a cup of chili instead of fries, and he said that he'd happily order it again.

As I mentioned above, dessert was on the house.  The owner insisted that we try the orangesicle cheesecake, which tasted very orange-y and rich.  It was great (if you love oranges -- and I do), but next time, I want to try the neapolitan cheesecake.

The homemade chips and ranch dip were phenomenally simple yet tasty.  I'd go back to EATS again just for the chips and a beer.  But, of course, then I'd want the cheesecake.  And a fried pork sandwich.  

Oh, be forewarned: on Tuesdays, kids eat free, so Tuesdays are crowded with kids.  That might or might not be a positive in your book.

1 star?  Yes....1 star.  This "iconic" & historic property in Safety Harbor has lovely grounds and hosts many weddings and the likes, but aside from the gardens the place is a dump.  Our checkin process was a complete disaster where there was a discrepancy with the rate of our room due to a package we booked.  The difference was a mere $40, but rather than solve the problem the Front Desk Supervisor Rennie opted to argue with me about what he saw on his screen and he didn't care what I thought I did while booking the room; his main concern was proving that he was right and I as the customer was wrong.  That is clearly why he instructed me to "come back here and look at my computer if you don't believe me".  WOW!  Now there's a way to kick off a weekend as the best man of a wedding there!!

Ok, so there's apparently been several additions to the hotel, so getting from the lobby to some of the areas that rooms were at was like a maze.  When we finally got our keys, we were instructed to go outside, walk into the doors that say human resources, then walk past all the offices, then go to the end of the hall make a left, then go down stairs to get to our room that was apparently down in the sunken gardens.  The room was "ok", but goodness gracious was it HOT.  The AC ran from 3pm to 12am and only cooled off FOUR degree....yes all the way down from 82 to 78 (and no they don't have ceiling fans either).

Alright, now let's get off the complain train for a second to address with the GM the "I'll show you how wrong you are attitude" I got at check in.  I asked four times to speak with the manager...any manager for that matter, but days went by with no response.  Once I finally got a call from the GM Ajith Dissanayake, I was greeted with a very disgruntle attitude.  I attempted to explain how things went down at check in and I kept get the "yea yeah yea" "mmm hmm"  "ok" treatment.  I had to stop and say that it doesn't sound like you're particularly interested in my conversation since he had rebuttals already prepared to justify anything and everything that could possibly come up.  Never once did he say I'm sorry you had a poor experience, but rather when I asked him if he was interested he started to YELL at me!!  "Are you a mind reader?  Do you have the capability of knowing all the thoughts that exist in my head??"  All I could say was no, but I can tell you that you're acting really unprofessional. The conversation went on and he just repeated talking about the booking process and that it was my fault there was a price discrepancy.  Hello.....this was never about the money, it was about the fact that both the supervisor and GM treated me like dirt.

From what I've seen and heard, including those in our party, was that experiences are hot and cold.  People either manage to have a nice time or they end up needing something which involves bringing the staff into the picture and the whole trip goes up in smoke.  It's really a shame that I had to endure this crappy treatment when my best friend was spending a fortune and also getting married there.  It really left me with a horrible taste in my mouth.

I did contact the Choice Hotel Corporation, but they can't offer any help aside from filing a complaint with the very person I have a complaint about, so the agent I spoke to said she didn't know what would come out of it since it's about the GM and gets sent to the GM.  The hotel is a franchise of Choice and they have no regulation over the facility at all.

All I can say is......stay at your own risk.  There's no shortage of fantastic resorts in the area.  Try the Don Cesar...it's fabulous.

It's been quite some time since I've had Moe's, but I knew it'd be just as good!  Some favorites available, but also very customizable to each person.  Our party of 5 was moved through the ordering and whipping up process at a very acceptable pace.  There were plenty of employees around.  The place was pretty clean as well, plenty of seating.  They do have one of those Coke machine with all of the multitude of flavor options of several sodas.  
I love the Queso here!  I like the chips too!  They aren't stingy on their Guac or other toppings.
I really enjoyed the meal.  Decent portions, plenty of chips.  Anyone who has the chance to stop by a Moe's I would definitely recommend it!  It's quick and from what I remember previously, it's pretty efficient to take it to go!

So first with the negative...no where to park...For the size of the grocery store they really need their own parking lot, or more designated parking for their store.  However, everything once we got inside was awesome. I was able to find a lot of Korean or Japanese goods that I find in T&T or Lucky 97 hidden and hard to find. We bought a lot of Korean staples (think fish sauce, Korean noodles, pepper sauce, etc,..etc.) But I was also intrigued with the amount of frozen food they had available. Well worth a second visit. I would love it if they had daily a sample of a product that may be unfamiliar to non Koreans that we could try before we commited to a box. I found our clerk super friendly and because of the amount we bought se threw in some Korean snacks for our family to try (our kids loved the snack cakes by the way). The only other suggestion I would have is not all the labels are translated into English with the price tag and that would be super helpful for white people like me who can't read Korean. Definitely will be back

I've seen this place at several events now so I decided to stop in while I was doing some shopping on Mass Ave the other day. I gotta say, I love their support for local authors. I also love that they sell Just Pop In carmel and cheddar popcorn too

This was probably my most memorable evening in New Orleans.. with cafe au lait, beignet's and the live music.. perfect ambiance for French quarters 
it is located right outside our hotel(royal sonesta), my husband loved their jambalayas as well..

I love cheese and I love it even more when it's fried. Cow and the Curd hits the spot every. single. time. I once took this truck for granted, because it was following me around last summer. Everywhere I went, there it was. When we first started our foodlationship I would split my order with others. As time has progressed I now need an order all to myself.  They are similar to mozzarella sticks, but the cheddar is juicier and delicious-er.  I like my $9 cheese curds plain. If you like to get a little crazy they have dipping sauces for an extra $2. It's not just fried cheese it's fried happiness.

I was super excited to finally try this place. Maybe too excited. It fell flat with me.

Walking in it's an old warehouse and it looks awesome. It has a great open vibe.

There was a wait but not too bad for a Saturday night. Especially since we had a party of 6.

We were brought drinks quickly. Our waiter was friendly and kept up with the pace of the evening.

Now for the food. Out of a party of 6, 3 people either didn't like what they had or just thought it was meh.

I had This Grill is On Fire @ $9 - southwest veggie patty, ozark mushrooms, chipotle mayo, jalapeño jam, sweet chili dressed spring mix. 

There was more bread than anything. The patty was bland and mostly tasted like mushed black beans. There were barely any mushrooms or spring mix. I had it minus the mayo. The jam was good and the best part of the whole disaster. 

The Hubs and I ordered a large fry @ $5 to share and they were the best part of the meal for me. They were crispy, not too skinny, not too greasy, and had a great taste. He had Sriracha Catsup and I had honey mustard. We both enjoyed our dips. Mine was sweet and tangy.

The Hubs ordered The Buffalo @ $10 - Ground chicken patty, house made buffalo sauce, cheddar, bacon, ranch.

He got it minus the bacon. He said that his was really good. I didn't try it. I personally think he is just in love with buffalo sauce and that if you put it on something he will like it.

My Mom and another member of our party had the Winter Slaw Salad @ $5 - cabbage, sweet potato, butternut squash, fried Brussels sprouts, toasted nuts, thai chili dressing.

My Mom liked it. The other lady didn't. I did try this and thought it was superior to my veggie burger. The veggies were fresh and crisp. The dressing was spicy and pretty tasty. 

Another member of the party ordered buffalo wings @ $9.

He said they were meh and wouldn't order them again. They tasted ok but they were tiny and weren't very many of them

My sister in law had the Fried Chicken Salad @ $10 - romaine, fried chicken, cornbread croutons, tomato, green onion, corn, cheddar, avocado ranch. 

She said it was ok but mostly just ate the chicken out of it.

My brother in law had the PB&J @ $11 - bison patty, arugula pesto, house tomato jam, goat cheese, arugula.

He said it was ok but too small and he didn't like the jam.

All in all it was ok but I was let down overall. Most of us felt it was a little pricey for the quality and quantity of what we got.

Mos def check it out for yourself but we will not be running back.

Always a positive experience here, the owner always greets us and remembers us each and every time. Which is so nice, to be appropriated by a company. Every time we come in we try a different arrangement of flavors or cakes. We love them all

YUM!! 

We were starving and wandering pretty aimlessly when we happened upon Marathon. Around 8 on a Friday we were sat right away but the place was pretty full, it seems like we got lucky.

SO HUNGRY!!

I got the "Best In Philly" matzoh soup and the kale and quinoa salad. The soup was HEAVEN. I wish I could eat this every day. 

Cocktails were strong and tasty, decently priced. Then there were the boozy shakes. Ooooh boozy shakes, always a great idea. 

Staff was decent, but nothing that stood out. 

I love when I find a place like this out of the blue and thanks for the great meal Marathon

Being that my fiance is from New Orleans she loves seafood, so whenever she gets a chance to go eat at what we now nicknamed "The Lobb" ,..she be too excited! Now we have gone to this particular Lobb twice now and I STILL HATE IT!! I know its a seafood spot but is it supposed to smell like feet, a**, and fish all at the same time!??!! I can't tell the difference between the raunchy smell of the bathroom when I'm in there and the musty smell of the restaurant when I come out. OK, now on to the  wait staff,..friendly but slow as hell even on a weekday night we waited as if it were packed! Food on the other hand is pretty good, my family and I love the biscuits they serve and I love the Long Island tea cause it helps me endure the smell of this establishment. Prices are reasonable but I realized that this Lobb doesn't have a selection of dressing for your salad's only two choices in which my fiance and I didn't eat either:(...I don't want to go back but probably will cause my baby loves seafood and its not to far from home....taking one for the team again!

I think this is my new favorite hotel. At least for this area. It's not a Homewood Suites nor an Embassy Suites, but has many of the same amenities without the evening reception. Great location. Friendly staff. Gated lot for parking. Shuttle or close walk to downtown stores or restaurants. 
The room was a nice size, very modern and new. I love the stall shower as opposed to those bathtubs with the wide arch shower rod. The fitness center was great having ellipticals,treadmills, cycle and free weights. Very nice breakfast in the morning with a sweetheart attendant who explains all of the foods, where to go, and how to cook them. Just take the breakfast sandwich and put it in the microwave on 1, not 2 unless it's the other microwave. The folks there are very nice and helpful.

I love this place! They are friendly and willing to be patient while you read and ask for samples on all of their ridiculous menu of ice cream. I always find something new. They have different seasonals and new things they are trying out. The lavender honey ice cream is crazy good. Since there is so many new flavors or flavors that you will never see again, I recommend getting a sample boat. 5 or 7 kids sized scoops for a reasonable price. The sundaes, shakes and floats are great too.

I'm here to unequivocally say that they do not have the best burger in town.  I've had two here now and I just haven't been awed the way I was when I bit into a burger at 12 south tap room.  THAT is a burger.  M.L. Rose burgers are small. 
 
Today I ordered the chili burger that sounds like a big burger covered in tons of chili and jalepenos.  Never tasted the jalepeños.  Could have picked it up.  It was served on paper that disintegrated into the burger, so don't fork and knife it as it says.  It was $9, didn't fill me up, didn't come with a salad or fries.  

I LOVE the fact that they have good beer, including Green Flash's West Coast IPA, but I'm not all that keen on paying $8 for a bottle of beer.  A pint of a monstrous imperial IPA?  No problem, but not a bottle.

They do usually have attractive waitresses and bar staff, actually, last time I went our waitress was a total knockout, so that never hurts, but I'd still rather have a plate of food that is irresistible.  That is what I'm there for.

Woot! Woot! Is how I felt while I was eating breakfast at Three Sisters Cafe. I mean I loooove unique menus and this establishment has creativity on the brain! There is so much to offer at Three Sisters - I personally am in love with the biscuits and gravy. First of all the biscuits are beer biscuits... Who knew there was such a thing? They were so good, I think I can't have them anywhere else or it may just ruin my experience. My husband said "dang, those are some big biscuits" and they were! The sauce on top was to die for. Not too salty which is usually the issue with biscuits and gravy!

My friend ordered the lemon corn cakes! When I tasted them, I immediately regretted not getting them. So for next time my order will be the best of both worlds = my meal plus hers. They have a lot of their meals in a 1/2 size serving... So when I go again, I will order a 1/2 order of the lemon corn cakes (for the sweet) and a 1/2 order of the biscuits and gravy (for the savory). 

The thing I also really enjoyed is the cute environment and fun character! The restaurant is literally in a house - Adorbs!

There are few restaurants that I leave and am craving a few hours later... This absolutely was the case for three sisters!!! Round two please!!!!

I've loved the Bridgestone Arena since I was a child, when it was called the Municipal Auditorium and my first concert was the Osmond's in 1973.  Yeah, so what...I'm 137 years old.  I look really good for my age.

I recently went to see the farewell tour of Elton John.  Now I'm just gonna remind you again, I am 137 years old.
Elton John was playing as long as I can remember and he's only 49.99999 years old now.  If you've never experienced him in concert, sorry 'bout yer luck. 

The Bridgestone has the most spectacular sound system.  It is extremely loud, but it was also extremely clear.  The instruments as well as the lyrics were crisp and clear, as was Elton's voice when he spoke.  His concert being his farewell tour also tells of his journey, and it was very inspiring.  I really can't express how much I enjoyed this particular concert , or how much I have enjoyed every experience I've ever had at the Bridgestone Arena.

I'm constantly on a diet.  It is so-called the "See-Food" diet. Healthy food and I are not good friends whatsoever! 

At work, when we order pizzas, we always order a ton. Top Tomato serves fresh and tasty ingredients on the traditional and more creative pizzas.

The usual: One Buffalo chicken, one Philadelphia steak, one vegetarian delight, and one meat Lover's (not my favorite but loved by everyone else). Each one of us can probably eat 6 slices in one sitting. That's how much everyone enjoyed the pizzas. Very much!!
Another thing you don't want to miss by not ordering is the cheesesteak. Personally, I think they make the BEST cheesesteak, and I blame them for every time I crave a delicious cheesesteak. Luckily, I live close by, even though my waistline keep screaming. 



Pro Tip: 
**This is an excellent to-go/ delivery pizza, I never dined there. The customer service is a hit or miss. Improvement needed. 
** In my opinion, don't get a slice of pizza. I prefer the fresh, made-to-order pizza. Don't forget this is my under-the-radar cheesesteak spot, so give it a try!

Three and half Yelps

The food item that I probably crave most often is a good burger. I really really really love burgers, so I was extremely excited when I realized Bailey's range would have another soft opening from Wed-Sun of this week. I was in a predicament though, the Cards game was on (which I refuse to miss) and when I called Bailey's the guy who answered was very apologetic in explaining to me that they don't have their tv's yet since they didn't realize the season would still be going on when they opened. He did however say that I could place a carryout order and they would have the food ready for me in 15 minutes. Sweet. I placed my order and by the time I got downtown and found a parking spot my food was ready. When I walked in, I was immediately impressed with the use of space. The decor was cute, unique and intimate. I was greeted by 3 employees within a matter of seconds who directed me to the bar where my order was waiting. The bartender rang us out quickly and was friendly as well. Everything smelled so delicious that the 5 minute drive back home seemed like a lot longer. Once we got home we dug in and were NOT disappointed.

I got the Thai chicken burger which according to the menu is: ground chicken patty, shredded cabbage, daikon slaw, cilantro aoli, peanut sauce, lettuce and tomato. The chicken burger was super moist and the sauces complimented it perfectly. J got the blackened blue and by how quickly it disappeared I'm guessing he enjoyed it. We also got an order of fries (super delicious, seasoning was spot on) and I tried 2 of the sauces: honey mustard and rooster. Both were yummy but the rooster sauce is pretty thick and I probably would like it better on a burger. J tried the caesar salad which came topped with fried white anchovies. Of course I snuck a bite of his salad and I was pretty impressed by the flavors. I only finished about half my food before I was pretty full so I know I have something to look forward to for dinner tonight.

On a side not, one random thing I loved was instead of styrofoam all of my carryout items were packaged in 100% compostable containers (even the sauces!) and my order was packaged in a paper bag. 

I can't wait to go back and dine in so I can try that bourbon, candied bacon and salted caramel ice cream shake that's calling my name.

Without a doubt, my FAVORITE place! Not one bite has passed my teeth that I didn't love. At first glance at the menu, it looks a little pricey, but we eat on Mass Ave all the time, so we weren't surprised. What we were surprised about was the amount of food you get with each plate. I was shocked during our first visit that we had enough to take home! I wasn't mad at all about those leftovers! In typical CRG fashion, everything about the restaurant is amazing. You won't be disappointed with anything you choose. For my fellow sweet tooths (Is that a word? If not, now it is!) don't leave without those churros. In a word - Unbelievable. Get over there now, but make sure to leave room for me!

There's not a lot to say about Hudson's on Whyte, because it's just Hudson's. It looks the way Hudson's looks and serves the things Hudson's serves and after two beers is indistinguishable from The Pint and On The Rocks and all the other pubs in Edmonton. This is just how Edmonton does pubs. Nevertheless, we go to Hudson's because it IS how Edmonton does pubs and since we are from Edmonton, we like that sort of thing. I have no complaints about this bar, but nothing to rave about it either. Hudson's is homey and tiresome, like your hometown is. You go there and complain that you should be somewhere else, but secretly you love the comfort of familiarity. Both of my younger sisters are servers at another location, and it treats them well, so I appreciate that. Thank you Hudson's, for being you, like a McDonald's for grown-ups.

This is a gem of a golf course.  You can teel there has been considerable investment in bringing it to this level and there appears to be more to come.  

The overall conditions are as good as any other public course in the area with the exception of Seminole Lake and their unfair advantage of Paspalum fairways/greens, which are the envy of every other course in the area.  

Overall:
-6/10, practice area - pretty small but the mats are new
-7/10, layout - one of the tightest around, but very playable since everything is well-manicured, nearly always making the penalty a punch out, versus lost ball.  Lots of water and the back 9 is brutally hard when there is wind.  Ends with a par 3, which is universally despised, but unavoidable in some circumstances.  
-8/10, tee boxes - in great shape
-9/10, fairways - just about as good as any you will find
-7/10, greens - when I was there yesterday they had just been verti-cut and were pretty shaggy/grainy/slow.  I'd love to try them in 2 weeks on the weekend.
-9/10, staff.  Everyone was insanely nice and helpful.  The female pro inside was a pleasure to talk with.

I will try this course again and suggest others do not sleep on it.

Ahh...I absolutely love coffeeshops!  It brings me back to my graduate and undergraduate days as well as high school!

Anywho,living in Mid-City I try to support local (although Starbucks your soy chai lattes are pretty friggin awesome but CC's has changed their chai and it's driving me nuts!).  This is my idea of an eclectic coffeeshop.  I remember when Rue de la Course is where the Rum House currently resides.  People were allowed to smoke and there were banker's lamps on each table.

Well, Fair Grinds, you had me at banker's lamps.  Plus, they have an outdoor seating area which I have yet to try.  I'm a night owl so you won't see me out and about before 11am on a weekend unless I'm going to church or forced to leave puttering in my apartment.  Plus, bonus that they are open later than PJ's so I'm all about it!  I even ran into my favorite waitress from Nonna Mia there (ok so I eat at Nonna Mia alot to have a relationship with the waitress, manager, and other waiters! hehe).  She also gave me the FYI that Zotz on Oak is open even later if I can't get everything done in time.  Good to know!

I also enjoy that Fair Grinds is located in the mix, it's on the same street as Cafe Degas, Canseco's, Maple Street bookstore, Swirl, and a salon that I haven't frequented yet.  There is street parking.

Also, the staff are friendly, there is only one unisex bathroom, adorable outdoor seating, free wifi, and a delicious soy chai latte!

Am happy to have found a neighborhood! 

Happy coffee coffee drinking!

Love this spot. You can stop in to grab a cold pint or a six pack to go.  They specialize in hard to find beers that are both local and international. The staff are so nice and will help recommend any beer based on your tastes and preferences. The space is bright and open - with a bit of open shelf space when we went, so looks like room to grow and expand. 

I've been exploring neighborhoods lately and there's so much to see and discover on Cherokee, including here. It's been open 5 or so years and hope it stays there many more. 

Pro tip: you can get a free beer here with the St Louis pub pass. It is a half- pour though because the beers are so unique and so strong. It comes in the cutest tulip little glass.

Have been wanting to try this one for a while. It is near our home and tucked away in a strip mall.  Nice patio on the side, dining area and small bar- and it was busy on a Thursday night.

They have specials all week and we happen to go on buy one, get one free chicken parm night- Thursday.  Wow! We love chicken parm and find that it does represent the quality of the Italian restaurant.  It included bread sticks and salad as well.

Nice place, food was good to very good.  Bread sticks needed to be cooked longer and were a bit plain tasting.  Salad was good and italian dressing was nice- not too salty.  Salad had grape tomato, pepper and cuke.  Chicken parm was HUGE! and the side of capellini with marinara were good.  This is not a place where it is quantity over quality.  I would definitely get the chicken parm again.

Nice place.  We will be back.

I am not cool.  This was my first time to the much lauded Burger Up as I am a grump about waiting in line for food.  And my kids are even grumpier (but not by much).  I love what the owner has done for 12 South, but this was not a great day for Burger Up.  My son and I both got Woodstock burgers and they were really good.  I got mine with Vidalia onion rings - super amazing BTW and my son did straight fries.  I the place is cute, parking is a monster and service is fun and funny.  I love that they are kid friendly but clearly not going to deal with brats.  The bread is super amazing and our whole meal costs about $35.  So, you ask.....why the two stars?  Well....that would be the weight loss program they put us on around 7h later that evening.  We lost all the weight of eating there and then some.  I could feel the stomach rumble coming about an hour in advance and my stomach was still hurting after a long night for both junior and myself.  The only shared food was burgers, so I'm going with that being the culprit but oh, what a culprit it was. I think I'll be eating crackers for awhile still.

This used to be one of my favorite restaurants! Everything is always served fresh and usually in a timely fashion. Consistency hasn't been excellent. I used to love the consistency with Anthony's and I find that things aren't always the same on different occasions. Sometimes the items are cooked differently than the last time and it's not the way it should be. The food is still good regardless and so is the service.

Maybe just a bit of editing is needed

Burger Study is 100% ok.  I went in hoping to be wowed, but sadly, I wasn't.  My first question came about when my friends and I asked to be seated, and were directed to the bar for our party of 5 instead of a booth.  That would have been fine, except for the two, empty six-person booths which went unoccupied during our visit.  The food was decent, but I think a few tweaks to the menu could really make things pop.  Plan for standard bar fare, with a few original items like fried avocado and beer-cheese tots.  The burgers are pretty to look at, but flavor-wise, no one in our party remarked on any stand-outs.

For decor, I went in expecting to feel like I had been dropped into an old library.  Sadly, the only library-esque decor I noticed was one wall with a few books which were artfully displayed.  I'd love to see a few more tomes showcased, and maybe even a menu dressed up to look like a leather-bound tome.  This seems like a concept that would be so much to play with, from a design standpoint.  Bookcases in the bathroom, posters of book covers on the walls, and many, many more books throughout the space seems like a no-brainer, and a sure crowd-pleaser.

Burger Study is still fairly new, so hopefully, the management team will be able to work out the kinks (orders which were placed, but never received) and really capitalize on their great location and fun concept.

I have a lot of mixed feelings when it comes to sifting through my numerous Wasabi adventures. I used to come here all the time for their lunch and happy hour specials and the sushi has always been consistently good. There is a woman who works the sushi bar (I think she is the manager?) and she makes some BOMB sushi! She is possibly one of the best sushi chefs I've ever met. I actually used to get really excited when I came and saw she was working because I knew it would be a great experience. Joe, the bartender/owner is a super nice guy and he's great for a fun chat if you are feeling social and want to sit at the bar and make small talk. All in all...you would think I would have no issue with this place since I am clearly a repeating customer...HOWEVER...this place has a LOT of inconsistencies with their service. So many inconsistencies, in fact, that it makes it really hard for me to really endorse this restaurant in good faith. 

Ordinarily I would say the food quality at this place is 4 stars, but the service is consistently a definite 1-2 depending on the night. I haven't been to their other locations so I can't speak for them, but I might have just had one too many bad experiences here to come back in recent days. 

We came in on a Saturday evening with a group of 4. My group rallied and ranked many nearby restaurant possibilities before leaving a nearby bar and I was actually the one who encourage them to come and try Wasabi. I hadn't been back there in awhile, but I was nearly certain they would enjoy themselves and at least love the food even if the service happened to be slow (as usual). 

We sat down and it took them 10 minutes before acknowledging us (ok fair enough, seems like business as usual), and then another 10 minute for waters to arrive and then the server promptly left before we could give him our order, then another 10 minutes went by and he finally came to take our order, then 20 minutes went by just to produce 2 sushi rolls. We wanted to order more but our server NEVER came back to our table. He didn't refill our waters or ask us how we were doing or anything, he just dropped off the food and never came back. We finally just walked over to the sushi bar and told the sushi chef that we wanted more rolls, which his response was "ok I get your server soon" (the woman sushi chef that I previously mentioned was not working on this night). I kid you not, we were there for about an hour and half and all we could get out of this place were 2 rolls...and we were absolutely starving! Wasabi's service has always been pretty slow and unimpressive...but this was just ridiculous. 

We waited and waited to close out our tab but he never acknowledged us again. Finally, we physically chased him down in an effort to pay our tab so we could just leave. Having worked in service industry jobs in my younger days, I would never condone a "dine and dash" method, but we were literally running after them with our money and trying to force them to take it so we could leave in good conscience. Quite honestly, I think anyone else with less bother than I would have just gotten up and left.

In our server's defense, the dining room was packed and there was only ONE SERVER in the whole restaurant (which is actually typical for this location but I guess I hadn't been during a packed dinner before to see how bad it could really get). Our server looked like he was sweating profusely and about to have a nervous breakdown so I didn't take it personally. But I DID feel totally embarrassed that I had convinced my whole group to go there and then they all had this absolutely atrocious experience.

I don't want to totally discourage anyone from giving this place a try because for lunch or happy hour the service certainly seems much more tolerable, but avoid Wasabi at all cost if you have a group during peak dinner hours.

Ok this is so hard for me because I am not one to whip out my phone after a meal and write a negative review....but hear it goes!!

I live right down the road from Rickshaws and was hesitant to try it because it never looks busy and I didn't want to cheat on my favorite Hinoki Sushi place, since I have always had a wonderful meal there. I was in a hurry and hungry and it is Thursday Sushi so I figured I might as well give Ricks a shot and boy was I disappointed!!!

1st, place was empty....granted it was 2 in the afternoon. 

2nd, place was a mess, sticky menus and dirty bussed bins in plan view.

3rd, language barrier, I was trying to ask questions and no one understood me.

Ok, I could go on but let me get to my dinner.  I love my normal Mickey Nigiris and Upside down Shrimp it's basically the only thing I eat and it looked fabulous in its little to go container, and I get home all hungry and excited, get my sauce ready and my chop sticks in action to take the first bite and uggggg the tuna was so fatty I couldn't even bite through it....ok no biggie, maybe it's just that one, nope all 6 where layered with fat strands....and it had a hint on fishy smell. I was so disappointed!!! You can't tell me that the girl preparing them did not take notice??? 

I will not return AT ALL....and I will never, ever cheat on my favorite spot just down the street.

In all fairness, for those who might want to give it a shot, their prices where good and here is a picture of before and after and the menu....maybe you will have a better experience then

Tucson, AZ:  Sonoran Desert immersion, YESS!

First time visiting. Despite the forecast in 90sF, and a late start, we loved our drive along the eight mile, paved Cactus Forest Drive. Limited pullouts and parking along this road. Too hot for hiking but the scenery is outstanding for the rich variety of local cacti and wildflowers, set against the Rincon Mountains. The unique Saguaro Cactus is only found in the Sonoran Desert.

The Visitors Center is located outside the park gate with free parking. Wonderful short video, and informative displays provide an overview of the park. Rangers available to answer any questions. A must stop for visitors visiting Tucson.

This was just a lucky find for us when we were in St. Louis for the weekend, had a taste for Italian, and were near Clayton when we Yelped.  Yes, it's an older crowd, but that tells me the food is good and the price is appropriate, and both were true.  We called and asked if they could accommodate our party of three at the last minute, and were told yes.  We arrived about five minutes later and waited maybe 10 minutes or less for a table -- Excellent!)  We had a lovely, very traditional Italian meal with all the ambiance,  Dessert was especially wonderful -- the Tiramisu, with a touch of cinnamon, was superb.

This is one of my favorite cafes to get a super filling and delicious salad and I'm a huge sucker for clean, spacious and classy aesthetics. My mood instantly lifts when I come here - everything is just so pleasing to the eye and taste buds. 

There are 3 separate sections in this cafe: beverages, sandwiches and salads. I've only ordered at the salad bar so I can't speak for the others yet. It's SO good and I've noticed that the majority of other patrons order the salad too. I get the BYO salad for $13 and they give you a huge portion so it's def worth it. I love how they chop up the salad in front of you which makes it taste so fresh and also easier to eat. 

I've seen people read and work here so it can be a nice study spot. There is AMPLE seating!

I loved this place in so many ways.

Loved:

- the high ceilings
-the well-lit space
- the spaciousness
- the bottle shop/bar concept, which New Mexico so desperately needs (Tap and Bottle owners, if you're listening, open one of these in Albuquerque. I'd quit my job to work for a place this great.)
-the impeccable selection

I'll deviate from my bullets to really comment on the selection. It was superb. There's a cask option, which is always a nice touch and it was cool that it was a beer, Jalapeno Cherry Bomb IPA from Dragoon, that not even the brewery had on tap when I was there the day before. The rest of the tap selection was a good mix of styles and local (Huss, Four Peaks, etc.) and national craft options. They even had a gose! Yep, goses aren't easy to find, but Tap and Bottle had a great representation of this German style courtesy of Destihl. I recommend it if it's on tap. 

Then there's the obscene bottle selection. Woosa! So many bottles to choose from. The selection here was better than Plaza Liquors! The beers were arranged by style and had many of the heavy-hitters of craft, Firestone Walker, Dogfish Head, Mikkeller, Tool, Sierra Nevada, Oskar Blues, and I could go on and on. The bartender was even so kind as to hip me to a great price on a Uinta beer, which I was able to get for $10 cheaper than it normally should cost. Gracias.

The pourers were also some friendly folks that seemed to know their beers and appreciate them. Also, the prices of pours were very reasonable, ranging from around $4-9. 

If I lived in Tucson, I'd be in here everyday probably. I'll have to wait a few decades until I can make my millions and/or find investors to help make my dream of something similar happen in Albuquerque.

I live an hour outside of Nola. I love coming to the city and trying different restaurants. Today was a special occasion: my best friend is moving away and expecting a baby. We wanted to hang out in the city before she left. We've both never been here and was excited to try. Let's start with the takeaway: This place needs to get it together. I've never GIVEN A BAD REVIEW SO BELIEVE ME AS YOU READ. We walked in and it was immediately a 90 minute wait, that's fine we get it. They gave us the option to sit at the bar, which we did, but was difficult for my friend being shes very pregnant. We waited 20 minutes for a water and to have our order taken. Fast forward to an hour later. WE ARE STILL SITTING HERE WAITING on our food. While people beside us on both ends of the bar have received and eaten their food. Bottom line, our waitress forgot to put in our ticket. We are still waiting with our order not in sight. I'm livid. This is the worst experience I've ever had at a restaurant that is well known in the city. Did I mention it's Monday? I'm speechless.
UPDATE: 20 minutes after I posted this review and still no food. I wanted to let the manager know and she refused to talk to me.

If you want classic, South Philly Italian food, you need to go to Ralph's! 

I knew I'd love this place as soon as I walked in - it's one of those restaurants where you can dress casual or formal and fit in regardless. There's a nice ambience and it's cozy (coziness enhanced by a delicious glass of Merlot). 

I ordered the eggplant parm with spaghetti and a side of meatballs. The eggplant was amazing - meaty with a nice, crispy breading. The meatballs were also some of the best I've had (after my Mom-Mom's, of course). The simplicity of the meal really allowed each flavor to shine. 

Obviously, I sampled my family members' dishes as well. Both of my parents ordered homemade pasta dishes - the cavatelli in gorgonzola cream sauce and the pappardelli with prosciutto and peas in an Alfredo sauce. Both pastas were amazing, but what really impressed me were the sauces - they were creamy but light at the same time! I loved that about them. 

For dessert, I ordered the tiramisu - it came out like a slice of cake with the espresso-dipped lady fingers as the crust. It kind of reminded me of an Italian cheesecake, which didn't bother me but might disappoint some people (so FYI). I also sipped on some Frangelico, which was devine.

If you haven't been to America's oldest Italian restaurant yet, what are you waiting for?! All I can say is, I can't wait to go back.

Ah, yes.... strange. You have my heart. And my stomach. 

I love the constant rotation of amazing and unique donuts, ranging from safe to "wait, what?" pop-up donuts. The sections rotate monthly with some mainstay dones. In particular, the gooey butter and chocolate protein donut are my favorites. The gooey butter cake is also a hit with folks from out of town and is definitely St. Louis in donut form. 

In addition to the donuts. the staff is always friendly when I come in. Though this location is tiny with no seating, the whole place has a cool vibe.

As soon as I laid my eyes on my baked potato pizza visceral memories of my Sparty days at Michigan State University were evoked.  Baked potato pizza from Georgio's is near and dear to my heart.  So, bless you, No Anchovies for offering up, what is truly heaven to me.  Food is intimate- you touch it, taste it, smell it and the feeling it provides, bonds us to places and to one another.  I cannot recall the numerous times my friends and I bonded (usually around 3am, from late night cram sessions, not because of yard long skip and go nakeds, clearly) over a baked potato pizza.  

Usually, when I tell people I love baked potato pizza they look at me quizzically.  I explain that it is a thin crust pizza with no sauce, sliced baked potato, green onion, loads of bacon, colby jack and provolone cheese.  I personally top mine with sour cream...No Anchovies tried this out but found ranch sold better.  They use redskin potato, I think I prefer a russet....but I am not complaining.

Since I had such HIGH expectations, I feared a major let down....however, this pizza delivered!  Trust me go big or go home, get the 20 inch!  If you do not, you will be back in a few days to get more.  This is one pizza I actually like to reheat, actually the only pizza.  Warning:  A 20 inch pie will run you $25.25.....but it is worth every cent.

Since I had a 40 minute drive home, I also got a slice of the hotwing pizza.  (don't judge it was 8 at night and I was famished) I love that you can order slices!  And I think the slices are large.  Usually, I shy away from chicken on pizza, because honestly, places rarely do not use precooked chicken...and the chicken is always off.  NOT HERE!  This was cooked with love....long and slow in the hot wing sauce until they could shred the chicken with a fork.  Ranch was the base of the sauce and blue cheese crumbles set this slice off!  I could have used a little more blue cheese- but I am a fromage fanatic.

I was so bummed when I arrived because the patio was jamming (I ordered a carry out)...loads of people and their dogs were enjoying cocktails and pizza while relishing in the weekend, while being misted by fans....every near by patio was packed, most had live music, and the misting fans are the complete opposite of the patios in Michigan...we are batting away mosquitoes and crowding around heat lamps.  i cannot wait to bring my betrothed and soak in the downtown atmosphere....and more importantly get more pizza!

So finally after numerous visits to Brauhaus Schmitz I decided to get around to writing a review.  As I stood there amongst the circus that is south street on a pleasant fall afternoon I finally realized that this review had to happen.  Perhaps it was the beer or maybe the roasted pig, but something made me grab the trusty iPhone and draft a review.

As a restaurant brauhaus Schmitz is simple.  There is no real flair.  The menu includes what seem to be traditional German staples (various kinds of sausages, sauerkraut, awesome spaetzle and of course Beer) and the service staff has always been pleasant, well informed and very stuffed into their corsets.  I'm not sure if corset is the right word but I can appreciate the effect it has.

If you've never dined here you should go and get the wurstplatte.  It's going to be an easily approachable dish because it let's you choose you sausage type and two sides.  It's priced very reasonably and like I said before the spaetzle kicks ass.  It's buttery and slighty crunchy, ok I'm making myself hungry.

Moving on, if you want a small adventure pre-meal I suggest the schinkenplatte.  It is a large board of meats, cheeses, pickled veggies and bread.  Easily split with a group of people or possibly housed alone if you're really getting ferschnooken (I made that one up Webster) it will not disappoint.  I believe I even had the black forest cake once and it was a very large, moist and decadent piece of cake.  Splitting that is a must unless you're the octomom.

The beer list changes pretty frequently and the selection is good both on draft and in bottles.  I met the owner at the Craft Beer Fest earlier this year and he was a cool man.  They had a special during the blizzard that we had in philly and he got cleaned out of his rochefort 10.

I love this place.

The tropical rainforest exhibit is spectacular. Love the water theme is the flower show. Very crowded on the weekend and somewhat difficult to get close to the displays. Lots of food and things to buy. Wish there was less of this and more big exhibits.

This is my new go to coffee shop when I'm in SB. It has a great vibe. I love the open feel and although it's popular, you can always find a place to sit. The coffee and tea is way better than your average coffee shop and so flavorful. I always have an urge to get a second glass of ice tea, but it's pricey so I never indulge. 

The food they offer is great but I wish they had more food options (especially healthy ones). They have a small pastry selection and a fridge with mostly juices, I did see a parfait. Their plain croissant was good but I wish they had more flavors to choose from. Another weekend I was there they had ham and cheese croissants but the person in front of me got the last one. *sigh*

Also, they seem to be super dog friendly, like most places in SB, I've always seen a few people with different dogs on the patio outside. There were a few people doing work, but most people are just chilling there for a quick drink before continuing on with their day.

Pretty good nice small place but fast. When you want cheesy this place is it. Such a large variety, all the way down to the packaging it's so good. I would love to get back and try other options. Thanks for sharing the Mac with the world. Check out the photos, you may even see something you want to try.

So far, I have not been too impressed with the food trucks in Nashville. So, with no real expectations in mind I went over to The Hot Spot trailer while they were parked at Turtle Anarchy. I had never heard of them before this so with the 'deer in the headlights' look I approached cautiously. The person behind the counter offered some suggestions. Their Twisted Chicken, with Jamaican jerk spice and Asian hot sauce, it's Sriracha. I don't know why they don't mention it by name, it's like calling Guinness 'Irish stout from the St. James brewery.' I don't think I've met someone who doesn't love Sriracha so no need for euphemisms.

Anyway, it was $7 for two big pieces of their chicken, spiraled with Sriracha and a separate container containing their fennel slaw. I've been similarly unimpressed with hot chicken but once I sat back down at the bar and opened the container it was a flaky, spicy, but still tasty piece of chicken. The hot chicken I've gotten was just heat but with very little flavor. The chicken, while sweat pouringly, mouth burningly spicy was still really tasty. I kept biting into it thinking 'oh man this is good' while wiping my face on my sleeves, careful to avoid rubbing my eyes with any heat. The random smoothness of the Sriracha with the spice in their batter was awesome. Their fennel slaw, was also really tasty with plenty of fennel seed in the mix and it was basically the only thing that could keep the heat down-too bad that there was so little of it.

My friend came later and I got her the patty melt as a belated bday dinner. She really seemed to like it and it's probably the only thing on the menu that doesn't have spice on it. He was even nice enough to walk it into the brewery when it was ready. 

He eventually left because of the lightning that came in "me in a little metal box with lightning around, I'm leaving" and as my friend and I were thinking of eating again we told him how sad it was that he was wrapped up to go. He gave us what he had left, a huge basket of fries and three big pieces of chicken for free. He's changed my mind about food trucks and hot chicken, but more slaw please!

I loved  visiting this west part of Tucson, near its birthplace. And I loved the colorful building of St. Mary's. The gentleman who took our orders was very polite and the food arrived quickly. 

Concrete floors, simple tables, food served in styrofoam containers with plastic forks. Basically grab it and serve yourself. No choices of salsas, which I missed.

The green tamale I ordered  came with the usual tasting rice and beans and a delicious tortilla. The tamale, sadly, was uninspired and cold. (El Parador, Tucson Tamale Co. and Poca Cosa still are the best for corn tamales IMHO).

My partner had the bean burrito veggie style and pronounced it "quite good." That's all: "quite good." hmmm.

I'm glad we ate here and I would certainly try them again if we're in that part of the Old Pueblo but I was less than amazed at the experience.

So I've been a customer of this fabulous shop for years... HOW has a review escaped me?!

There is no way you won't find something here that is amazing and delicious! Are you celiac, gluten free or just loving that smell of an amazing deli? Come here. 

Frozen gluten-free pizzas are FANTASTIC! Made on amazing Care Bakery (Calgary) crusts are loaded with toppings and can't be beaten! The meat lover pizza is our favourite but try the BBQ chicken! Woohoo! Sweet, spicy, meaty!

Hot food to go? Gluten free spring rolls, chicken strips, nuggets... fries! Done in an air fryer that is super HOT! 
Special gluten-free mini Donut Saturdays! Bucket please! 

Cheese? Why yes please!

Something for the four-legged family member? Dog bones? Pigs ears? You bet.

They carry pre-blended ground beef/pork for cabbage rolls or whatever you make! Sliders, burgers, delicious! Deli meats, steaks, cured meats... all in the deli counter with fabulous personal service. 

The aisles are packed with Dutch goodies, stroopwaffel? Several kinds including glutenfree! Bulk candies? Rainbow of selection!

So many great things about this local gem of a shop.

Covid protocols are followed, masks required. POS equipment cleaned frequently.  The only challenge shopping here is parking. You might have to walk a little bit, but it's worth it.

I'm a sucker for ice cream, but Jeni's takes the cake (or maybe cone) for my addiction. This place is very modern and had a fun atmosphere about it. Every time I drive by, there seems to me a line out the door. 

I stopped in with a friend to check it out, finally and I'm so glad I did. There was a line when we arrived, but we didn't wait long.

We were greeted by the friendly scooper (not sure the technical term - but it sounds right?) who encouraged me to try a few different types so I got the ice cream I truly loved! 

I had a few samples and chose on the Pistacho and Honey. It was very hard to chose from all the fun flavors they had available. 

I can't wait to head back and try all the other flavors!

Cute place. Good food. Inside a building that houses a hotel. A few different items on the menu that are unusual. Love that they offer mimosas and bloody mary's. Smoothies and fresh squeezed o.j.
The grits were delicious and the home fries are very tasty.  We enjoyed our breakfast.

Now that we all get to see these bar charts showing how liberal we are with stars/ratings, I have been making a conscious effort to be picky and give tougher ratings...but it cannot be done at Supper.
Why not?  Here's why I give it a 5.
1.  Beautifully renovated old building which has been tastefullly renovated.
2.  You get greeted by a genuine, smiling face as you arrive to claim your difficult to acquire reservation.
3.  The waiter is a complete pro.  Immediate service without feeling pressured.
4.  The waiter knows the drink/wine menu (and subsequently the dinner menu) like the back of his hand.  Has obviously tried and enjoyed all the wines...and can tell you why he likes or dislikes each.
5.  The waiter describes the merits of the different preparations of each dish, and again offers genuine opinions on each (instead of the classic and soooo irritating, "they're all good.") And, he has great taste in food.
6.  My food was awesome.  Easily one of the best meals in my memory.  The menu is creative and the preparation and presentation is amazing.  Grilled squid with lemongrass, followed by sea scallops with uni butter, stuffed romaine and Japanese mint.  Mouthwatering.

Philadelphia, you are one lucky town.  Hey Supper!  Wanna move to Chicago?  The Windy City would love you.

I stopped in one very busy Friday evening and luckily got a spot at the sushi bar.  The service was great and the sushi chef really friendly.  A fairly extensive sake menu as well.  After reading the dizzying array of menu choices - they serve everything with 3 kinds of sauces, I finally ordered a scallop and a yellowtail sashimi, and squid stuffed with spicy tuna.  While everything was tasty, I have to say that the sauces really took away from the fresh flavors of the seafood itself.  There was just too much chipotle and jalapeno flavors trying to pass itself off in japanese cuisine.  I love peppers, but the thing I like most about japanese food is the simplicity of the flavors.  The chef agreed that one would find more traditional restaurants in Japan.  I like the choices, but I may just stick with traditional sashimi next time I visit.

Very slim pickins in Holland PA so can't be too diva. For what this place used to be, I think it looks amazing! The bar is beautiful, I love all the skull decorations. I came for Cinco de Mayo / Happy Hour so it was pretty crowded but I was still able to get a drink within 15 minutes in the bar. The strawberry basil margarita didn't seem very strong, but the mango one was delicious and the perfect amount of sour. 

The chips and salsa were very good but as for the carne taco, the meat was very tough and hard to eat. The beer battered fish taco was good and crispy.I am intrigued to come again to try the crab avocado and the ceviche. I'm a little scared to try ceviche in Village Shires but maybe once I hear good reviews I will be open

Umami is a newly opened pan-Asian restaurant serving authentic Japanese, Korean and Thai food. I live in Chicago, but I go to Nashville often to visit family and friends (I stayed in Brentwood area), so it was nice timing for me to try out this new restaurant and I got to try a lot of their menu items with our group. They've got a great variety of dishes on their menu, and everything we had was delicious. You can tell that everything is made from scratch here, as well as using fresh, authentic ingredients. Here's my review on each item, in no particular order:

Kimchi fries: This is a fun take using a Korean classic (the kimchi) and an American snack (cheese fries). I loved all the flavors and textures on this dish: crispy hot french fries topped with ooey, gooey nacho cheese, sauteed kimchi, scallions, and a white sauce that I can only guess is mayo (or sour cream?). I will try to update this when I find out. 

Korean Fried Chicken: One of their more popular items (according to our server). You can select the soy garlic or the spicy sauce, or go half and half with your order (6 pcs, 10 pcs, 20 pcs, 30 pcs). I wanted my son to be able to try it, so I opted for the soy garlic. That did NOT disappoint! It's the perfect blend of that umami flavor that comes from soy sauce paired with the garlic flavor. It comes with a side of pickled radishes that is the perfect complementary crunch with your chicken. This is actually how fried chicken is served in Korea, and it's excellent. No need to travel all the way to Seoul!

Tuna poke: this is your classic tuna poke (pronouned poh-kae), which is a salad of raw tuna, cucumber and avocados. There were large chunks of fresh tuna, marinated and seasoned well (not overpowering the tuna or anything). 

Speaking of fresh...can't get any fresher with the sashimi plate! We got a variety of sashimi to share, and I seriously loved every type of fish! If you're adventurous, you can try the freshly fried shrimp head if you order the sweet shrimp sashimi. The kitchen basically deep-fries the actual shrimp head that's taken off the body of the raw shrimp. For some of you, that sounds like something that could be shown on Andrew Zimmern's show, Bizarre Foods. But like he says on his show...if it looks good, eat it!!!!!!! Ahng!!!!! 

Mango Tango Maki Roll: one of the recommendations from our server -- did not disappoint! I asked for this roll without cream cheese (I just do not prefer to have any cream cheese in any of my rolls) and it was not even an issue (I mention this, because some restaurants don't like to customize the maki roll orders -- "no substitutes" policy at those places). I don't think I've ever had a "sweet" maki roll before, and I was pleasantly surprised with the flavors of this roll. The spicy crab and mango/strawberry actually went really well together. I'm glad that they can be inventive with their maki rolls, as well as serve the usual crowd favorites. 
Side note: I love the fun names of the maki rolls -- ranging from "Pokemon Go", "Music City", and "the "OMG Roll" (I imagine this one will make you say OMG haha)

Korean Chicken Tacos: You can choose from beef, chicken or pork for the Korean tacos. My son loves chicken, so we just went with the safer option (still delicious). I guess we could have tried the combo, I think that comes with one of each taco, maybe? This is also a very fun take on some classic Korean flavors with a little Mexican twist: the chicken has a Korean marinade, topped with Asian pickled radishes and cilantro, served in a warm corn tortilla.

Seafood Ramen: If you're familiar with and (like me) LOVE the Chinese-Korean noodle dish called "Jjam-bbong", then you will equally fall in love with this dish! The noodles are obviously the ramen noodles, but in the spicy seafood broth that is used for the "jjam-bbong" dish. I can tell that they use fresh seafood for the broth, because it's spicy and refreshing, not fishy at all! I was actually thinking about this bowl the next day...and how much I wanted to eat it again. The next time I'm in town, I will definitely be coming back to get this dish again!

Beer Selection: They have an AWESOME beer selection, with some local and international beers. I love checking out local beers wherever I go, and the ones I tried were awesome. They also have some great ones on tap. 
Fun tip: Order a large pitcher of beer, and it comes out in this REALLY fun pitcher that has dry ice and flashing lights -- so flashing smoke from your pitcher. It's not just for funsies, though...it keeps your beer nice and cold so that every pour is just as refreshing as the first.

I saw a lot of people coming in for pick-up orders, so if you don't have time to sit down in the restaurant, you could always call ahead and pick up on your way home (or wherever you're headed).

Overall, a wonderful meal and experience at Umami. Keep it up, guys! I'll be coming back soon.

I absolutely love this place! Extremely Divey and the Mexican food is fantastic. My boyfriend and I's favorite items are the chicken tacos and the quesadillas! It's cheap and easy and a fun place to look around and grocery shop!

BEST: Crab Rangoons

...at least in STL.  Great sauce with it too.

Really have grown to love this place!  Good lunch specials.  I love the sushi, but love the chicken dishes too.  I like the sushi dish that comes on fire.  That always gets attention.   Pad Thai is really good food too.  
Tip:  Some of the rice dishes can be a little bland, so add a little sweet and sour sauce in order to build some more flavor.  It isn't your typical sweet and sour, and just a little really gives the dish more depth.

I'd go there just for the crab Rangoon though.

The Toastery is my new favorite brunch place! I love the warm corn bread with apple butter that welcomes you when you arrive! My pancakes were equally delicious, as they were served with crispy bacon and topped with powdered sugar! Another great brunch spot!

Small froyo shop in the cute neighborhood off of Delmar and North & South. There were 2 vegan options: cinnamon and banana. I liked neither.  They had a watermelon flavor, but it contained dairy. WHY??!! The kids loved their flavors, which included salted caramel, chocolate, and cheesecake.  They offer 2 cup sizes here: large and larger. So no matter how little you put in even the smallest cup, it's gonna cost you $5. I'm not a fan of this money-grabbing practice.

I hear that they rotate the flavors often, so I wouldn't be against returning to see if they have more appealing vegan options next time.  However, in general, they are over-priced and would not be my first choice for dairy-free dessert. 

Also, if the cramped little parking area on the side of the building is full, there is more parking in the back, off of North & South.

Went to Goat Hollow last night for dinner with a friend who lives in Mt. Airy. Atmosphere was great - rustic, love the wood stove (would imagine that it's very warm & welcoming on a winter night). We sat at the bar, bartender was attentive, my martini was excellent and she kept an eye on my friend's wine glass. We ordered the charcuterie platter (currently kind of obsessed with them) and a large house salad to split. The salad was fine, but I was somewhat surprised that they didn't split it for us (especially given lack of space at the bar). Slightly overdressed and could have used more goat cheese. The charcuterie platter was disappointing to say the least! The cheeses (I believe there were 3?) were cut into such tiny slivers that you could barely get a decent feeling for the taste/texture. The prosciutto was fine, there just wasn't much of it. There was no explanation of the cheeses OR the meats, and a couple of the meats were... difficult to discern? A terrine of some kind? The pickled veggies were good, as were the cornichons (but those likely came out of a can, as did the whole grain mustard). I believe we received 5 pieces of bread to go with the whole thing. Needless to say, we both left hungry. 

On a positive note, another patron at the bar ordered the smoked salmon board, and it looked delicious - we were both jealous and drooling over the plentiful portion of salmon and pile of bread. Why so stingy with the meats & cheeses, Goat Hollow?

This place was great! I loved the atmosphere, really good services. I did end up just eating wings and fries because I had to run but I will def. be back for a burger I was so jealous as they were bring them out looked and smelled so good! Great place to meet up with friends on a Friday after work. Can't wait to go back!

I've been in several times now, a couple times for dinner a few times for drinks only. I'm so impressed with how beautiful the restaurant is. It has an industrial feel, but is still warm. 

I order my beloved caipirinha (Brazilian cocktail made with cachaca, muddled limes and cane sugar) - something you don't see on menus often in Indianapolis. I've also tried the passion fruit caipirinha and didn't love it nearly as much; lime is the way to go. If you want tequila, the carriage house margarita is very good (careful, they creep up on you).

Brussels sprouts app is amazing - charred and topped with cotija cheese and lime juice. The empanadas I've had were good but a bit bland. I've had empanadas at two authentic Cuban restaurants in the past and they had more flavor. I know that there are different interpretations of empanadas depending on where you go, but these seemed moreso Americanized. 

The Red Drum entree is amazing. Just get it. 

Churros very good. I will always need the churros when I come. 

I'll definitely be back for the beautiful ambiance, service and food.
