I loved their vinegar out of their four sauce. The pork skin isn't greasy and the seasoning is tasty. The deviled egg potato salad was creamy and delicious. Heavy enough to put me in a food coma. Lastly their sweet tea is a must to wash down all the delicious bbq meat.

Our group of gals headed over to Tavern for a brunch while visiting Nashville for a bachelorette party. We were a party of five, and while we waited for a table, we found a back bar that was quieter than the main dining room chock-full of brunchers and bach parties ( I literally had no idea that Nashville was such a bach party destination). At this little back bar was one of the most chill bartenders, Rebekah, who took care of us with delicious bloody marys and bellinis (and much needed waters). During brunch, there is a two-for-one on their Brunch Libations which includes bloody marys, mimosas, bellinis, and sangria. Definitely worth it. 

We opted to sit outside since the weather was pleasant. The prices are really fair especially since some of the dishes were massive. I split the Singapore Stir Fry with another gal, and my own dish seemed like one serving. I also got avocados to mash into it!  I do feel like this dish could've had more oomph of flavor, but maybe its toned down for the hoi polloi so ask for some hot sauce!  

The Maple Fondue is great to try a little bit of everything on their menu, and I love savory and sweet flavors together. Standout was the grilled spicy chicken sausage. Great for the whole table. 

Not sure if it was because we were outside, but our waitress (not Rebekah, but a different gal) was a bit MIA at times. Note to folks wanting to eat outside during the summer, at some point it will get warm, haha, so maybe bring a fan 'cause what's brunch without a cute fan. 

I'd definitely suggest this as a great spot to bring a group for brunch, and would be interested to check them out on a return visit for other eating hours and to peruse their beer selection! 

$11.50 SINGAPORE STIR FRY
#1 short-grain rice / sunny side up eggs / bacon / scallions / sweet & spicy soy / wok-flavored

$17 MAPLE FONDUE ( FOR THE TABLE)
warm maple syrup / fresh fruit / red velvet waffle / grilled sausages / pain perdu

I recently went to the Yelp Elite Event at Bartaco last month. I decided to bring my fiancé back here since I was given some bar token (1 bar token = 1 free taco) as part of a goodie bag from the event and because I think the food is awesome. We had a really sweet server named Regina K. I highly recommend the pomegranate lemonade that is made from scratch daily. One of the issues I had with the visit this time was that our lemonades took a long time to come out. The other issue I had was I asked the server if the $3.50 tacos counted as part of the free taco bar token and she thought it was, but our check only reflected the cheaper tacos ($2.50 ones) count towards the free taco token. No big deal, but I feel this is important information for anyone to know who has bar chips and what tacos would be completely free etc. I completely understand the reasoning behind that. My fiancé and I shared the guacamole, corn fritters, and empanadas for appetizers. Everything was so delicious - I think the corn fritters are the best, and I loved the sauce served its them. The tacos were wonderful of course, and I'm a big fan of the corn tortillas. For dessert, we each had the tres leches, which was awesome as well. I was expecting it to be a tiny portion size since Regina did mention it came in a mason jar, but it was actually a decent size. I look forward to bringing my future in laws here since they are foodies like me, and I know they will love it too!

In retrospect, I have to wonder if I was in St. Louis for a conference or for barbecue.  Well, I do guess both since I find myself scoping out places to eat whenever I travel.  In my black book of St. Louis eats, there were two barbecue joints, Pappy's and Bogart's. Barbecue is always at the top of my list.  Why should a visit to St. Louis be any different?

Well, I lucked out this time.  After spending an hour and a half a few days before in Pappy's queue, I spent a mire 15 minutes in Bogart's.  I expected a huge line, but I guess we timed it just right.

As we viewed the menu, we realized that history had to repeat itself - we would have to go for the combo.  At Bogart's it's called the Old Joe Platter - a full slab of ribs, any 3 sandwiches, plus 4 sides. Again, two people had an uphill battle - another man versus food.

In addition to the ribs, our three sandwiches were the prime rib with grilled onions, pulled pork, and burnt ends. With that, we had cole slaw, deviled egg potato salad, baked beans, and the fire and ice pickles.  We were ready for a showdown.

The star was the ribs - nicely peppered, beautifully glazed, and finger-licking sticky. The ribs were super meaty, tender, juicy, and pulled off the bone with ease. These were, without a doubt, the best ribs I've ever had.

After attacking the ribs, It was hard to enjoy the other sandwiches because I wanted more ribs.  The prime ribs was delicious, but it seemed to be out of place somehow; it may deserve a restaurant of its very own. Kiss Arby's goodbye if that happens.

I enjoyed both the pulled pork and burnt ends.  But the ribs....the ribs! I hope you understand.

Of the sides, there were two stars - the deviled egg potato salad and the fire and ice pickles.  The potato salad itself is familiar yet so very different.  Loved it!  The fire and ice pickles came out ice cold - that's the way to eat'em.  As they warm up, you can feel the heat a bit more intensely.  They were almost palate cleansing like pickled ginger at a Japanese restaurant.  Good eating!

I was pleasantly surprised by Pappy's barbecue, but Bogart's took it to another level.  The food is amazing and the service is even better.  No less than four people stopped by to check on us.  As we filed through the line, we were given smoky wings; a great meal starter. 

Overall, it was a real pleasant experience.  Too bad the 'Old Joe' did us in; we were able to finish it.  I ate the ribs first, though.

The service here is beyond awesome!  They were super accommodating to our large group when the restaurant we had reservations at had a fire.  Cafe Napoli came to our rescue and did a very fine job of it.  The service was fast and accurate.  They were very good at keeping water glasses filled and removing empty plates.  The menu was limited due to our circumstances, but actually made it easier to choose.  I had the Penne con Broccoli and it was outstanding.  I thought the house salad was perfect.  I would love to go back and try other things.

I am somewhat embarrassed to admit but I do not get it. I'm not from St. Louis so didn't grow up eating Ted Drewes. As a result, I do not have any childhood memories or nostalgia. The only thing I know about the place is that they have decent and forgettable custard that comes out partially melted. 

I love ice cream and custard and was genuinely excited (probably too much for someone approaching 30) to be served a concrete upside down but I received a partially melted cup of custard the normal way. I have had better ice cream/custard at a variety of other places. I wonder if after so many years, they are just relying on their reputation.

Loved that they had ethically sourced coffee and that their donuts were vegan and allergy friendly. Ample parking, which is somewhat rare for Tampa. 

The donuts were shockingly small but most were pretty tasty with good texture. At least they weren't overpriced for the size, which some donut places are. The strawberry cheesecake donut was strong on strawberry but lacking in cheesecakiness. The fruity pebble and apple pie were the favorites. 

Didn't appreciate the jesus music that was blaring through the whole time though. Overall would probably return if I were in the area and craving delicious things.

We love this place.

We have had a membership here for over 10 years.   it's clean and everything is in a big oval so you are not missing major parts of the zoo.  

They are always updating and making the zoo better.  The childrens zoo is new and very well thought out.  My son loves going to this area.

They have plenty of parking. The staff is helpful.

For the money the membership is an amazing deal.  We are here all year.. Covers parking and discount in the shop/food areas.   

We visited Santa and he was awesome.  Prices for pics were very reasonable (cheaper then the mall).

We will DEFINITELY be back.

poke is new to me, but how it's served at poke bowl reminds me a lot of chirashi or hwe dup bap - both of which i love. 

it's a chipotle style operation where you add ingredients as you move down the line. i was full after having the large bowl, which comes with 5 scoops of protein. i only tried the salmon, octopus and crab - all of which were great. the protein gets marinated in a sauce of your choice before it's added to the bowl. afterwards you get to pick toppings and other sauces to drizzle on top. presentation is strong here - the edible flower is a really nice touch.

i think the small size of the bowls make it really hard to mix anything until you've pretty much nibbled off a good chunk of your toppings to make space. i was nervous about things toppling off the sides as i maneuvered my chopsticks around.

hope poke is here to stay!

Absolutely love the food and atmosphere. The guy working the front is full of positivity, energy and hustle. Long line but the wait is not bad because it moves so fast. 

The watermelon cucumber fresca was amazing, and the house guac was probably the best I've ever had!

The chips were warm and crisp, very yummy with all the salsas and guac. 

Love love loved it and we will definitely be back!

I had a chance to swing by the new Barking Buffalo Cafe last week, a small grab-and-go coffee space paired with local fashion brand Salgado Fenwick. Coffee and fashion all in one space? It's not an unusual concept but definitely a presentation of two visions bringing more life to the growing 124 Street district.

The space was previously home to Parkhill Vision Care, with the downstairs space being used as Salgado Fenwick's workshop. The upstairs became vacant last winter and Salgado Fenwick owners Linda Ritter and Shauna Force figured, why not? As lovers of coffee, they joined forces with Kassie Burkholder to bring you Barking Buffalo Cafe. Throw in Elliot Kerr, previously at Duchess Bakeshop, to help behind the bar and tada!

The space is gorgeous, a display and shop of Salgado Fenwick's fashions, complete with change rooms. Custom woodworking done by Oleson Woodshop in Regina gives Barking Buffalo Cafe, a fitting cabin-feel as most of the clothing have animal-inspired silkscreened prints. Head towards the back and you can actually see the cutting and sewing spaces for the shop which is pretty cool. The space extends even past the workshop, currently up for debate as to what it will become in the future.

A few tables line the side wall, although the space is meant for a grab-and-go (or shop!) cup. Loved that they're serving Toronto's Pilot Coffee Roasters, a new roast to me and a welcomed one at that. I'm all about variety! Almond milk is a default here, a vegetarian/vegan friendly staple and for those sick and tired of paying the extra cost for the substitute. For those of us who like our regular milk, don't worry, just ask! Muffins and granola bars are also available for munching.

Congrats to Barking Buffalo Cafe on their opening! For a different cup of coffee and a chance to check out a great space, head up a little further 124th street to pay them a visit. Open late on Thursday nights, you can also pop by during the 124 Grand Market.

Excellent service from David O.! Food was excellent! My steak was cooked exactly as I ordered, and my fiancé's shrimp dish was so good. I love the mini desserts they have - we both ordered the peanut butter chocolate jar. So good! I don't know why I don't come here more often as I live minutes away. I hope to be back soon!

I'm a big fan of the Hawkers in the Mills 50 area of Orlando, so I had really high hopes for the St Pete incarnation. The atmosphere is great. The owners completely gutted Taps and Tequila and the new space is light, airy and open. A garage door opens to a patio, which is where our table of 8 was seated. We probably should have known better than to bring such a large party so close to the grand opening, but we did it anyway. The food was great, I had the Summer Rolls, which were huge, and Char Kway Tao, a personal favorite. We ordered lots of the naan, which everyone enjoyed. The service was spotty to say the least. They were out of the sparkling sake on the menu, our server kept forgetting things, and on at least one occasion they brought us someone else's food. The server admitted that they were having a problem with runners just leaving the kitchen with food and not checking the tickets, which is kind of concerning. We ordered sake bombs for the table- 3 Kirins and 4 bottles of sake, roughly. When it came time to pay, the server could not figure out how to break up the sake bombs (how does an asian restaurant NOT have something for this on their POS system?). At this point we had been there almost three hours! I got frustrated and just paid for the whole thing, as I was not going to waste any more time on $35. Long story short, I will be back to try again soon with a smaller party because I'm loyal to Hawkers and I do love the food. I really do hope they get the service under control, though, as I have never had these problems at the Hawkers in Orlando

A few of my friends and I go to Han Dynasty all the time. Every time we make plans with each other, we all pretend to think about other places to eat. But in the end we always go to Han Dynasty. 

I really love the food at Han Dynasty. But just as a warning, be prepared to go into a food coma after eating here because the food is really oily. My personal favorites are the Dan Dan Noodles and Eggplant with Garlic Sauce. The food is pretty spicy. Each dish comes with a spice rating from 1-10. But if you can't handle too much spice, you can ask them to tone the spice down to a lower number. 

If you have a big party, you can get a table in the back that has a Lazy Susan on it. The tables in the back are also semi-private. 

Waiters are always prompt and friendly. Ambiance is casual. Over, just a great place for lunch or dinner with friends.

3/4/17

The BF and I came to the Galleria to dine at the Cheesecake Factory and due to a long wait,we decided to walk around. We ended up here and David came over to help us when he noticed us looking at men wedding bands. I picked out a few I liked and my boyfriend picked out his choices. David helped him try on tje rings and really kept us entertained. He was super funny and knowledgeable! We eventually ended up in the watch section and once he saw my guy's eyes light up, he quickly turned on the intensity to make a sale. Lol. He really did not have to as watches are sorta my guy's thing; he loves watches the more expensive the better. All in all he walked away with an early birthday present from me. We received a quality product from a well known, reputable business that employs great people such as David.

Don't shoot me...but....I'm not a pizza girl. Yeah - it's almost like saying you don't like rainbows or butterflies. But, in comparison to the general population, I don't get half as excited as ya'll do when it comes to the savory pie. It might be even better to describe me as a pizza snob. The kind of person who gets all razzled for pizzas that have toppings like prosciutto, arugula or sun dried tomatoes. Snob. You won't find me knocking at the door of Pizza Hut or Pizza King. However, if I'm in Italy - I'm eating pizza. And, if I'm in Indy, I'm eating Bazbeaux (conveniently located in my neighborhood).  

I think it's the wide variety of available veggies that makes me love Bazbeaux so much. Last night, I opted for the new "Fresh Pizza" - pesto/olive oil in place of pizza sauce, arugula, roasted tomatoes, mozzarella (sliced), basil with added garlic and proscuitto. I was a little bummed that I didn't opt for the larger size because by the final slice, my friends and I were passing it like a pipe...just oneeee moooorrreeee bitteeee... The cherry on top? BP carries H20 Sushi's soheartyitsgottabehealthy,right? Shagbark cookies. If you haven't had one, stop waiting. Make it happen. 

Their new location in the 3Mass building seems to suit them well - spacious with a sidewalk cafe. The only bummer is that the old location is still sitting empty in one of Downtown's primest of prime locations.

My first time here and I am super impressed!!

It's definitely not a typical "Nashville" spot - don't expect some trendy Instagrammable scene. I read one review that said the atmosphere was confusing, which isn't wrong, but I don't think it's a negative thing.

We sat at the bar because there were two seats left and we were hungry. Half off bottles of wine all day, every day. If that's not enough to get you there then I don't know what is.  service at the bar is obviously never as good as being seated, but the bartender was as attentive as she could be and was super helpful each time she came over to us.

We got the Salmon dip to start. SO GOOD. For the entree, we split the Plum Salmon and the Ahi Tuna (that's why my photos look like the plates are small). 

There wasn't a thing I didn't love and I'd recommend this place to anyone! Such a wide selection of food -- tacos, pasta, meats, fish.

I have always leased cars and the most recent car I leased was a Toyota Corolla from Andy Mohr Toyota. I really liked the service I received from Andy Mohr Toyota but I grew to hate my corolla. After coming close to getting in a serious car accident, I was desperate to end my lease early and get into something bigger and safer. I was super picky about what I wanted but knew I wanted an affordable suv with 3rd row seating. To get my garage spot I told my fiancé my car would need remote start and heated seats. We found the affordable Volkswagen Tiguan online and decided to check it out. 

We were greeted at Andy Mohr Volkswagen with smiles and phenomenal customer service. Tyler was patient with our indecisiveness as he walked us around the entire lot to look at every Tiguan they had as we compared every small detail. We decided on the Tiguan SEL and I absolutely LOVE it. Tyler was patient and understanding when we asked for some time to think about all of our options. Once we decided on the perfect one Tyler walked us through all of the paperwork in an easy to understand way. He used his time wisely and explained the features of the car to us while we waited for someone to finalize all of the paperwork for us. 

They called to make sure I was loving my new car and were there to answer any little question I had. When I returned the spare keys to my old car, they greeted us by name. I work at a school and we collected toys for tots but we weren't a drop off location so I asked if we could drop off the toys at their store. They were so excited and helped us carry in the multiple boxes of toys we had for them. 

I did have to take my car in the get the latch in the driver side door tightened up and they were sure to get me in quickly. Again I was greeted with smiles and was called by name. They thanked me again for all of the toys we donated and were quick to get my car fixed. While i waited in their computer waiting area they even washed my car for me. If you need a new car I would highly suggest heading to Andy Mohr Volkswagen and asking for Tyler. You won't be disappointed.

The things this place can do with vegetables is bananas. 
Their ability to pair texture, flavor, temperatures, and mix in substitutes is amazing. The Kung Pao crunch is so fun to eat. The Korean bbq tacos have so much balance. The must have are the mushroom based Dan Dan noodles. So salty and saucey. I just love this place!

You know you're getting good Chinese food outside of China when almost everyone in the restaurant is Chinese. Came here last night with a Chinese friend of mine because he was determined to show us what actual Chinese food is all about and Cate Zone delivers. We started with a traditional appetizer - pork skins in gelatin. A chilled dish which was not to my taste but many in the group loved. We were paraded with dish after dish of flavorful favorites of my friend's - crispy eggplant, sautéed pea shoots, egg-battered shrimp, and for the adventurer: some sort of organ stew, complete with a broth which encorporated pig's blood (waste not,want not, right?). The latter was not to my taste, but I was grateful to try so many traditional favorites. And he was thrilled to show them off! I will recommend cate zone to anyone. 

A few notes - service is good, and fast, but the place is small and popular so your guaranteed to wait and don't expect to linger long after dinner. The atmosphere is bare bones. They just got a liquor license, they offer a single Chinese beer that you won't want to miss. Light, crisp, and refreshing, it goes great with the flavor-packed dishes.

*drum roll please*

I will be the very first to confess that I am not a coffee drinker. I never got used to the taste of coffee, although I do like the smell of freshly-brewed coffee. What I do enjoy is a place to visit with friends, sip a beverage of my choosing, and relax in a comfortable "homey" environment.

Sips Specialty Coffee House is just such a place, located along Gunn Highway near Citrus Park. You'll find Sips in a little strip mall out in front of Super WalMart and down the block from an Amscot financial center. It's right at the intersection of Gunn and Henderson Road.

Walking in the front door I had to do a double-take because I thought that I'd stepped back into my mother's kitchen. You could smell all of the wonderful scents of baked goods, along with the flavors of coffee and toppings. There were people sitting at tables, sipping their drinks, playing cards, board games, laughing, and chattering away. The decorations were definitely right in line with what my Mom would have placed around her kitchen.

I had the opportunity to meet the owners, Caryn and Ken Reed, and learn a bit about their journey from Michigan to Florida, and the idea for their coffee house which opened six months ago. Very nice, down-to-earth people who are looking to provide that comfy neighborhood gathering place for people to meet up, play a game of Jenga or chess, and do a bit of networking. 

Oh yes, and enjoy that coffee - hot, iced, blended, frozen - you name it. The house special is Sips Mocha which is made with white chocolate, swirls of caramel, steamed milk & espresso. They have lattes and mochas and cappuccinos and espressos, fruit smoothies, hot teas, iced teas, and your regular ol' cup o' Joe. There's also a refrigerated case with fruit juices, soda, and bottled water.

They have a baked goods counter with bagels, muffins and pastries, and these AMAZING homemade dark chocolate cupcakes with Reese's cups inside.  YUMMMMM!!!!

For those who are on the go and don't want to climb out of your car, then Sips has a drive-up, full-service window. You can get a single-serving cup, or pick up one of their containers of coffee for the office.

Now one final treat -- especially for us Yelpers. Sips happens to employ the very lovely and sweet Ms. Cece C. as a barrista, and I highly encourage you to stop in and say Hi to her.

Yes, I understand, there are a lot of places where you can stop for coffee, but not many places offer this type of cozy atmosphere. It is worth the time to stop and make some new friends while enjoying a great cup of......well, I was gonna say tea, but y'all would probably like the coffee a whole lot too.

Really a great Salon! I got my hair cut by Jessica, and she is the sweetest stylist you will ever meet. I got acquainted to the salon via Yelp, and was definitely willing to try it despite the distance from my house based on the reviews and positive comments. 

Once I got there, I parked on a side street (free, 2am-8pm for 2 hours only) which was  no trouble at all and walked a block to the salon. The area is different from what I was expecting, seeing as this was my first time in this part of town, seemed a little...grubby. However, the salon was presentable, and almost had a little bit of a hipster vibe (it IS organic, anyway) which I was comfortable with. They dont have state of the art decor and furniture, but I liked the homey feel and their vintage pieces and the ease at which the clients and hair stylists moved around. I was offered a drink, and sat to get my hair washed, cut and dried, all for $35. Very affordable, especially for me! She listened to all my concerns and then gave me a nice trim and updated my current cut for the look I wanted. Nothing bad to say about the entire experience. I loved the little scalp massage during the wash too!

Definitely a good experience and I'd likely come back in the future to get my hair cut again, but do wish it was a little closer to home.

This place is a true gem!!!! I loved the atmosphere it was very quiet clean and calming. I got a gel manicure and a pedicure and it was perfect!!! I like how they use paraffin wax on my feet, i hate the scrapper things lol. I will go back while Im here from Atlanta!!!! Suzie and Sophia are AMAZING!!!!!

Blondie's makes me wish I still worked downtown. It is a great addition to Washington and I've been (mostly) impressed the two times I've been. First just for drinks late on a Saturday. Other than 2-3 other small parties, the place was quiet. I was really surprised considering how busy everything else seemed to be. The decor is brilliant - cozy, comfortable, and practical. It's a mix of normal dining tables along with armchairs and sofas. Since we weren't ordering food we were able to relax by the fire. Nice!

I was also there for lunch on Saturday and the food was delicious. I tried the veggie sandwich and the turkey, green apple, mayo sandwich. Both came on a plain popover which made them impossible to eat with your hands. They were closer to an open-faced sandwich. Which leads me to my first complaint - the paper than they cover the plates with. Makes no sense at all. The sauce from the sandwiches quickly made the paper soggy and since I had to eat with utensils I was carving up the paper along with my sandwich. It was really annoying and impossible not to do. But that's an easy fix. The veggie was world's better than the turkey and this is only the second time ever I've raved about a veggie sandwich. You get either chips or fruit as a side and the chips come in a generous portion.

My other complaint is service was really, really slow. Slow to order, really slow to get our food (even though, again, there were only 3 other tables occupied), and we never did get our check delivered. We eventually went up front to pay. If service is like this during the work week, I can't imagine who would continue to go here.

Big bonus points for playing TCM on the TV's. But not cool that they have two bathrooms, both of which are unisex. Please make one a boy's and one a girl's. I hate using a public restroom after a guy. Gross.

But overall I love this place and it seems to work equally well as a lunch spot or late night hangout, which few places can do.

Really cool spot with both indoor and outdoor seating area. Friendly staff and they cell cigars! We got a flight and bought a cigar and enjoyed the beautiful weather outside.

Flight of 4:
Blueberry Prussia - fairly tart but paired very well with the cigar which cut it down. You can definitely get the Blueberry notes and it was pretty good.
Cast Iron Brown - I love brown Ales and definitely one of the better ones I've tasted. Kind of toasty, not over powering and easy to drink.
Nitro Irish Stout - As a Nitro Stout, you definitely get that creaminess and it is pretty good as well. Not my favorite of the four but all the beers were good here.
Absence of Light - I loved this one, the mix of peanut butter, chocolate and caramel are well balanced and it is smooth and delicious. This was probably my favorite one.

Great place and a cool vibe. Small parking lot here and some street parking around. They also sell food but we didn't order any. Definitely would come back and try more beers and the food!

I got lost in here multiple times but I don't care. This place is absolutely beautiful. Please come here and make a visit if you can. I found out about this place because of Karrueche (I love her so much) and I am so glad my friends and I came here. 

They said pictures are worth a thousand words, so just look at my photos and you'll see what I'm talking about. Yes, there's a small price to get in ($8) but it is totally worth every dollar! It's just absolutely beautiful here!

I love trying new places (especially my fav, SUSHI!) so we decided to give Kabuki off of Manchester a try after hearing rave reviews from friends.  We came in on a Friday night and the place was about half full, and we were seated quickly by a very sweet hostess.  We ordered a miso soup and their spicy soup (can't remember the name..) and both were really good.  The spicy soup is VERY spicy though, just to warn you!  Our waitress was very nice and attentive and made sure to keep stopping by if we needed refills.  We ordered a few plain rolls (which are usually always my favorite) like the tuna and yellowtail, and both were great.  We also ordered the tiger roll which was probably my favorite.  It's wrapped in pink soy paper and the flavors were delicious.  The Alaska roll was also wonderful.  I thought the sushi was very fresh, beautifully presented and their rice wasn't too overpowering or sweet (don't you hate when that happens??).  That being said, my only complaint was that for the price, I thought the rolls would be larger and we would have had more food.  I've heard their HH is great with cheap prices on drinks and select rolls, and we will definitely be back to check it out!

This is a great place to get a little work done, meet a friend, and sip a nice coffee! Note: you can get free refills on the coffee, which makes it great for a morning study session. Their sandwiches are quite yummy (my fav is the prosciutto one). I only wish I could get a few more chips on the side (it's a healthy little portion of chips). The staff is always friendly and I love the upstairs workspace! Definitely check it out!!

I went to Fogo for my bf's birthday last week, and it was very, very good! We got there 15 minutes after our reservation time (oops), but they seated us right away (it was a Thursday night and not horribly busy.) The servers came over right away to explain how it works. Basically, you have a small disc that is red on one side and green on the other. When you are ready to eat, you flip it to green. If you need a break, you flip it to red, and they won't offer you anything. There are chefs circling the tables, each with a different type of meat on a giant skewer. If you want that meat, they'll cut off a piece for you. You can do this as many times as you want. It's almost like dim sum, for those familiar with that type of dining.

I love that the food service began immediately, because everything was pretty much already cooked. They brought out the sides, which were polenta (just eh, but I'm not really into that), mashed potatoes (ok, but nothing special), and fried bananas (sweet mother of fried fruits, that was GREAT.) Just based on the sides, my review wouldn't have been that stellar, but then the meats started going around...

We started with the Parmesan-crusted pork, which was very salty but really good. I got that one a couple more times later on. I also really liked the bacon-wrapped filet Mignon. Boyfriend was practically hunting down the chef with the Picanha, which is a top sirloin and the house specialty. I didn't like that one as much, but he was getting a little obsessive about it. Everything else was good but not incredibly memorable. 

I should also mention that I ordered 2 Caipirinhas during the dinner service. It's the national drink of Brazil. I wasn't crazy about the first one--it was just the original recipe and kind of strong in an acidic way. The second one was the Passionfruit version, and that was delicious. They were both very strong, alcohol-wise, which is how I like my drinks!! They were also pretty darn expensive, but that's to be expected, I guess.

Finally, dessert. We got the chocolate molten lava cake with ice cream. There's really no way you can go wrong with that, and it was delicious. Just make sure to save room for dessert after all that meat.

One thing--it's expensive (over $150 just for bf and me), but it'd be pretty hard not to expect that going into it. The only thing is that there really isn't a menu, so you can't keep track of how everything adds up. Overall, though, we had a really great experience and will probably be back. I also got my dad (another steak-lover) a gift certificate there for Father' Day.

Bistro La Minette is the perfect date spot. Amazing service, food, and wine selection. 

I have been to Paris and the food here is reminiscent of my favorite bistro in Montmartre. I love that they have some of the French country style cuisine like Coq au Vin which is the best thing I have had there.

You will not be disappointed with anything you order.

Yes, it's true, the best tacos in Tucson are here! The staff is also very friendly, I love that there's a chips and salsa bar, and the watermelon-cucumber juice is to DIE FOR. You definitely can't go wrong ordering three tacos with a side of the Mexican rice. I will definitely be back!
Great place. Super fast, good service. Veggie ramen is delicious. Would love to have more veg options!  But will be back.

This is a nice hike, I"m not sure exactly where the trail gears off too the only sign of it is at the entrance.  I crossed the tracks and headed to the beach, they have a sign posted it's where the sea lions gather between December and May and they close the beach access off between those months.  You would be able to see the sea lions from the cliff with their pups.  The day I went hiking we just walked along the ocean as the little ones gathered their shells and we walked from one end to the only other way out and hiked back along the bluff from the parking lot (no sign posted)  the trail is surrounded by chrub.  It eventually goes along side a rail road track and we saw the train twice while hiking.  When we came back I saw people walking on the other side of the train track in a field which I thought was private property but I"m guessing where the trail head actually is.  Either way, both sides of the track is a nice hike.  It was empty when we went exploring the area. Saw some people hang gliding above us.   I loved the quietness and I only saw one jogger when I got to the train area.  The beach access itself is empty just a few joggers and at the parking lot entrance at the far end of the beach is where some people gathered but it's a nice quiet beach area over all.  Total distance we did was 6-7 miles.
Snowballs stuffed with cheesecake? Really? Okay. The kid loved it and wanted it again. My traditional spearmint was the way to go for me!! Delicious and plenty of choices!

The northside has a great, little place for nabbing some Korean! Don't be fooled by the biz name "I Love Salad". This hole-in-the-wall Korean cafe has plenty more to choose from than just leafy greens and veggies, including crossan'wiches, wraps, soups, classic Korean entreés, fro yo, and boba tea! That's a lot. I don't typically recommend restaurants that have an overly large menu because it indicates they're trying too many things and may not do any one thing particularly well. But, I Love Salad's Korean options were decent. Not to mention, when you see that the local Koreans are also fans (and it's not just hipster Caucasians that frequent a place), you know it's probably going to be a good one.

My hubby and his friends nabbed the bibimbap with beef, which is served steaming hot in the traditional stone pot. I tried a bit and it had good flavor and texture and a fair amount for a grown man to polish off. Their bibimbap is not quite as good as that which is served at a few of the other traditional Korean BBQ places on the eastside, but it will definitely hit the spot if you're in the area and have a taste for bulgogi. The bibimbap meal comes with a small bowl of miso soup. That was quite nice -- not too salty and contained a fair amount of tofu and scallions instead of just the broth.

I went for the bento box with salmon...mmmm...and it was tasty. They drizzled a lovely teriyaki BBQ on the fish and nestle it on top of some fresh greens. The fish portion was decent and not overcooked (I definitely used my finger to lap up the sauce haha.) The box also comes with a beautifully colorful side salad (complete with fresh strawberries, red bell peppers, and cukes...I love a nice, colorful salad), a hefty portion of rice, and four lightly pan fried dumplings. The dumplings were perfect! I dislike when dumplings are fried to oblivion and as a result overly tough in the skin. These didn't even need the soy sauce to dip in.

I would have liked to have nabbed me some boba tea or fro yo, but I filled up on the delicious rice and salmon. So, that just means another visit is in order. Perhaps then I can try some of their not-so-traditional / non-Korean menu items as well.

My advice to the business owner: you should consider tidying up your dining area (the many stacks of Korean magazines up by the window are unnecessary and make the space seem cluttered and overwhelming), and try to keep your food prep space that is visible to customers a little more organized. It sends a certain message to your customers about the cleanliness and preparedness of your restaurant.

I adore this market! As soon as you walk in, the bakery case is right there. It is bright and beautiful, and everything looks delicious. In addition to regular cakes, desserts and breads they have Latin ones which look amazing. There is tons of choice. As you keep walking, there is a hot food bar that looks and smells amazing. It is a bit overwhelming because the menu is set over the middle of the food, but if you just stand back and look for a minute you should be good to go. The produce section is next and it is beautiful. They have everything you find in a regular grocery, plus things I've only seen there. I love it! The isles are fun- again a mix of the usual and the imported/unusual. But my absolute favorite part is the meat counter. The meats are gorgeous and the prices are great. This is definitely a place to at least check out once if you have never been!

Those that know me well are quite aware of my low aptitude for beer. Sure I know my wines, but now, I'm thinking it's time to really understand beer. With the beer boom going on in the old pueblo, I don't tire of seeing more breweries hop on the scene, and Ten Fifty-Five Brewing is doing many things well! This small operation started out in a home kitchen and has wowed locals since it's debut in Tucson. They have four beers in constant rotation and plan to have six by November. And so far, so good! Actually, great! What I find especially great is the variety. They really make beer for many palates to enjoy. I typically steer away from IPAs, so lucky for me, the Lazy Duck (American Wheat) and Leap Pale Ale are light and crisp. The Leap Pale Ale is their flagship brew and in my humble opinion, a perfect beer for those that don't want a super hoppy beer. It's just the right amount! I tasted two other beers in my flight, which are not necessarily going to always be available in their rotation. The XOXO Coffee Stout (made with coffee beans from EXO Roasters) and the Pukka Bitter (British style Ale). I enjoyed both. They also make a double IPA, the Two Sons Citra, which was sold out. As mentioned earlier, this operation is quite small and carefully run by two owners, John Vyborny and Chris Squires. Both are super passionate about their craft and they're pouring some mad love into their nano-brews. Tasting hours are limited, so make sure to visit them Thursday and Friday 4pm-7pm and Saturday 2pm-7pm. They've recently expanded their space and now have more seating, a huge chalkboard menu and a tasting bar. Stop by and have flight! Meet the owners and have a chat. While small, it's cozy and welcoming and all beer drinkers-beginning or expert will be in a hoppy (pun intended) place upon first sip. Prices start at $2 for 6oz pours, growlers are $8. If you can't make it into the brewery for a visit, you can find their beer at several local restaurants including Playground, The Good Oak, La Cocina, Tap & Bottle, Zona 78 Hacienda del Sol, Pasco and Wilko. Cheers!

This is a decent carry out place that my office uses pretty regularly for work lunches.  The prices are inexpensive with the lunch specials being an especially good deal.  The portion sizes are generous: 8 pieces of crab rangoon in an order, a full cup of hot & sour soup as a lunch side, etc.  They always remember spicy mustard packets for me, too!  I don't know where the love is for spicy mustard, but you only get them now if requested at most places.  Delivery is quick, always right about the time they estimate.

The food itself is fairly average Chinese delivery.  The filling of the crab rangoon is a little sweet for me- not tender crab sweet, but leaning towards cheesecake sweet.  They have several flavors of egg roll that are tasty, if over-fried a bit like egg rolls sometimes can be.  Yummy steamed dumplings.  

For my meal, I order spicy entrees like kung pao beef and spicy chicken.  They are different every time time I get them, so not great consistency.  Some of my coworkers take understandable issue when an unexpected veggie or spice shows up in a dish where it typically is not used. To top the meal off, the brand of fortune cookies they use is delicious- sweet, crispy, and airy.  I usually can't even eat a fortune cookie, but I like to polish off a couple of these!

Went here again and the service and food were very good. We got the fries and mozz sticks. Came out very hot and tasted great. The pizza we got was half florentine and half veggie (minus the peppers) they were very good & the dough was ever so crispy and the crust was perfect. I loved it. And even reheated the next day it was awesome! Prices could be a tad cheaper though, that is the only draw back.

We enjoyed the foods here! Their spicy is actually pretty spicy - I got medium and it had a good kick. I love eating spicy foods so was pleasantly surprised that a medium would actually burn my mouth a bit. I ordered a pound of head on shrimp in the boil house sauce which is essentially all the seasonings/sauces, medium spicy. We also shared half a dozen of the char grilled oysters. Others had the mussels + shrimp no spice, shrimp po boy sandwich, salad, fettuccine noodles, fire brussels sprouts. Our waitress was friendly and attentive. The restaurant was empty when we arrived on a Sunday lunch but slowly started to fill up closer to 1pm. Still plenty of tables available. 

We got our foods within a decent amount of time. My pound of shrimp was pretty small - a pound of shrimp in the bay comes with much more shrimp... fortunately I wasn't too hungry and it was enough to fill me up. I think others would need double the portion to get full. The char grilled oysters came with cheesy/garlic toppings! It was really good and had the right amount of flavors. The shrimp seasoning was salty and tasty - I enjoyed the spice and sauces... especially the chunks of garlic. The fire brussels sprouts were crispy and delicious. It had a tiny kick of spice to it. Overall I enjoyed the seafood boil here and would definitely be back here if I'm in the area.

Love this place!

My girlfriend and I are both not very big fans of going to Jersey for ANY reason.  However, every 2 months or so, we'll cross the WW to restock our wine and beer supplies at Canal's.

The manager of the store is super friendly as well as the rest of the staff there.  It's pretty impressive that everyone knows exactly where specific wines can be found throughout the store.  There is a ton of a variety and they know where to find it, just ask!  Also, they usually give samples of different wines that are on sale.  

As for their craft beer selection, it is great as well and reasonably priced.  Yes, let me reiterate that in general their prices are extremely reasonable.  And, you can fill up on cheap gas while youre in NJ too!

Not sure about Mark P.'s review but I have had the exact opposite experience each time I've gone there.

I honestly can't say enough about Pauly's Bar Room, formerly Rick's Press Room, in downtown Meridian. When we were new in town, we were looking for those local hangouts, the neighborhood bars and Yelp gave Pauly's a great rating. From the first 5 minutes we were there, everyone was super welcoming. The bartenders and the patrons were chatty with us, which we love, the drinks were stiff and the beers were cold served in chilled glasses. Since that first visit, we have been back many times, on our way to becoming regulars. I have to say their daily and nightly food specials are amazing. They have some hard working talented cooks at Pauly's. We've had meatloaf, prime rib, tacos, then regular menu items like burgers and tots and such. Everything is good. I actually check their Facebook page regularly to see what the specials are. They have a Sunday Brunch which is pretty popular, although the regular menu isn't available until after brunch.. I do think food and drinks are fairly priced too. Overall, if you are looking for a friendly, local, not stuffy bar, check out Pauly's!

Expect to leave super stuffed! After a few people suggested we check out Palace of Asia, we decided to head over one night while we were craving Indian food. We arrived during dinnertime expecting it to be crowded but it was empty. Inside, the decor was very pretty. It was nicely decorated and had lovely fixtures and rugs. The servers aren't the friendliest out there, but they weren't rude either. 

We ordered garlic naan, chicken vindaloo and chicken tikka masala. The two entrees came with a side of rice. Everything was absolutely delicious and the portions were huge. The quality of the food here is phenomenal and we were incredibly full after we left. Everyone I know who has come here commented about how full they left. Come on an empty stomach and enjoy!

Mid century modern diner in blue and white, just east of downtown. Hipster staff and locally sourced upscale casual fare. Eclectic cocktail menu  with a good selection of wine and craft brew. Open 7 days a week from 7am to 2am. Serves food til 2:00am. That's special for Tucson. Face it, Tucson is an older town and most of the folks hit the early bird special and are tucked in by 9:00pm. So being able to get food late from other than a chain or fast food joint is special. We shared the Mac N Cheese with Andouille for an apply  and got the Jambalaya and No Way Jose burger, also ordered a side of Brussels Sprouts for our entrees. All delish. In addition to the menu items, there are daily drink and food specials; and a Happy Hour. Awesome! We want to try this place for breakfast. Love the vibe, love the food. This place is special.

I liked it. I love the smell of fresh baked bread and all the cute various signs. I've never had a sandwich with sprouts and I have to say I don't like it. i was kind of disappointed they did not offer any kind of chicken sandwich even subways and quiznos offers that.

Service wasnt great the girl at the counter looked like she didnt want to be there and i could barely hear a word she said when i asked her questions.All in all pretty affordable for the amount of food you get

Next time I wanna try a sandwich with 7 grain bread plain with just cheese and meat.

I moved to the neighborhood almost 3 months ago and have spent a lot of time visiting either Home Depot or this store. I was giddy to come across this Ace which is a fantastic alternative to HD or Lowes. I am there so often they always recognize me. All of the employees are helpful whenever I needed something or had questions. I have gone there to buy plants, seeds, brackets, drill bits, nails/screws, soil, planters, bug spray, you name it. I love walking by the store to take a look at the latest plants. I find the cost of plants is comparable to Home Depot. One of the ladies that works there is always so helpful helping me choose which plants are suited for the weather, shade, etc. One day, since I was buying a bunch of plants, she sweetly gave one of the clearance small plants to my daughter and explained how to take care of it. Another day, when my daughter was with me, another woman cashing us out gave my daughter a coloring book. Very thoughtful. 

There are some things that you can definitely get cheaper elsewhere (this was true when I was pricing ladders), but for the most part, the prices are comparable and oh so convenient for those of who live in the neighborhood. You can't beat it.

I have been craving for really good South Indian food . As soon as I moved to Indianapolis, I looked for the restaurants in the evening and this was the only place which offer dinner buffet. I dropped in this place for dinner with my friend and needless to say, the restaurant was smelling all curry and I loved the aroma. They were still setting up the dishes for the dinner buffet but they told us to grab the plates and hog on! We were like Hell Yeah !! Let's do it !

The items on the buffet were great. I think it was a huge spread but it's quite common if you drop into an Indian restaurant for buffet. There was two kinds of soup - chicken soup and tomato soup which I didn't try. I always recommend people to stay away from soups at Indian restaurants. Moving on.. There was my favorite South Indian food - Vada [ pro tip: they look like small donuts but they are not sweet] , and they were awesome, I had almost 10 of them. There were four kinds of chutneys, every chutney was perfect. They had delicious sambar too.  [pro tip : you generally have Vada's with chutney and sambar. Especially coconut chutney] They had Potato fry [aloo fry], egg plant curry, panner makhani [paneer butter masala], veg Manchurian and couple more vegetarian dishes. They all were fantastic.

Coming to the non- vegetarian section, they have chicken makhani [chicken butter masala], lamb curry, tandoori chicken, chicken dum biryani. I didn't try the lamb curry but the chicken dum biryani was great. [pro tip: add some chicken makhani to your chicken biryani rice and have it, it's so yummy]. The tandoori chicken was not so great. I don't understand why several Indian restaurants get this dish wrong. They add plenty of food color which spoils the taste of the dish and make it look red and dark pink in color. It's ridiculous. Please get this right!! 

They had carrot halwa, couple of ice creams and fresh cut fruits in the desserts section. 

They serve any kind of naan and roti and Dosa's at your table if you tell the server. [pro tip: Dosa is a South Indian dish and they look little like pan cakes and some people even refer them as Indian pan cakes. And again they are not sweet like pan cakes. You eat them with chutneys and sambar or with potato curry ] 

I really had a very good time having the food at this place. I do recommend this restaurant. I will definitely go there again.

Oh look it's 5 years later  and it's time for an update. The owner has transitioned from father to son in the last few years, so there have actually been some changes at this venerable restaurant. The dining room looks the same, only spruced up...same for the bar. The menu has some different items on it and some of them are actually healthy. I know it's a shock.

I recently enjoyed a Tales of the Cocktail lunch at Tujague's. It was 3 courses and a Sazerac for around $25. And it was delicious. I had a lovely salad, a beautiful piece of fish and then bread pudding, of course. Oh and I almost ate an entire loaf of french bread by myself because it was warm and tasty.

The staff was great and even let me charge my phone near their station (no plugs in the antique dining room). I'm glad to see them still going strong.

I am giving them 4 stars (rather than maybe a more reasonable 3) strictly because they seemed to handle the sudden crowd from the  UYE very well and they deserve credit for that.  That may make little difference when you walk in, then maybe it's just your normal Chinese food place but there you go.  I did order the St. Paul sandwich, something I had been looking forward to since I clicked I'm in.  It had been years since I had my first and only one and while I remember it being just a blob of a sandwich, it was a good memory.  I loved this one ... messy, the mayo, pickles, all falling apart, filled the right spot that night.  I also ordered the pot stickers that were pretty good.  It seems like most others liked there food but I also have rarely been to any similar place that stands out.  Not worth a special trip but if you are nearby, why not.

I must have walked by this place a dozen or so times when I used to work in center city.  Didn't think much of it.  Was just introduced to it this past weekend and loved it.  Cheap beer and cheap food.  They had $3.75 for 23oz domestic drafts all night, I think.  I got the Oscar burger which was a standard hockey puck with cheese, lettuce and tomato for five bucks and change.  They got some tvs, a little bit of space and a touch tunes. What more do you want.

If you're looking for an awesome dive bar in Philly, this is it.

So happy with this place. I had to find a new nail tech recently as mine has moved away, and I felt like such a dweeb for never noticing this place across from The Fashion Mall. I love it! I only get my acrylics done here now and might I add, for an extremely reasonable price. The facility itself is very clean, they have a really nice selection of polishes and services, and my nails are beautiful every time. For those people who are anal about finger nail polish and symmetry: this place has it on point for the most part. Really thankful to have found this lil gem. Highly recommend. The service providers are always very sweet however the end result of your nail service can be, every so often, a little off. I think that could just be with acrylics though, since a lot of people don't do them anymore it seems. Hasn't hindered my desire to return, but my advice is ask for whomever makes you happiest if you're recurring! And mind you, this is barely worth mentioning but a possibility.

They have several pop-up restaurants through out the week.  My favorite being Pirate pizza Friday and apparently Saturday's too now.

But besides the pizza, I really like this place.  Its got a neighborhood bar kinda feel without the creepiness of a dive bar. Its the modern day Cheers basically...and who doesn't love Cheers? 

The layout is a little odd but the space is what it is.  Its a long narrow bar with small tables against the wall and a row of tables beside the bar which are only for overflow. Every time I've sat there, the poker players arrive and I'm suddenly in their way.  There is also a room in the back with a pool table.  I've honestly never been back there.  Maybe on a busy weekend people might use it.  The jukebox has tons of classics.  Usually a familiar tune playing when you're sippin' on your drink.   

The same bartender is always there when I go in on various days of the week.  I like seeing the same face. She makes great recommendations like the Pear Martini which is now my go-to drink and shes the happiest person I've ever seen working.  So nice and always smiling.  Love her! 

Although its not a fancy cocktail lounge, they happen to make some great mixed drinks.

-1star for the smoking, although they have filters which help keep the smoke to a minimum, you still leave smelling like an ashtray.

It's a typical asian resto that every americans love. I don't think my chinese friend will even try it here, basically because their food is not authentic and more of a western taste in it, i.e. Sweet. I tried their soup, which is not in their menu and it's acceptable. I'd come back here for the soup and not their main entre.

So chipotle is so amazing! I feel like everytime I think about going, gods killing kittens! Why? This addiction is evil!! Lol. Anyhow I love this place for all their organic meats, the chicken is amazing, the Barbados is even better, what mood will I be in next week when the carnitas is going to end up in my burro?

Decor is awesome, the place is well laid out, and they always have some good tunes playing. 

You ready for the bad part?
Ok, so my only gripe, is how these bastards don't mind a HUGE spoon of rice and beans but then they go in with the tongs and shake out half the meat!! WTF! don't skimp on the best part! 

P.S. I always tell them to add my sauce to a cup on the side!! And I slather my burro in it as I eat! Get the hot, it's insane good.

Nuff said.... K bye!

I grew up working here so I am a little skewed with my review but bottom line, this is a family-run bakery and you feel good above all else that you are supporting a local business. 

The sticky buns are glorious. I love mine with nuts and raisins. Get there early while they are still nice and warm and the store gals will cut you off a trio. 

Their powdered cream donuts are arguably the best ever. Don't believe me? Try for yourself. 

For the more adult palette, try the almond horns dipped in chocolate at the tips. Chewy, dense almond flavor. Mmm. 

Also an early sell-out every day are the boxes of mini Danish...what better way to sample all the flavors?

Lastly, birthday cakes are stocked in case and also made to order. I say go with the pound cake and vanilla buttercream icing. Their classic combo and, in my opinion, what they do best. 

Around the holidays, lines are out the door, so be patient, embrace the festive chaos and give a big smile to the girl covered in powdered sugar behind the counter...chances are she has been up since 3 AM boxing YOUR cream puffs. :)

Good lord I love Han Dynasty. I have been here for dinner a few times, but my most recent trip for lunch was my best yet. I went with a friend as part of our 'ladies who lunch' series, and we had an incredible time. We each startred with a beer (surprisingly good draft list for an Asian restaurant) and split the dumplings in chili oil. Although I'm not usually a pork fan, the chili oil was too good to pass up, and the dumplings disappeared in a matter of moments! We also had a hilarious struggle eating the dumplings with our chopsticks, much to the amusement of our waitress (who was awesome). 

For entrees, I had the dry pepper style with chicken (adding extra veggies for no upcharge), and my friend had the double cooked style pork. I didn't get a chance to try hers, but mine was so good! Not too much sauce, the heat level was perfect (per the recommendation of our server), and everything cooked beautifully. I actually could not have asked for a better lunch.

In the past I've had the dry pot style with chicken, as well as the spicy cucumbers, and both were also amazing. Needless to say, I haven't had a bad meal here!

As a side note, our server was Minjung, and she was probably one of the best servers I've ever had in my life (no joke) - friendly, attentive (but not overly so), and made sure we had a great experience.

For a first time, Sisters was AMAZING!  The decor and the lighting really set the mood, and everyone from the door staff to the bartenders to the coat check attendant were very friendly.  They do have a $5 cover, but it does end up being worth it.  I love that they don't make you pay extra to go on the dance floor.  The DJ happened to be spinning boy band/girl group music which made the experience all the more fun, and what's more, I enjoyed a custom mixed cocktail, ran into a few friends, and danced like I'd never danced before.  I will FOR SURE be back for one of their parties, hopefully their upcoming 90's party!

My husband and I passed by Ole Red right before it opened at 11 and decided to wait with the handful of others at the door to get in for lunch. 

We decided to sit at the bar since it was only the 2 of us. The bartender was very nice and took her time to explain the menu offerings. We really liked that most of their food, sauces etc are made in house. 

We both started with a beer (love the local beer offerings!) The one thing I didn't quite get was that the beer was served in a plastic cup. I get why they'd do that after hours once a rowdier crowd comes in, but not in the early afternoon. 

We both split the nachos and they were SOOOO GOOD!! Like I'm not even kidding. From the chicken, to the BBQ sauce and everything in between, I highly recommend the nachos!! It was plenty for 2 people and honestly we couldn't even finish it between us. YUM!!!

The interior of Ole Red is definitely a step above the rest. The stage was awesome and they had a bluegrass band playing the whole time. There are multiple levels and a rooftop bar, but unfortunately the rooftop was closed when we were there so we didn't get to see it.

The service was fine, even though she was the only server working and had 2 large tables (including a party of 20) to take care of as well. She did as well as she could.

I was not pleased with my steak at all. I didn't mention it since it seemed like it was a rough night for the staff and I didn't want to make it worse for them. (Having worked in a restaurant for 8 years prior to my current job at a bank, I am extra considerate of the service industry.)

The steak was one of the worst I've had and I will probably never get it again. It tasted strange (like it may have been past date), it had some dryness and toughness to it (a ribeye should be juicy), and it could have been seasoned better. The baked potato that came it was fine.

My wife got the grilled chicken breast with mixed veggies, the portion was nice, but the chicken was over seasoned and had a little spiciness to it.

We got the stuffed artichoke appetizer which we love and have never been disappointed with it.

We will go back to this place because we generally have had good experiences there in the past, but I'm not getting the steak again. I'll stick with their other dishes, I've had better luck with their daily specials.

This 2 star review is only based on tonight's visit. Averaged in with all the other times we've been there in the past, I'd probably give it 3.5 to 4 stars. I will adjust my rating after my next visit.

What a great little neighborhood hangout! Smack dab in the middle of Maryland Farms, it's not an incredibly visible location. But they do steady business with an extensive menu of American classics, way better than your typical sports bar!

I'm a sucker for fried pickles and these pass the test! The fried oysters are also fantastic and extraordinarily fresh! The wings are pretty good, but I felt like the lemon pepper flavor was a bit overwhelming and salty. Good quality chicken though. The fries are nearly perfect!

The house-made ranch and bleu cheese dressings that accompanied the wings, fried pickles, and chicken strips were very, very, very good!!! I love it when a restaurant offers a great house-made ranch (shout out to McDougal's in Hillsboro Village) and Jefferson's does it very well!

The only thing I would change is the batter for the fried pickles and the oysters. I love the fact that it's light rather than heavy, but it wasn't quite crispy enough. Almost soggy but not quite. Otherwise, Jefferson's is definitely a place that has earned my business.

I had a sushi burrito and I loved it! I was a little nervous. Would the seaweed wrap be chewy? Would it stay together? Would the flavors work? The sushi burrito anxiety was real and it took me awhile to try it. If you feel like this, don't worry. It is not that scary. 

The Spot is combined with Ha Long Bay. You can actually order Pho with your sushi burrito! Anyway, if you walk into "The Spot" side of the restaurant, you will see that you order your burrito like you would a certain fast food Mexican burrito.

First you pick burrito, bowl or salad. Then you pick your protein. You can pick two or three for a higher price. Then you pick sauce, veggies, and toppings. Then you watch your beauty be wrapped into a burrito. 

I ordered a burrito with salmon and tempura shrimp (I highly recommend both). I then asked about the sauce and was recommended the spicy sauce since I am a heat fiend. I added cucumber, carrots, and jalapenos. I then added sesame seeds and little crunch wontons for texture. 

Some of the things that you could also add that I remember were tuna, corn, cilantro, red onion, avocado (upcharge), asparagus (upcharge). There were a lot of other choices too, but that is what I can recall.  

I grabbed a drink, a container of soy and lots of napkins (note: grab extra! Burritos are a little messy if you are like me and dip in soy).

The first bite was magical. It was super fresh, delicious, salty and crunchy all at once. Each subsequent bite just reinforced my joy. I polished it off and left very happy. I will definitely return soon. It is a little pricey, but I think that it is worth it. You have to try a sushi burrito if you are a sushi fan. You will love it!

The Cafe Beignet On Bourbon has some kind of live music playing most
Of the day. 
You can sit in the courtyard area or up in the balcony. There is also some covered seating areas. 

When you arrive you go to the register and order. They have 3 beignets for 3.99 and some other breakfast items and many choices for lunch. 

Once you order and pay then you take a number and find a table. Once your order is ready they will locate you by the number. Remember to get your napkins before you sit so you don't have to leave your warm beignets to grab a napkin. YES you will need several. 

If you enjoy the music remember to tip them. Usually there is a tip bucket out by the musicians. 

There are two other Café Beignets nearby but Bourbon is my favorite because of the ongoing music.  The Royal street location also has Music but later in the afternoon. 

#lovejazzmusic

I travel for work, and spent a week here earlier this month.  It was such a great experience that when I returned to work in the area again this was the only hotel I considered staying in. Excellent location, wonderful staff, very nice breakfast and extras like social mixers in the evening with appetizers and snacks. And my room was absolutely perfect!
 
The kitchen was well-equipped, and had a full size refrigerator which was perfect for storing the food and drinks that I needed for the week.   I like to cook in my room so that i don't have to eat out all the time. All the cooking equipment I needed was there, silverware, and a complete set of dishes.  Even a dishwasher!

The sitting area was comfortable, and I appreciated that I could swivel the tv so that it could be seen from either the bed or sitting area. Workspace was excellent, and I LOVED actually having enough electric outlets to plug in my phone, laptop, ipad, and camera all at the same time. The outlets were conveniently located within easy reach so that I didn't have to crawl on the floor to plug things in.  Often when I travel I have to unplug a light or alarm clock and crawl behind the bed to find an outlet.  Not the case here! 

The bed was super comfortable, and the lighting on both sides of the bed was very nice. The lighting in the entire suite was perfect: lights in in kitchen, desk area, sitting area, reading lights near the bed.  The bathroom was very nice and the shower was super!! Probably the best shower I have ever had in any hotel, even hotels with a much higher price point. 

I also liked the large windows that let in natural light. The windows open too, so you can experience some fresh air if you like.

The breakfast was very nice, really good scrambled eggs, fresh fruit, baked items, Greek yogurt, and many other offerings. I was able to make a great breakfast burrito with tortilla, eggs, cheese, salsa and hot sauce.

The evening social mixers offered appetizers, snacks, beverages, and sandwiches, plus there is a bar.  The seating area is plentiful with tables of different sizes and some community type seating.  Very comfortable and a good excuse to get out of the room and away from working at night.

Breakfast staff and housekeeping staff are excellent!

This is our new favorite grocery store. The prices are decent, and the selection is absolutely insane -- especially where it counts, which, for me, is the produce section. It's annoying as hell for me to drive all the way through West Philly from the Spring Garden District, but it's worth it, since I can't find what I need, affordably, anywhere else closer. I also love the fact that they discount your gas if you have a club card, and once you build up enough points, you can get a ton of money off per gallon. Their gas prices seem to be cheaper than elsewhere anyway, so you can't lose!

This is one of the best Vietnamese restaurants in Indy. It is one of a handful on Lafayette Road, but this is the best in my opinion. 
Please do not go here and get Chinese food, it is good, but you can pretty much get the same thing anywhere else. Most of the Vietnamese food that I have had is very good. 
My favorite is the spicy beef noodle soup called Bom Bu Hue. All of the fish dishes are tremendous too, very flavorful. Get the shrimp rolls as an appetizer you will not be disappointed. The Pho, which is the traditional vietnamese dish, is good, but I have had better but it is definitely worth a try.
It is a small cozy little restaurant with usually just one server, but works hard and is very friendly.
So go try something new, you will love it.

Delicious! It's a small take-out place with a few tables. I had the palak paneer and samosa chaat. The palak paneer was just creamy enough. I think the preparation of this dish by many other places in Delaware is a bit mediocre - usually too dry. I loved the flavor and texture of the dish from this place. The samosa chaat was filling and flavorful. Highly recommended!

This place is def off the beat and path...but it's worth the walk or find.  

Great atmosphere, very good service on a very, very quiet night.  

There were 9 of us and were quickly seated and offered drinks.  The apps were very good, we especially liked the mini calzones and Bruschetta Crostini.

Pizza ordered were all hand-tossed.  Enjoyed the portabella pizza, Hawaiian and meat lovers.  One member of the party ordered rosemary mac and cheese and said it was amazing.  

Overall a very good experience at a wonderful little pub!

We arrived late after driving through heavy rain and storms. When we came the front desk woman was very friendly and asked us how our trip was. We had a quick check in as I had already done it on the app and we were placed on the SPG member floor which was very quiet and I loved the fact the ice machine was located one floor below. The room was spacious and clean with a jacuzzi tub we didn't use based on all of our travels visiting family and friends. The bed was very soft but supporting, the only down side was only 4 pillows for two of us. One down side was no hairdryer for her. The television gets directv which is a plus because that is what I have but also a down side because I can't watch the Phillies. Our room was refreshed to perfect condition upon our return Saturday. I would definitely stay here again it's quiet and comfortable. I'll try the restaurant next time also

What a wonderful novel addition to the crowded Philly sandwich scene!  Nick Filet on Lancaster Avenue in Paoli serves up genuine Filet Mignon sandwiches - yeah you read that right - Filet Mignon sandwiches!  These tasty creations can also have many toppings and I chose crumbled bleu cheese, cooked onions mushrooms & peppers, and the Nick Filet Sauce. The Nick Filet Sauce is a flavorful mixture of Worcestershire, mustard, and mayo.  And amazingly all this came in under ten dollars!  

Now for a side note - Everyone knows Philly's beloved Super Bowl winning quarterback Nick Foles so I had to go here before the big Eagles playoff game this Sunday versus the Saints. Well of course there's the Nick sandwich, then there's the Big Nick sandwich, and finally there is the gigantic Mount Saint Nick.  (If you eat the latter, you'll be on their Wall of Fame!)  Well all these names were devised without thinking of Nick Foles but it's an amazing coincidence - no? 

Anyway, Nick Filet is worthy of a destination to Paoli ... and maybe even St. Nick Foles will eat here sometime!

Okay, so we all know this is my go-to restaurant for any meal of the day. If I can't come up with somewhere new, I go here. The food is always the best. Simple, hearty, tasty, hot, and ready for me to eat. Also, generous. So I am making this a four star update because I love it so, but I received some NO STAR service recently. For the first time ever!

I was made to feel like I was a pest - you know the feeling. OKAY - I am a customer in a nearly empty restaurant! At the end of this transaction, a tip will be left that will comprise a fraction of your pay! Alienating me is not doing anyone any favors! I just put in an 8+ hour day at my job, now you are at your job. This is the way of the world. It's fair to dislike your job, or to be tired, bored, or just in a bad mood, but it's unprofessional to take it out on an unassuming customer.

My final request was for little cups with lids to go with my to-go box (gotta get that gravy to-go). Last time I ate here, the server was super friendly and basically made it rain little cups before I could even ask for one.  I didn't think my request for a little cup this time was going to be a problem. So I asked for one and I was met with total blankness. No verbal response whatsoever, just a look that I read as "GFY". I got my cups, I felt like ass about asking in the first place. 

In the end, Mike tipped generously, per usual, but only because it's Honey's. You can't tip bad here on principle alone.

We all really enjoyed Pho Street. We didn't plan our visit, but were happy to have happened about this place. It's casual with plenty of seating and you can order at a kiosk, which is much appreciated.

I did a quick scan of the reviews to know not to order the pho. I ordered the grilled pork vermicelli bowl (bun thit nuong with cha gio), my sister had the Vietnamese hoagie (banh mi thit nuong), and my brother-in-law ordered the broken rice (com tam) with a cha gio side. Everything was excellent. The pork was super flavorful and there were tons of fresh vegetables and herbs in my bun. My sister said the bread on her banh mi was great. And my BIL loved his perfectly cooked and delicious com tam. We all appreciated the crispness of the cha gio. Even my baby niece enjoyed the vegetables we gave her. I love that they have a house-made fish sauce, which add depth to everything.

I'd stop here again if craving Vietnamese in Center City.

Never realized that this place existed until I got on Yelp to find a place for a meetup for a friend in the city, but man is this place as good as it gets! Come here for the chaats ... they are beyond delicious. Love how the owner asks for your preferences before making it (attentive much?). In general, the chaats are blended together wonderfully. Never had I had so many flavors going through my mouth at once ... savory of the carbs, tangy of the fruit/mango, sweet of some Pakistani ethnic fruit, etc. etc. In short, it resulted in one very happy mouth at the end of the day.
You can't go wrong with the lassis either, though I would go for the mango one. Light on sugar and definitely light on the conscience vs. frozen yogurt or ice cream (in terms of calories).
However, I think the one thing that really impressed me was the customer service ... he won't let me pay him unless I found the food satisfying. Not only that ... he also ended up giving us two desserts (rice pudding and carrot something) for free and refused to let us pay for them. Both of the desserts were delicious ... rice pudding was perfect as the rice helped to moderate the sugar content of the dessert and as for the other, I found the carrot dessert excessively sweet even for a sweet tooth like me. Nonetheless, I will definitely return down the line.

Their staple-donuts are absolutely delicious. It's hard to not love a donut covered in bacon. Or in salted caramel. Or a blueberry cheesecake donut. 
Both the conception of the more strange flavored donuts as well as the integrity of all of their offerings are clearly of great quality. I think that if you line up a glazed donut from strange, and one from a chain grocery store side by side, there is an obvious difference in which one tastes better. 
That being said, you have to expect to pay a little more for the donuts from strange. It's like opting for craft beer over domestic. Or artisanal cheese over kraft singles. You pay for the quality.  I don't find myself eating donuts that often, but if everytime i were in the mood for one Strange Donuts was my go-to shop? I would be very content with that.

Sushi Wasabi is a little gem in a stripmall near Southgate Mall (behind the Petro-Canada). It's quite small and busy all the time - reservations definitely recommended. 

We only sampled sashimi and maki. Their menu is very traditional, which is nice - don't expect any of those weird cream cheese rolls. The rice in the maki is perfect - lovely grains that are not mushy, and stick together nicely. My favourites are the spicy tuna, spicy octopus, tuna with green onion, and unagi. Simple, and showcases the quality of ingredients. Strangely, they don't have any spicy salmon or regular salmon rolls? However they do have salmon sashimi which is just phenomenal - they use high quality fish that is very fresh and actually tastes the way it should (in contrast to some places where the fish looks good but tastes like nothing). You can also order sashimi by the piece - basically anything they offer as nigiri, you can also get as sashimi. The one nigiri I did order was chop chop - I love the scallop - this one had roe mixed into the mayo which was neat. Unfortunately I found that there was too much mayo - too saucy for my liking.

For takeout, you have to order from their little paper menu (see Kris B.'s photos). I didn't compare it to their regular menu but I am pretty sure it is pared down. They have take-out specials that are mostly nigiri/simple maki combos (substitutions accepted for a fee).

It's not cheap, but I'd definitely come back to try some other items like black cod (and eat more sashimi). I would be here all the time if it was closer to me!
Note: don't expect great things for white wine - they only had two options but were out of the better one. Better to stick with beer :)
