Lord, this review is overdue - this is what happens when you plan your own wedding :( Anyway, thankfully I always take notes (dork), so despite the fact that my review is from warmer times I can say that Kermit's Bakeshop produces tasty treats that are primarily fun, and all in a very surprising location on Washington Ave. I live about 15 minutes away and not long after they opened I walked over with the explicit purpose of picking up a bunch of goods for us to try together. The place is really just take-out, although there is a small bar on the side. The one staffer at the counter was super nice and patient, and amused when I told him our plan to 'taste test' their baked goods that evening. He answered the few questions I had as I went along both cases, and packaged up everything in boxes so that nothing would get accidentally destroyed. I lugged my big order back to our apartment and later on we all had fun taking bites and commenting on each:

Hamburglar (no longer on the menu?): a soft vanilla cake bun with sesame seeds, creamy "patty" that tasted like thick fudgy milk chocolate with chocolate sauce and coconut flakes "lettuce", and raspberry sauce "ketchup" - its like getting a vanilla cupcake with chocolate fudge frosting,  sweetened coconut flakes and a raspberry jelly filling. Mostly just fun, but pretty tasty too.
Ballpark Frank (not sure if also still available): my husband's favorite treat, its a red velvet hotdog with I believe a white chocolate cream, pistachio "relish" all in a choux pastry bun. The pink frosting was off putting at first, but the first bite revealed the yummy, sweet flavors for a slight variation on the classic red velvet cake
Banana Bread: this slice of quick bread was solid overall - moist, not too dense, a good banana flavor, and a sweet basic icing glaze on top with chopped walnuts
Chocolate chip cookie: large chunks of semisweet chocolate in a shortbread like cookie base, this cookie was kind of dry and compact, not a hit with anyone
Oreo Marshmallow: this was a damn fine glob of homemade fluff about the size of my palm - it was a special treat that day
Kermit Hole: this cookie was simple and therefore perfect - thin shortbread cookies sandwiched a thin nutella layer with a cocoa-sugar dusting. The light nutella flavor with the buttery shortbread was the perfect amount for balanced flavors
Pistachio tea cake: Delicious! Moist and sweet, though the pistachio flavor was subtle, with the top crust dusted with confectioner's sugar
Finger 32 (again, no longer on the menu): this pastry was a roll with sweet, thin, moist cake layers with a cream filling, white chocolate ganache frosting, mini marshmallows and gold painted walnut pieces, and a thin shortbread-biscuit vanilla cookie bottom. The guy had said the words 'sweet potato,' which may have been in the filling. This was my favorite, and very pretty
Smores: their version was rectangular with a thin marshmallow bottom dipped in chocolate with graham cracker crumbs dusted on top, and a graham cracker piece stabbing center. Good, but truth be told, homemade smores are the best 
Chocolate Marshmallow Pop Tart: chocolate filling inside a flaky pop tart pastry dough and a basic chocolate icing glaze topped with a cookie crumble and mini marshmallows that were lightly torched. It was good not great, but if you like pop tarts then this is probably your type of treat - I actually didn't grow up with pop tarts, freak that I am
Hippie dippie whoo-pie: I wanted to like this, but it needed improvement. The cake was thin but dense, and moist like pound cake. The cream filling was a sweet cream with fruity pebbles within it. 
There's something about the fruity pebbles flavor, and I realized that you have to love the cereal to like this whoopie pie. 

All in all, it was a super fun, sugar-filled evening that we all greatly enjoyed. I would go back, and actually would like to try their savory items, but it's kind of out of my way to get to...and one reason why I haven't had a chance to go back. Once I get a free day on the weekend, though, all bets are off - or perhaps I should get delivery since they oh so conveniently offer it...

Tried this restaurant & it is amazing! The environment inside the restaurant is clean and contemporary. We ordered a few lunch specials, D&B Roll & Wasabi Lobster Roll. The special rolls are amazing with so many ingredients in each bite. Visually, the chefs craft the special rolls so beautifully that a picture can not even do justice. Overall, the experience including food & service was outstanding. Would highly recommend to any sushi lovers!

25 cents for a 20 ounce drink (yes, coffee included) the day after the Cards have a game with 6 runs!  That's how I got into this place.  My parents are very "thrifty" and sent us pronto the next morning to pick up beverages.

This is a very clean location and I live in Chicagoland, so I love that the gas is 30 cents less a gallon here!

The location is handy, not too far from 64 and of course, my parent's house.  Be prepared to wait a bit on the drink discount days, but not too long.  They are pretty speedy at getting you in and out.

To begin - must get their chips & salsa.  The yellow salsa is the best. I could have 3 of those! If you love spicy - you will love this salsa. The guac is delicious but the serving size is small. Too small. 

For entrees - the chicken enchilada were just ok. I would go with the tacos! Their shrimp tacos were fabulous. And do not turn down the opportunity to get the pot roast tacos. They are sooooo good!!!! I know they sound gross. But really - so good. 

Their house margs are definitely not my favorite. Bakersfield still holds the crown. They do have a great grapefruit marg. Try this. Unless you like sweet margaritas and the traditional may be for you.

I LOVE PWAT! I've been here 6 times and have 6 awesome paintings to show for it. I'm not terribly artistic but they break the paintings down into easy steps and walk you through each one. Apparently they even have a time when you can come in to work on fixing any mistakes you feel that you've made.

They also have a punch card so you can get a free painting class after you fill the card. And if you check-in on Facebook while you're there, they'll give you 2 punches. So that's basically 1 free class after you take 5 classes. AND they gave my friend and I our own aprons when we turned in our punch card for our free class. Did I mention how much I love this place?

I recently found myself in downtown St. Pete with a friend looking for some place to get a drink and food. I pulled up yelp and found this place. The reviews look good so we decided to try it. It was Thursday night around 9:00pm and a slightly chilly night so plenty of empty tables outside so figured we would have no wait. The hostess told us that they had calls out to other customers waiting for those tables and had to give them 15 minutes to show up. The thing is those customers put their names in an hour ago, don't think they are coming. So it was very frustrating we had to stand around waiting for 15 minutes when there were 5+ empty tables. This place would of been 4 stars otherwise. 

Now onto the drinks and food. We were trying to decide between two bottles of wine and the waitress kindly brought us out a taste of both. We went with Domain Gayda- 'Flying Solo' Grenache Blanc-Viognier and it was pretty reasonable in price at $36 for the bottle. 

Then we decided to share a few appetizers. We got the BRIE & CONFIT CROQUETTES, LOCAL SQUASH BRUSCHETTA and CRISPY PUMPKIN GNOCCHI. The LOVED the gnocchi. You could tell it was made fresh and the flavor was delicious. The Leek Hay on the bruschetta was different but tasty. The croquettes were good, though I think if the cheese was on the inside instead of on top it might of been better. 

And dessert was the real star of the night! We shared the chocolate tart. Our slice had to be at least 6 inches tall! And it had house made brittle on top. It was simply amazing!

Get the ice cream!!! True this is a pizza shoppe, but don't forget the ice cream!!

I had the Chopped Salad (frisee, onions, green beans, and chickpeas), and loved it. I love all the textures of the salad, the dressing wasn't overpowering, and the ingredients were fresh. We tried the Melanzana Pizza (with eggplant!) and the classic Margherita. Both were done well, and I especially enjoyed the Melanzana. The pizzas were delicious, light and fluffy.

Little did I know that Pizzeria Vetri has an awesome custard machine. The Soft Serve Ice Cream was probably the highlight of the meal- awesome creaminess and flavor. Leave room for dessert!

Thank you Danielle for doing my set!! I love these and as a first time customer, I think that this is my new salon. Danielle is great at attention to detail and I didn't even have a wait time. I showed her a picture of what I wanted and she delivered. I will definitely be back. The place was clean and they take their time and do it right. Also Lani did my pedicure and it was so relaxing. She also did my eyebrows which came out very nice. See you soon!

Baseline: Reviewed during 2013 summer Devour Downtown 

Who: Me, my wife, our neighbors (married couple) 

Devour Menu: Craft cocktail + 3 courses for $25/person

Food ordered & Food Review: 
-Heirloom Tomato and Mozzarella Salad: very testy and easily can be shared
-Trio of Hummus: each hummus had its own flavor and texture. The traditional was good. The red pepper was very salty, which I prefer, but be warned. The edamame was weird, but then again that isn't really hummus. This could also easily be shared as an appetizer. 

I forgot to take photos of the apps, but the pita comes out in a small fryer basket, which is a fun presentation. 

Second Course & Food Review:
The portions are extremely small, as in Tapas size. They do not come with a side, and Plat doesn't offer any sides. 
-Pork Belly Slider: 2 small sliders, but the flavor was good and the combination of toppings worked well. 
-Artisanal Grilled Cheese: I don't care for cheese that much, or at least I don't love it like most people. But, I really don't care for pork belly or duck pate. so I ordered the grilled cheese. It was delicious and gourmet. Highly recommended. 

Third Course & Food Review:
-Milk and Cookies: this isn't really milk and cookies. like, at all. they soak fresh chocolate chip cookies in cream, strain it, then use the cream to make a panna cotta. Cookies and milk, no. Delicious, yes. 

Craft Cocktails ordered & Review:
-A Grassy Knoll (lemongrass-infused indiana vodka, cocchi americano, zoning prosecco, cucumber, celery shrub, house orgeat): this was OK. it was extremely strong, but it normally cost $13 and you get maybe 5 oz of cocktail once you remove the giant ice cube. But, they do make the vodka in house at Plat 99, so they get bonus points for that. 

-A Sticky Situation (bone snapper rye, clement creole shrub, shagbark hickory syrup, peaches, lemon, hickory foam, bacon): yes, this drink has a piece of bacon in it. You must like whipped egg whites to enjoy this drink, as that is basically what the foam is. 

-Fog Cutter (oronoco rum, le reviseur v.s. cognac, prohibition indiana gin, orange, lemon, house orgeat, cherry-infused pisco): basically this is a fresh, extremely sweet long island iced tea. My wife loves long island iced teas, but she just though this was OK. 

I love that they don't rush you. Not at all. We sat at the restaurant for at least 90 minutes, and the courses were ordered individually and spaced out, not rushed. However, we also did NOT receive the popcorn that several reviews talk about, even though I saw several other tables enjoying a bag. I'm sad about the popcorn, but combining that factor with our "no rush" service makes me question if we just had a slow/bad waitress. 

I would go back, but I would probably sit on the patio/deck which overlooks south street and enjoy an appetizer and a craft beer (of which they have plenty on tap for $5.50 a pint). Maybe I'm not into the new mixology hipster trend, but give me a beer over a gourmet cocktail any day.

First night in Nashville my friend and I were looking for a dinner restaurant  that was close to the hotel we were at and fancy-ish as we wanted to be able to get a bottle of wine to celebrate our reunion.  
we yelped amerigo and based on the reviews and the price listings we thought this would be able to work.  granted, when Kyle told me about it i really thought we were going to some sort of "American Style" food place instead of an italian joint. Granted, to me this is american style italian, but they did a decent job.  i still need to teach kyle how to actually use this site though... burgers do not compare to tortellini.
we walked in without a reservation and only had to wait 10 minutes to get seated. however, there was a group in front of us that i got the impression had been waiting for quite a bit when one of the guys leaned over to the waitress and asked her if "this is the kind of place you need to make a reservation to get into", i guess he felt a little out of place in his jeans and button up shirt, which he shouldn't.  to me, in my obvious nola bias, this was a place one could get away with jeans, nice shirt, and/or a comfy dress/ skirt. lord knows kyle and i weren't wearing anything special... i did see some full on seriously dressy clothing though, super short satin skirts and sports jackets and the like. i wold define it more as dressy casual than dressy.  the decor was like an upscale applebees to me, but a bit more intimate.
the wait staff were all very nice, i think they were a little surprised by how much fun kyle and i were having together. this place is obviously a date night place and that we were laughing and not flirting and interested more in jabbering at one another, even inviting them into our conversation seemed to throw them off a little.  also that we weren't extremely picky over every little thing seemed surprising, but they did their jobs and they did them well and they even cracked a more than polite smile at several of our comments.
as for the food and wine.... well, we paid $36 for a bottle of "Woop, Woop" wine that we found in the wine store the next day for $14, but we knew we would be overpaying, this was, after all a restaurant, with the atmosphere of ... well... you'll pay out the nose for the soft lighting and bench seating. the food was pretty decent, the cheese fritters were tasty, basically just a round friend cheese stick, but def had more flavor than that. i was totally down with the red sauce they served with it, but the other half of the sauce on the plate was a honey mustard concoction that just didn't hit my pallet right. we then ordered the spring salad, which was decent, the lettuce was fresh and the housemaid vinagrette was pretty tasty, it's a recipe i would be happy to get my hands on. They did do one of my favorite things on the planet which was to bring us out a plate of cibatta bread with the olive oil and vinegar and spices, i'm old school italian man, that just speaks to my heart.... so i instantly started to commit carbocide as soon as that was out on the table. as for our entress....i was a little too toasty from the wine at that point to remember exactly but i think kyle got the chicken margaritte (mostly because he was afraid to mispronounce anything else... the man can click away in senagalese but he was too freaked out to try to pronounce italian... tsk tsk) which he seemed to enjoy, there were no complaints, but he couldn't finish it all and mostly just left the pasta at the end. i had the tortellini with spinach and crab and white sauce.  i really have to admit to being disappointed by the lack of spinach, but i am a spinach lover and i guess when you're catering to a large clientel like that you don't necessarily want to throw more than a few springs in there....maybe.....  however, there was a TON of crab meat on the plate and the portion size was huge. sauce was tasty, nothing that i can absolutely rave about, but it was good. i didn't actually end up finishing anywhere near half the plate from everything else i had ordered, and ended up accidentally leaving the boxes at the table in our determined search for wine, so i didn't even get to give it the cold tortellini test (which i always do because yes... i am that person that likes leftover cold tortellini... and pizza... and sushi).
prices varied from a  reasonable $14.00 for my entree to a whopping $32 for the filet (which is what i pay for a filet in nola in an EXPENSIVE restaurant).  i didn't look at the bar menu, but the cheapest bottle of wine started at over $25 and house wine is only sold by the glass.  we didn't get desert either just because of how stuffed we were.  so plenty of food for the price in what we ordered.
overall i give this place a decent night out.  it wasn't spectacular, but i am food spoiled so it takes a lot to impress me, but it was in NO way as bad as i thought it might be on our first walk in the door.  its worth a try if you're ever near by.

I really wanted to give this restaurant 2.5 stars because half of everything was good.  We came for the Christmas Day buffet.  First, our service was outstanding.  I believe our servers name was Josh and he was very attentive.  The Christmas buffet was a little smaller than I expected but they did have a hot pasta station which was a plus.  Our reservations were at 1:30 and it wasn't busy when we got started.  But by the time I went back for my second plate the line was very long, the staff was trying to change out trays of food and it seemed hectic and mismanaged.  The food was mixed, for me.  Some of it I loved and some of it I didn't like at all.  Tops on my did not like list were the banana rum sweet potato mash.  I loved the sound of it but it sounded better than it tasted.  The antipasto salad was amazing and delicious, as was the tropical fruit salad.  I discovered a new favorite fruit, there was a white fruit with black seeds that tasted like a combination of fig and watermelon to me.  I asked a server and he went back to the chef to find out what it was.  It was dragonfruit.  The roasted root vegetables were not to my liking either.  There were mixed reviews on the clam chowder at our table, it was a sweet chowder.  I liked it but others prefer their chowder spicier instead of sweet.  The ham was good and the chollah rolls too.  Overall it was an interesting meal.  We had plenty to talk about discussing the food while we were eating, and since we are foodies that adds to our enjoyment.  I would not drive back from Tampa to Port Richey to eat here again but if I was in the neighborhood I would give it another try.

I'm surprised by the slightly lower rating. We were seated at a lovely window table with a great view of the park. The service was great and every single dish we tried was delicious. I had the butterfish which was great. However, I was most impressed the unique pretzeled trout.

Lovely, warm atmosphere, with a variety of coffees and baked goods, as well as a few sandwiches, soup, and a modest selection of beer and wine. I recommend the whoopie pies - very original flavours. But what a lot of people don't know is that there is live music here on Friday and Saturday evenings, from about 6:30 until closing. If you like to enjoy local singer/songwriters while sipping coffee, check the place out!

They have a great Fall Fest for the kids. I've gone the last couple of years and my daughter loves it. They have people in the parking lot directing traffic and parking. It's super helpful. They have plenty of activities for the kids. The have a corn maze, two hayrides, a big slide, pig races, sand art, etc. They also have a small area where they have some farm animals. You can also mini golf if you'd like. You cant leave without visiting their icecream shop. They make it there at the farm and it's creamy. Three of us went and we only spent about $25. For three hours of entertainment and lasting memories, you can't beat it.

I have loved this place for years. It is the best place to stop In West Ed, especially for the value of the food! Their green onion cakes are fantastic and their food is always cooked with lots of flavour.

My favourite dish is the Thai coconut curry chicken noodle soup. It is my go to when I am sick and the bowl is MASSIVE for 13$.

I wouldn't expect top service as there are usually not many people working and I rarely get a refill on water because they are busy. 

The menu is large and there is an expansive amount of choices. 

Food has always come quickly and correctly.

Once again, Eyesite and Gene have gotten me a WINNER!!!

I am in love, love, LOVE with my new glasses.
They are from Belgium and very unique looking.
They make me feel like a butterfly when I wear them.
They are so light and comfortable - and GORGEOUS.

I absolutely love to shop for eyewear - and I go to lots of higher-end shops, but EYESITE is where I purchase my frames and lenses.

Simply the best.

Sabrina's Café is awesome!  I love to come here for any meal.  No matter what you always get a fantastic meal!  

Mostly, I come for breakfast/brunch!

Huevo's Rancheros is one of my favorite dishes and is usually my go to when I am here for a breakfast item.  I also like the barking Chihuahua when I am feeling very hungry!  Their frittatas are also excellent.  My favorite is the egg white turkey bacon frittata.  Its is a good option if you want a bit of a healthier type breakfast, with no loss of flavor! 

I like to come here with my sister and young nephew.  The place isn't bad for kids.  My nephew loves the pancakes and French toast. (He also loves their French fries!)

Their fruit is always super fresh too, which I love.

For lunch, I like to get either the Mel's Chicken cutlet (so drool worthy), the Tuscan chicken sandwich, or the Mediterranean wrap.  Everything is different and so flavorful.  Portions are pretty big, so whenever I come with my mom, we often share!

Their salads are also excellent.  Very often I will split a salad and sandwich with someone I am with, you cannot go wrong with any of the salads here.

They do themed brunches too, which is such a great novelty!  Special menu's are available for these with cute puns as all of the menu item names.

They don't serve dinner at all of their locations, but I highly suggest checking the places that do serve dinner out.  Fantastic meal!  Our go-to's are the octopus and calamari as a starter.  Always a good pick!  If we want something a bit lighter, we go for the hummus.

The dishes I have had as my main course are the Grilled Orange Ginger Pork Chop, The Honey Melon Glazed Salmon, and the Smokey Cajun Spiced Ahi Tuna.  You cannot go wrong with either.  Portions are also pretty big, so make sure you are hungry!!


I also really like that this restaurant has plenty of vegentarian and vegan options.   I myself am a carnivore, but I do also enjoy the vegetarian options and have many vegan/vegetarian friends.   It is really nice to have plenty of choices and a variety in the menu which Sabrin'a certainly provides.

The prices here are pretty reasonable.  The only downside here, is the wait, especially on the weekends. Plus they can get crazy crowded and the space is pretty tight and can get pretty loud. However, I guess that is part of what makes Sabrina's so special.  Also, not a bad place for kids!Certainly worth a wait for the food, staff is always friendly and accommodating!  Great for smaller groups, but since space is on the tighter side, I wouldn't go in a group larger than 6.

Sabrina's is a great, casual, fun place to eat, I suggest you go and enjoy!

I absolutely LOVE the Melting Pot.  As others mention, it is an EXPERIENCE -- the way Fondu should be! -- and that's perhaps my favorite part.  You can easily spend 3-4 hours here enjoying your food and the company you bring, so I definitely suggest going with a group of 4, asking for a table with two pots, and having that be your night.

Their DRINKS are outstanding!  Love their mango margarita, dragon berry mojito, and blackberry sage lemonade.  They were all excellent, strong enough to warrant $8-9, and tasted fresh and fruity.

We always do the "BIG NIGHT OUT" -- $88/couple for a cheese appetizer pot (we love the Wisconsin 3 cheese and Feng Shui), salad, dinner plate with either oil or broth (both are excellent) to cook the meat, and a dessert pot (LOVE the white chocolate, s'more, and the bananas foster!).  When you go as a group of four (two couples) with 2 pots, you get to try two of everything and that's seriously the best.

It's a TON of food, so BE HUNGRY!!!   We make it a 5pm dinner that counts as lunch, dinner, and dessert.

AMBIANCE is pretty standard but there's nothing wrong with it -- semi-romantic, clean, and the booths feel pretty private which is a plus.  The bathrooms are very clean and they have awesome disposable hand towels to dry your hands.

I know people say it depends on the server you get, but the two times I've been, I had FANTASTIC SERVICE.  Last Saturday it was Brian, and he was awesome -- laid back, punny (not a typo), and very knowledgable of the menu.  He made great recommendations and made sure we knew exactly how to cook our items to our liking.  We never had to ask for more water or dipping sauce because he was there with more as soon as we needed it.

The manager and the owner both came by to ensure we were having a good night, and that always adds to the experience for me.  Even the bus boy was hilarious and very friendly.  Honestly, to me that's great service!

Why 4 stars?  Their salads need a little work and it is probably a little more pricey than it needs to be.  If it was slightly less expensive, I may end up here for fun instead of only for special occasions.

Regardless, if you go hungry and are the kind of person who likes to enjoy your food and has a few good friends that are great company, it's worth it!  Remember -- you're paying for the experience and service in addition to the food.

If you're less hungry, maybe just get a cheese pot and a chocolate.  You'll spend less money, but still get to enjoy the deliciousness that is The Melting Pot!

Happy dipping. :]

We came in for a late lunch and found the place pretty busy. We told the waitress we were first timers and she was kind enough to explain the menu and let us know her favorite items on the menu. She made everything sound so delicious. I love when the staff feels passionate about the food they are serving. We started with some delicious Yucca fries. We ordered a side of the cilantro rice as it was raved about - all true excellent combo of flavors. My husband opted for the steak and chicken with rice and finished it off with a smile. I ordered a salad with chopped chicken and it was awesome - they have several different sauces and I opted for the sauce vs regular salad dressing. I wish we saved room for dessert as the next table was enjoying it. Would highly recommend

I have a love hate relationship with new restaurants , I always set the bar too high and sometimes the newness is great and other times not so much . Planned a lady date here last week with Becca S. I was super excited to try out yet another neighborhood pizza place so we met up here last Thursday during the rainstorm of 2014. 
The restaurant itself is pretty small about 3 four tops and bar seating for around 5 people. This place is Byob and they accept cards which is a plus. We both agreed a salad with our pie would make for less guilt so we ordered the only option available which was romaine hearts, artichokes , sun dried tomatoes , pickled eggplant and provolone. We requested the cheese on the side and did the large original pie. 

The salad was fresh and the vinaigrette had a nice balance of acid and salt. The pickled eggplant was something very different I didn't hate it but it wasn't something id order by itself.  

Our pie took a while to bake it seemed like a lot of to go orders were coming in, but we received our pie around the same time as another patron who came in as a walk. his pie came out right behind ours and we order about 10 min before he got there. The pizza is not Santuccis or Nomad it's in it's own unique category. I wouldn't quite call it Sicilian as the crust on the bottom was super crispy and the top had some nice bubbles happening. 
The pie itself was alright, it wasn't bad but it wasn't stellar. The sauce had a good balance of flavor I could actually taste the freshness of the tomatoes and herbs, there wasn't much cheese to be seen which was a little disappointing. I believe the chef owner was there the night we went and he brought out cheese and red pepper flakes which was nice. The large pie is a decent size and Becca and I barely made a dent each taking home at least 1.5 slices for lunch the next day. Left over pizza lunch is usually my favorite but I was reminded the next morning how little cheese there was and wound up eating just mostly crust. 

Our damage was minimum as the salad and pie rang in under 25.00. I think the price point of the pies is great for the neighborhood and some of the other menu options sound great so I would probably order something for takeout.

This place and Nomad are equal in distance to my apartment for now I can't say which place will reign supreme but I will say I prefer the type of service I received at square pie ( that's a direct dig at you Nomad) This made for a good lady dinner date for now it's a high 3 stars for square pie.

I'm so happy The Libertine is in Indy.  I think the Seelbach is my new favorite cocktail.  We sampled a number of their offerings including oysters, the warm mushrooms salad, the beet salad, deviled eggs (three different kinds!), and the lamb neck rillette.  Everything was very good but the lamb rillette was my favorite.  

As mentioned previously plates are small.  I personally love this about The Libertine as I got to try so many of their tasty dishes.

I can't wait to go back to try more cocktails and food.

Oh one other thing.  I think they are the only place in Indianapolis that offers Fernet at the bar.  For that alone, they get 5 stars.

Must haves: pork belly tacos and the chicken, all drinks are liquid heaven!

I love the decor in this place allows for an intimate dining experience.

We love this place!!!! We have been here twice and it is always so busy but the wait is never painful to be seated and to be served. And, once we were seated, we ate for three hours without feeling rushed. 

Saganaki (flaming cheese): don't say no just say yes! Even if you are lactose intolerant, take some lactase and go for it!!! You only live once and you have to try this salty, crunchy, creamy, chewy, and gooey goodness! Get one per each person and don't forget the magic word Opa!!!!

When I first came to this country, I wanted to try everything that I have never tried. One of those things was grilled cheese imagining exactly this! Then, the waitress served me a sandwich. I called waitress over to let her know that she had my order wrong saying I ordered grilled cheese not sandwich, she looked at me wide-eyed and said, "That is grilled cheese!" My English was not good enough to explain what I expected to see when I ordered grilled cheese. And, I am pretty sure that the waitress was just as shocked as I was by the situation we found ourselves in. So, glad that my American cheese dream finally came true here!!!!

Baklava Martini: I am coming clean that I ordered this drink to be a great yelper. It is not everyday that you see Baklava Martini on the menu. There are not many things more disappointing than ordering a drink that you never tried before and realize that you did not like the drink and have to order what you know that you like. That is why I order a glass of red wine when I drink and I rarely order cocktail drinks. This is one of the very few times that I would order a cocktail drink. And, I had two! I ordered the first one for yelp and the second one for me. 
I am running out of space and time to write about the rest of the dish we ordered which was the salad without the lettuce, octopus (ordered it even after I watched my octopus friend and my companions although very nice gave me the looks that made me slightly guilty.) Scallops and 1 lb of shrimp.  All of them were excellent. I could be totally content with Opa cheese The whole one for myself, salad for two for myself, and two Baklava martini next time!!! 

Yes, definitely coming back to eat here!!!

Only one of the best spots in Fountain Square area. The food is INCREDIBLE! I'm vegetarian which they can accommodate with more than just a couple options which is amazing for a bar of this type. The patio in the warmer months is so much fun and you can almost always get a seat since there are so many! Love this place!

LOL, what's not to love about Good Time Charlies.  I have been a patron on & off for many years now & always seem to find a reason to return.
The clientele is as unique as the establishment itself. You will find all types of patrons from 3 piece suits to shorts and flip flops. People watching is a personal hobby of mine & this is another great place for me to partake in my hobby.
You can't really call GTC a dive, but it certainally is nothing to write home about, unless to tell your stories of adventures while there. It is like a "B" grade movie or a homemade potato vodka, even though they do have top shelf liquor available.
I can honestly say 90 % of the times I have been there have been really good times, I guess that helps to explain why I keep returning. Usually there is just something in the air that becomes contagious.  A bowling teams victory, a job promotion, a divorce party... or just a good time not to work party.
I love the different games & pool tables,  it adds to the charm of a decor that never seems to change. As usual, I normally end up sitting at the bar & chatting with the folks behind the bar, as well as around me. Both sides of the bar are usually fairly antimated.
I have to admit, I am not a fan of karaoke & now they have it every night.  No.... stop the madness, every night is 6 too many! I quit smoking 3 years ago, so that is no longer a reason I like GTC. I really don't like leaving and smelling like a cigarette,  but all things in moderation.
Overall they take their food pretty seriously. It is not just pub grub, but you can get specials and entire meals. I am sure there is no chef back there, but who ever is cooking, usually does okay.
Yup GTC & I go way back & other than the karaoke,  I see no reason to mess with our relationship.
What's a girl to do?  If it's not broken, don't fix it.

We are spolied rotten here in Chester County.  Baily's is a little farm on a bck road that lets the public come in and buy milk, eggs, cheese, ice cream all straight from the source.  The taste is incomparable to that you would buy in the supermarket.  This is convenient, well priced and runs by the honor system.  Seriously there is a cashbox and a ledger.  You write down what you got add it up and make your own change in the changebox.  Simple, wonderful and the money goes right to the provider.  Love this place.

Looking for the best prices on wine and the best beer selection in Tampa?  Oh, here it is!  It took me way too long to find out about Total Wine after moving to Tampa.

Their wine selection is enormous and can be a bit overwhelming, but they have a fantastic staff.  They are always friendly and willing to help you find whatever you need.  Not only do they have a great variety of excellent wine, but I find myself searching for the cheaper bottles towards the bottom of the shelves and I can still find so many great choices.  

Now for my favorite part....the craft beer section.  Holy. Crap.  I could spend hours in this area of the store.  I love beer and often can't find my favorite craft brews at most stores.  At Total Wine, I can't think of one beer that I have looked for and couldn't find.   Awesome variety and their prices are stellar.  Far better than any grocery store in the area (ahem, Publix).  Sometimes, I peruse the beer section at Whole Foods for some things to try and then go to Total Wine to find them at least a dollar or two cheaper.

I don't drink liquor as much as I drink wine and beer, but their selection of liquor is no different than the rest of the store.  You can find anything you need and I've found the prices better here than any liquor store around here.

Total Wine is a one stop shop for all your alcoholic needs.  Trust me, you'll love it.

Heaven, I'm in heeeaaavvven
And my mouth gasps so that I can hardly speak
And I seem to find the sugar cream I seek
When I'm eatin' pies from My Sugar Pie

Yes heaven, I'm in heaven
And the slice that was handed to me one eve'ning
Seemed to vanish into this Yelper's mouth real quick
When I'm eatin' pies from My Sugar Pie

Oh I love to nosh on cupcakes
And order fudgy brownies
But it doesn't thrill me half as much
As eatin' My Sugar Pie

Oh I love to go to bak'ries
Samplin' bread or a cookie
But I don't enjoy it half as much
As eatin' My Sugar Pie

Now pie slice come to me
I want my fork dug in you
That filling inside you
Will carry me through

To Heaven, I'm in heeeaaavvven
And my mouth drools so that I can hardly speak
And I seem to find the sugar cream I seek
When I'm eatin' pies from My Sugar Pie

I simply love the convenience of ordering lunch on the app and picking it up on the way to the office!  No wait, no lines, and a healthy option!  My fave is the Grilled Chicken Cool Wrap & Kale Salad Hot entrees are not available early but certain cold options are available. I'm a fan

I give this place 5 stars because it's SO much better than 99% of Mexican restaurants in Tennessee. The food actually has flavor and tastes fresh. 

The salsa clearly has real onion, cilantro and tomatoes; none of that canned stuff most places serve. Good start to things.

The top shelf margarita was fabulous. I frequently can't drink margaritas at restaurants because they overload them with sour mix. This margarita tasted like it had good quality tequila, and wasn't overly sweet or sour. 

I loved the chicken tortilla soup. The broth was delicious and wasn't greasy. The chicken was moist, and there were vegetables to balance out the taste. They had chunks of avocado, which I love. The portion was generous, I actually didn't finish it. 

My husband had the tamales, and really enjoyed them. I was too focused on my food to try it. 

If you live in the Bellevue area or west, this is a great option. The prices were great as well.

I was excited to try V street in the first few weeks of opening.  Although I'm not a vegan, I have really enjoyed Hip City Veg, Charlie was a Sinner, Vedge, and Blackbird.  Also, shout out to Blue Sage in the burbs, check it out if you get a chance.  Back to V Street... 

The set up is interesting, I got there first so put my name in, and they took my cell phone number, so you can actually leave to grab a drink somewhere else if the bar is full.  Apparently the bar had a wait list as well which was confusing.  I tried to sit down when some people got up, but was told I couldn't.  I was not a fan of the beer and wine list.  When there's a wait list at the bar, and a wait for a table, it's tough to ask the bartender any questions, so some better descriptions would be appreciated.  I ordered the cider which was super sour.  I actually felt really bad because it was my mistake but I did send it back and switched to the Riesling which still seemed off, but I wasn't going to send another drink back.  My friend had a red but it was super chilled.  The fancy cocktails looked good and I'll definitely try one of those next time.  At the table I had the pumpkin beer which was also a little sour, but interesting.  I guess next time I need to google things before I order them.

As for the food, I loved the Langos, it's like a vegan gyro.  The crunchy papadums were light and airy, the jerk trumpet mushrooms tasted like BBQ, and the mushroom dan dan noodles were great.  We tried a few other things too, the only dish I wasn't a fan of was the carrot choripan.

I'd probably go back for happy hour and get more of the Langos and the papadums.  Price was $50 each for a group of 5 who had several beers.  The staff was friendly, especially the hostess.  She checked in numerous times to update us on the wait.

I'm not going to write about the food. It's pretty standard and it's good. I always order from here. 
What i do want to write about is the experience eating here. It's awesome because you will always have the place to yourself. Seriously, inside Rich City is a ghost town and it's a shame because the place is actually nice inside. It's not like going into No. 1 Chinese Food only a few blocks away (where my dad, for some reason, loves to get his take out) where the place is dirty and sticky. Rich City is a decent spot. 
I used to come here all the time with my friends and eat dinner inside. The service is friendly and quick, but they never rush you out the door.   Bonus points for the most random music selection ever. Celine Dion? Michael Jackson? Awesome and authentic background music!

I have in many posts, described my love for what I like to call, "Missouri Mexican." Because of this, many told me about Mi Ranchito. I was super impressed. Great place in U-City and way better than the El Maguey off Delmar. Plus, if you are a fan of little cartoon Mexican mice, then you'll definitely dig the wall art. 

I would highly recommend Mi Ranchito. Great margaritas, okay queso, hella awesome prices. But if you are not into El Pasino or any other of the Los/EL bunch of restaurants, you'll find nothing to like at Mi Ranchito.

I really liked the spices and flavors from this place. It really surprised me how much "punch" it had especially for a fried fish dish that I had. The inside isn't too grand for larger parties, but since we are still in a pandemic, I don't think I am too worried about larger parties. They do have some outdoor seating, which is nicer for the summer time. 

I was sitting inside near a window to people watch  and it was nice. The amount of food I ordered needed two tables though - I was hungry. The soup dumplings were filled with soup and that is always a good thing. The flavor of the soup dumplings paled in comparison with other places and the fried fish I just had. Really loves that fish that much. Honestly, I would probably come back just for the fish dish. 

I had a soup as well, but I could not remember much about that dish. 

They accepted Venmo and cash, but not credit cards so that kind of took me by surprise. Luckily, I did have cash on me, but I generally don't carry cash. Just be cautious.

This place was so yummy. We originally went their first the breakfast tacos but we got their too late so they were no longer serving it. But my friend and I split their fried chicken sliders, and it did not disappoint! They were incredibly good. I wish I had got more for myself! Perfectly fried, and juicy meat (it's always the worst when it's dried out). Love the pop of jalapeños. Just really good flavor. Wish I tried more of the menu, but we just weren't very hungry at the time. Would definitely go back and try out some more options.

We loved it here. Outside of Winnie's leBus ( which I hate). Breakfast is hard to come by in Manayunk.  It's really cozy inside and very clean. Bathroom you could seriously eat in it.  My daughter had the chocolate chip pancakes, which she loved.  I had the breakfast sandwich which  was great. My husband had the Brekky bowl and LOVED it.  Greg the owner went out of his way to be sweet to my daughter.  Nice guy!!  You have to go try this place.

Urban Shabu is excellent. If you're a hot pot regular, you need to try this place.

The restaurant interior is clean and modern, with marble tabletops, contemporary plates and cutlery, new age chandeliers, and a "Bon Appetit" sign hovering over the sauces. The place is almost overrun with servers, who are ready to help you from the moment you enter the restaurant until you step outside the door.

We arrived around 7:15pm on a Thursday evening and were immediately seated. The restaurant, though fairly steady, wasn't nearly busy enough to be full. This is partly because the place is huge - similar to Kings - but also because weekend evenings are usually the most popular hot pot times.

We ordered our broth (HK Style Satay for myself; Tom Yum for Kylie) and a bottle of pinot noir (I love wine and hot pot). The servers checked on us a million times before we handed in our list of food items, but they weren't intrusive. They came by with an inquisitive look and could be sent off with a small shake of the head. At other restaurants, servers who come by too often can be annoying; at Urban Shabu, they're simply poised and ready to bring you what you need.

Once we got our food, though, they left us to it - hovering nearby just in case.
A note on the broth, before I get to the food: the satay soup is lovely. If you're allergic to peanuts, you're out of luck - it's as good as my favourite coconut satay broth from Bangkok Restaurant. The tom yum soup has a little more of a tangy taste, but it's delicious, too. With items like these on the menu, why would you even consider ordering the (boring) chicken broth?

We ordered way too much food, as I'm wont to do at hot pot. Everything was fresh and of a great quality, and they definitely don't skimp on the servings!

My favourites generally include the angus beef, marble beef, lobster balls, and crab sticks. I'm not too adventurous when it comes to hot pot, simply because I know what I like. I tried a mash, which wasn't to my tastes, and I had a few mussels, which (in my opinion) taste better when steamed in a red wine sauce. The fish balls were the same as everywhere else and the shrimp balls pleasantly reminded me of xia jiao (a dim sum dumpling).

Overall, I think I've found my new favourite hot pot joint. I still love Bangkok Restaurant's food and the owners there are lovely, but Urban Shabu has so much of the modern China feel and has many more items to choose from. Bangkok is a hidden gem; Urban Shabu is a well-known hotspot.

At $26 a person, it's pretty much the same price-wise as every other hot pot restaurant in the city. For two of us, with upgraded soup and a bottle of wine, it came to about $90. Not too shabby, Shabu. Not too shabby.

I missed the YELP Elite event here so figured I needed to go try it out ASAP. I wasn't disappointed. I met a friend here for lunch and the food was deletable!!

We started with the spicy edamame which had a nice little kick to it. I LOVE that they have 3 options for the edamame (Salty, Spicy & Tart). Normally you only ever see the classic salty edamame but they are switching it up! We then had their East lunch special which included a roll, 2 pieces of nigiri and a small salad. I had a spicy tuna roll, the Escolar nigiri and the Chuka salad (seaweed). Delicious!!! I think this may be the first time I've ever had Escolar. I still need to go back to try their Special Sushi (habenero-magno salsa anyone?) and their street tacos, not to mention their yummy sounding cocktail menu.

The ONLY reason this is not a 5 star review was that our service was humerously awful. We got the wrong edamame to start, had to wait quite a while for our food even though it wasn't busy, and our waitress asked us for our order 15 minutes after we had already given it to her. Being new I'm hoping the service element improves but Umi Star's food is well worth it. 

I'll be back...and soon :)

I love love love this place. Yes I am a shopaholic and I love my sales and stores that sell petites. My favorite store in this mall are Ann Taylor (they have a pretty good petite collection here), J Crew, Express (their factory outlet is just like their retail store). Tommy Hilfiger and Banana Republic could be a hit or a miss. Only thing that could improve here is the food court. Come on!! We can definitely do better.

Seafood does not get more fresh and tasty than the food at Drago's!

Oysters, oysters, oysters. People from all around come here just for their oysters and now I truly understand. Their oysters are so fresh and they have the best texture. If someone has never eaten oysters before, I recommend trying them here so you'll be sure to have a good experience. Their raw oysters are amazing and their charbroiled oyster are even better! TRY THEIR OYSTERS!!!

Some of their other dishes are just as amazing. They Lobster Marco is to die for! It's a whole lobster stuffed with angel hair pasta with shrimp for only $27. The gumbo is really good with lots of flavor. The spinach salad is good but doesn't really stand out to all their other amazing dishes. Their Spicy Andouille Ravioli was beyond good, I highly recommend this as an entree.

Aside from the food, the parking lot sucks when this place is crowded. The restaurant can smell really fishy sometimes, but that just proves how fresh their seafood is. The service here is absolutely exceptional. I highly recommend this restaurant to everyone who loves seafood!

We don't buy all our groceries here, but we do get a bunch of delicious things! Prices can tend to be a little high on some things, but it's a great specialty store with lots of healthy and tasty food.

It's a fun place to shop. My kids love going because they have a "find the animal" challenge where they can earn a lollipop each time they come. They also have a tasting corner in the back of the shop.

This place is two for two with me!

I went once for lunch and had their specialty Farmhouse Burger - a burger with an egg on top, and their specialty mustard on the side. It was a surprisingly excellent burger. Very juicy and full of flavor. Service on this particular visit was extremely slow, and with all the televisions showing college football plus the music blaring, the place was pretty loud.

My second visit I met a friend for happy hour.  Much lower volume level this visit, and the server was much more efficient.  Great deals for happy hour - I went with the lemon drop martini, on special for $6.  All the appetizers are discounted for happy hour also, so my friend and I ordered a smorgasbord of items.  

Duck wings are mentioned in every review, and they were great - nice and crispy, with a bit of a bite from the sauce. I also loved the drunken meatballs - they too were in a spicy sauce, and cooked perfectly. The big surprise of the night was the Kobe Brick Pizza - thin crust, loaded with wagyu beef, cheese, caramelized onions, roasted tomatoes, bacon and arugula, it had a fabulous flavor - I would definitely order this again. 

The only appetizer I didn't love was their version of the Seven Layer Dip: white bean purée, harissa, yogurt, oven roasted tomatoes, smashed avocados, smoked cheddar & chopped olives served with grilled naan.  Even with all those ingredients, it just did not have much flavor.  It was still good, but not great.

I will definitely be back to explore their drink and food menus further, and to take advantage of their excellent happy hour.

It would've been hard for this restaurant to do any wrong since it was our first experience sitting outside for the season. Luckily, the atmosphere mimicked the experience and food and it was a lovely evening!

We tried the middle eastern sampler which was divine. Tasty hummus, some kind of couscous, and  roasted garlic. Yum!!

I got the baby spinach salad which was wonderful. The sweet dressing and craisins complemented the pecans and goat cheese perfectly. It's easily my favorite salad anywhere because those flavors just work so well together! I sampled my husbands sweet potato fries and those were tasty as well. 

The boys in the group enjoyed the beer, and overall it was very pleasant! A great addition to the Loop's already great food-lineup.

I'm beginning to think the problem might be me, because I've liked about 20% of the Asian restaurants I've tried in St. Louis. So, if you're unimpressed by blatant CA snobbery, skip my review. 
Spring rolls: best part of the meal, but still pretty standard fare. It's a fried spring roll, so don't expect any miracles.
Roti: Fried dough can't really be screwed up too badly, but in my opinion it was a bit flaky and the peanut sauce wasn't great. I'd eat it again though.
Tom Yum: Hot sauce in a bowl with some undercooked mushrooms and questionable shrimp. It lacked the complexity of flavor that I love about traditional Tom Yum soup. However, the portion was generous, so if I would have liked the soup more I'd have been stoked.
Pad See Ew: Flavorless. Seriously. The broccoli was good though.
Service: Nice enough. You order at the counter and they bring your food out to you. There is indoor and outdoor seating, but I prefer being squeezed onto the sidewalk than sitting in their ambience-free space. I was seriously bummed after trying this place because it was supposed to be my little thai place down the street but nooooo it's just not really my taste at all. I didn't try their curries so I'd probably get that if I ever found myself back here for whatever reason, just because their noodles and soups were pretty blah.

One of the best hotels I could probably find in the location we wanted (by State St.).

Plusses:
- Modern decor, with classy Spanish influence
- Binoculars for peeping on your neigh- for birdwatching
- Clean bathroom with separate shower and tub, and LCD (to watch while soaking in aforementioned tub) - note we were in deluxe king room
- New alarm clock with ipod dock
- Very nice hardwood floors
- Large LCD TV in the bedroom
- Cool-looking,  high canopy bed
- Gorgeous top-floor pool with beautiful views
- Ice bucket filled every night

Minuses (minusi?):
- Staff was friendly, but stale (compared with other hotels I would consider 5-star worthy on yelp)
- Bed was a little too firm (may not be a problem for you)
- Forgot to bring an ipod for the ipod dock (may not be a problem for you)
- No HD on the nice new HD-compatible TV
- PRICEY.  Not only is room rate high, but $20 a day for valet and no free internet ($10 a day).

All in all, the Canary had enough nice little touches to keep us happy but not enough love (or value) to keep us coming back.

Stumbled upon this place when I was walking around the neighborhood. Very small but lovely. I think it's a fun "supplemental gift option" especially for your Philly friends who are leaving. If you're like me and you've come here for school, you've had a lot of good friends stay for a while and then up and leave me for residencies, fellowships, new jobs... So sad, but so nice to give them something to remember Philly by. I purchased this canvas where a local philly artist had painted different neighborhood logos-- like they had a Pennsport/Queen Village one that had Federal Donuts, Royal Tavern, Tatooed Mom's, etc... Very cute. They have lots of totes, philly-themed onesies, jewelry etc... A fun find!

This is my go to place for take out because they honestly have anything you are looking for. One night I was like I really want chocolate cake, and surprisingly they had it! It's now an ongoing joke. 

The food is almost always warm & cooked to our wants. There has been a few times, I ordered cheese whiz, I never got it with the order & they had charged me for it. I wasn't going to call and complain over a dollar but it's still frustrating but like I said it's only been a few times & there are times we order from them multiple times a week.

I would recommend getting sauces on the side of your sandwiches or wraps, because sometimes it's a mess or way too much on it. 

I love that the drivers use square reader & you can just pay for it at your door when it gets delivered. 
They do charge $1.50 for delivery. 

They always have weekday specials, everyday specials & amazing lunch deals. And depending on how much you spend they will give you a free 2 litter of soda. 

If you are looking for a new place to try this is it :)

Checked this place out for date night, and we really enjoyed it. Happened to visit on a night where they were offering $6 rolls, which we loved! Make sure you check out their specials, because it seemed like they change nightly. 

We tried the rainbow, kamikaze, and Rasta roll. All were fantastic, but my favorite was definitely the Rasta roll. It was very unique and had great flavors! 

My only complaint was the slow service we received. It took over 30 minutes to be served and I saw other tables that were sat after us getting their food before us. We came hungry, and didn't expect to wait that long for food at a sushi joint. Will visit again to try the happy hour, and hopefully we will have better service.

Cute little place in the Italian Market

Start with the good - service was really great, everyone had a smile on their face, the server explained the menu and specials of the night very well and service was attentive but not overbearing at all. 

We both had the Serrano pepper margarita , $10 which was good! It had a great kick to it and was actually spicy, we loved this. 

I was personally a little underwhelmed with the food. The chips were good, loved both the green and red sauces -- green was a bit tarte and the red nice and smokey. For my entrée I got the chicken pibil tacos - which were good but just underwhelming.

Based on the amazing reviews, I'd probably return to try some other items another time -- but might hang up my coat after the 2nd visit if still underwhelmed.

I love PPL Park! It's so beautiful. Located right on the Delaware-- perfect view. Every seat seems to be a great seat-- however-- I highly recommend you sit in the Sons of Ben (river end). We get rowdy, sing, dance, and have a great time!
Really nice bar with live music, gets a bit cramped during weekends but we loved it here. Great beer selection, too!

I've been bringing my two dogs here for several years. The doctors and staff are great.  They are true animal lovers.  My dogs are very happy to visit the vet.  I've never had to wait more than a minute or two when I arrive and am usually in and out pretty quick.  Their fees are reasonable and they provide a thorough service.

Had a great experience here in this lovely and clean salon today. Someone recommended it to me and I'm so glad they did. I had a great pedicure with a massage and the person who did it was excellent and also a great resource for restaurants in NOLA.  The owners couldn't have been nicer and I enjoyed talking with them about us both having a French Bulldog as a pet!  I would highly recommend this place!

It's just like nearly any other Home Depot. Except most of the employees I speak with have had some actual experience in carpentry and construction. In power tools I spent over an hour hanging out with an old timer talking about the evolution of cordless drills. Boring to some awesome to me. 

We ended up settling on a ridged drill and impact drill set. Totally worth it if you buy ridged power tools at Home Depot and then do the online registration with ridged (keep your receipt) you get a LIFETIME SERCIVE AGREEMENT. literally everything even the battery's will be replaced. Best power tool purchase ever. After spending a bunch of time using my drill I love my ridged over my old dewalts. 

Also in garden section I met an old fencing contractor who helped get every piece I needed to run a link fence in my backyard he helped measure it out and picked all the misc nuts and bolts. Best team of employees I've worked with at any home improvement warehouse. Forget lowes come here!!

what's a vegetarian doing giving a steakhouse a 4 star rating, you ask? well, while i will proudly admit that my brother is a server there, this review is not to praise his extensive knowledge of food & wine and dedication to fine service (ok, mini plug - ya caught me!)

i'm not one to complain about lack of veg options at an establishment that features meat (in harry's case, they are known for their prime rib), i just choose to not eat there. however, because of my family connection, i have ended up dining at harry's on multiple occasions...and loved it every time! 

on each visit i kindly alerted my server (when not my brother) to inform the chef that i was a vegetarian and to see what was available. let's not forget, quality chefs are masters of the culinary arts...and like any professional in the art world, doing the same thing all the time can get a bit tiresome. that said, instead of copping an attitude about this being a steakhouse, the chef, as i was told, was excited for the opportunity to "be creative" in the kitchen by making something off the menu. everything he has prepared for me used ingredients found in other dishes and was simply delicious!

another thing i love about harry's is their wine tasting flights. each month a different grape is featured, for example riesling or cabernet, and you are presented (quite nicely, i might add) with 2.5oz samples of this wine from 4 different vineyards, complete with printed descriptions of each. the price ranges depending on the particular wines being served, but in my experience, has always been under $15 - an excellent value, not to mention a great way to acquaint yourself with the subtle variations and discover the preference of your own palate.

I agree w other "vintage" is stretching it a bit w the title of the store.  It is an overpriced Goodwill with handpicked items more named brand items.  We only come here on 50% off day because it is actually ok pricing.  

The staff is always super nice though.  So helpful and really seem to love their jobs.

As many times as I've been to St. Louis over the years, I can't believe I just now made it to Perennial. It may be my new favorite spot.

I guess it's understandable why I haven't been here, as it isn't exactly close to major attractions. It's in an industrial, blue-collar area south of downtown near the river. Yet it feels like you've wandered into some lovely little Belgian farmhouse brewery when you arrive at the tap room.

It's not a big place, but it's a cool spot to hang out. It was a little too chilly for the patio outside, but I can't wait to come back and sit and sip there sometime (you can bring dogs, too).

Onto the beer, which is the most important thing. This brewery specializes in saisons, Belgians, ciders and the like. I was told that the draft list was a little more boring than usual when I was there, but I still found it to be pretty amazing. I particularly enjoyed the Hommel, their well-known Belgian pale ale. You can get full pours or 5 oz tasters, the latter of which is very reasonably priced at $2-3 and allows you to try many different ones.

I was there on a slow night, but the bartenders were extremely friendly. They even comped me a beer when they found out I was a beer nerd from out of town. Later, another bartender opened a bottle of the Foeder Saison and poured me a glass on the house. It was a spectacular saison, one of the best I've ever had. I ended up buying a bottle to take home. 

There are also some small bites on the menu. I got the pretzels and beer mustard. Loved the tanginess of the mustard, and while the plate is meant for sharing, I devoured the whole thing myself.

There are some amazing things happening with small breweries in Anheuser-Busch's hometown, and Perennial is my new favorite one.

I absolutely love Schlafly Bottleworks! It is an amazing place to grab a beer, quick dinner and chat with friends. It was clean, the staff was very friendly & I had the BEST mushroom burger there! You can't go wrong with any of their in house brews either!

My new favorite nail salon!!! I've been to quite a few nail salons in Seminole and this one is by far the best!!! They have a large variety of colors to chose from, which is important to me. I love the chromes and metallics...so many that I had the hardest time selecting one.  Service was fabulous.  I got the cat eye chrome, which in other salons took a long time, but here it only took 10 minutes. Nails look phenomenal!!!

FUBLE Diaries: Episode 6 
I try to put up a good front , but the fact is, I'm not very worldly. Strike that, Ive been around this globe, more true is that I'm not very Philadelphia-ly. I'm a huge sports fan, football being the best, but I have never tailgated and have never been to a regular season Eagles game. This would become evident to all before Sunday Game Time. 

I knew we needed an early start and after the Ruby Tuesday/Oasis 1-2 punch, I was surprised when the boys were ready to go at 7am. The first of many mistakes made was that we had forgotten to take the Moose meat, that the guys brought from Alaska, out of the freezer. We had to stop for some provisions anyway, so we just picked up some not-as-cool-as-moosemeat sausage to grill. 

We made it to the Linc in good time and were not surprised to see the lot pretty full already, at 8am even though it was a damp day...this was the Eagles Giants game after all. Not that I would wish it on anyone but having Jason's handicap placard was a great experience in there. It opened alot of doors for us and got us a sweet spot within the shadow of the stadium. 

As stated, this was my first tailgating experience, but not my first grilling experience, so there is really no excuse for the following screw-ups. I got the grill set up and went to light it with a brand new lighter. The piece of shit lighter didn't work at all! I could have farted on the charcoal with better results. Luckily, the Alaskans were good at making friends. Neighbors to both sides received authentic Alaskan beer (which they lugged all the way here on the plane...4 cases!) and we got our grill lit. 

After getting the meat on the grill , I realized I didn't bring any grilling utensils. Luckily hot dogs are easy to turn by hand. It was great eating hot sausages at 10am, amongst fellow sports fans, with the home of the Eagles in the background...even if we did forget to bring any condiments. 

Finally, I didn't have a viable plan to dispose of the spent charcoal and hot grill. We ended up using all of our bottled water to douse it and luckily it cooled off in time to pack it away before heading to the Stadium, but images of a burned out shell of a car (or cars!) plagued my mind for the rest of the day. You'd think all the snafus would have dampened the already drizzly day but we had a great time, in spite of the mistakes and agreed that we would be more prepared next time. 

Once inside the complex, it was like a carnival. Radio shows broadcasting, bands playing, cheerleaders posing, vendors gouging...it was great. Our seats were in the nosebleeds but I can honestly say that there isn't a bad seat in the house. 

Ive been a fan for quite some time but nothing compares to the goosebumps I received when the players were announced , to much music, fanfare and fireworks. I recommend all fans see their team at least once live and in person. 

The Alaskans absolutely loved the Philly fans, not in spite of the bad rep but because of it. They revelled in the fact that they were allowed to be assholes. They loved taunting Giants fans with the " Asshole!" chant , a practice which continued long after we left the stadium. They got caught up in the Eagles Chants, the High 5's, getting rival fans kicked out. They even added a little of their own flavor with the Alaskan chant of , " UP THE GUTS!" every time the running back would find a big hole and it was a trip when our seat neighbors used the line as well. I was also partial to Dean's shout of, ' He's built like a kicker!" , whenever a small or skinny guy would walk by. 

Jason was still feeling a little under the weather and the damp day wasn't helping. He wrapped himself snugly in a newly purchased Eagles fleece and at one point, a fan walked past and just said, " You comfortable sweetheart?" The other 2 heard this and thought it was the funniest thing they'd ever heard. It solidified their love of the ugly Philly sports fan. 

It helped considerably that the game itself was an Eagles rout of their division rival. We screamed ourselves hoarse at every play and had a grand time doing it. Towards the end, when others headed for their cars to get a jump on the traffic, we decided to stay in our seats for as long as we could, not wanting the experience to end. We knew it would be an ugly ride to our next destination as Game 4 of the World Series was set to be played in a few short hours, but we didn't care. This had been the whole reason for the trip and we wanted it to last. 

Plans were made on the spot to meet next year, possibly in another city giving some other of our fantasy football brothers a chance to attend. It was agreed that we would all bring a nice chunk of that Philly Fan Bravado, that made the day great. We finally left the stadium and made our way out of the complex. As the Linc got smaller in the rear view, we were reminded that while the reason for trip was over, there was still more adventure ahead...

Immediate sensory overload. I LOVE this store. If money were no object, this is how my house would look. 

I wanted to buy a few things but I live far away so would not be able to take it with me. Sadly. 

Beautiful store.
Great location. liked this Marriott. Easy in and out to Bourbon street. Room was clean and nice size. Love the beds. For sure will be back.

What can I say, all you can eat buffet restaurants are really polarizing in general. Brazillian Steakhouses are no exception -- not everyone likes or wants all you can eat meat. I'm prone to overeating when given the chance, but when the quality of the food is THIS good, it's not often nearly as bad as it would be otherwise. Still, I much prefer coming to a place like this for lunch or brunch rather than dinner (fewer options means less likelihood of my overeating terribly badly). 

We came here for New Year's Eve Brunch and it was most excellent. Previously I had only ever visited the downtown location of Pampa, but this one is new, and very brightly lit which is quite nice. I like how much space is available around the salad bar, and the food quality is quite excellent. The servers were really helpful as I was there with folks who had never been to this style of restaurant before. I find that the meat is very delicious on the whole, but there's always only a few cuts of meat that I absolutely adore while the others are just OK. It varies on the day. On our visit, I adored the soup (it was good!) the oils and the bread, the French toast, and the fruit and veggies (can't go far wrong with pineapple!).

As we had a late brunch reservation one person in my party was quite disappointed when a customer ahead of him in line took all of the watermelon before he was able to get any (and it wasn't refilled before we left :( ) but that's a pretty minor complaint when it comes to the whole grand scheme of things. I really wish that the delicious cheese buns were available at lunch or brunch as they are my favourite part of supper at Pampa in general! I guess I can't have everything. 

In any case, I love this restaurant though I'm only likely to visit a couple of times a year. I'm quite happy that they do online reservations (and they confirm them frequently -- both on Open Table and via phone call). I was surprised at how many times my reservation was confirmed, especially given that I was traveling over the holidays and got the phone call to confirm my reservation while I was out of the country. Still it was helpful and they really do seem detail-oriented when it comes to customer service at this location!

Beignets and coffee/milk/orange juice, what could be better!  It ended up being our dinner, so a tasty and unhealthy dinner, but what the heck that's what vacation is for.  Surprisingly it was easy to get a group of tables for 10 people.  Quick order, and not a long wait for the food to come.  Surprisingly small pint of TruMoo chocolate milk.  Was expecting the real thing, real milk and that was the only disappointing part of the meal.  Beignets are the bomb and there is nowhere outside of Cafe Du Monde that knows how to make the properly.  Love, love, love coming down here for these crispy fried moist flavorful dough with powdered sugar.

Don't miss this place or one of the other locations in town when you come to New Orleans!

Another quality location for this chain in the Tampa Bay Area that I first discovered in San Antonio, Texas almost two decades ago.

The vast selection of items speaks for itself and the spuds put them ahead of most other "sandwich and more" fast casual dining concepts.

Over time, the spuds have become almost a must have on every visit because they are very filling and a great choice on the Choose 2 menu.

Their selection of soups also stands out to me over similar spots and I haven't found one yet that wasn't worth putting next to my spud of choice for that particular day.

I will say that if you're in the mood for a sandwich, order it as a full size and not as a half or part of the Choose 2. Besides, you get a side item with the full size sandwich and the half is just not large enough on its own even with soup or salad in my opinion.

Another reason I like McAlister's is how the employees seem very relaxed and competent when taking orders, while also very open to questions and special requests. I've always liked the overall attitude and they don't sweat small details and seem to want to make people happy with their orders. 

Maybe it's just me, but I seem to rarely get the forced "Suggestive Sales Tactics" from cashiers at McAlister's. And if they do ask if I want a drink, it is like they're just making sure rather than really trying to sell it to run up my bill.

Oh, and about half of you hate pickles, so you can be gone now. For the rest of us, don't you love how McAlister's has a huge bucket of pickles cut into quarters that customers can just take as they wish? I find this at a number of various places in Texas (Such as Twisted Root), which brings me back to where I first went to a McAlister's in 1998. It was really good on that San Antonio trip and still is now as they've expanded into Florida.

One word - delicious.  We stopped in on a busy Saturday for a cheesesteak and a roast pork hoagie with sharp provolone and spinach.  The buns are fresh and substantial enough that they don't soak through and disintegrate.  The cheesesteak comes on a sesame seed roll which adds such a lovely flavor as the seeds are toasted.  The price is very decent, $8 for a foot-long, cash only.  They also have meatball, roast beef and chicken subs along with sides like kick-ass onion rings.

The service is incredibly friendly and although there isn't a lot of room inside where you're ordering and waiting, they keep it moving right along and there are tables outside (picnic) for eating, but not a lot of seating total.  Again, cash only so be prepared.  It's across the street from Super Fresh, Target, etc. so there's lots of parking.

As i basked in the glow of belly full of deliciousness, husband said - oh, we'll be back.  Definitely.

OK so this review is hard to write.  I want to love this place,  I really really do...  But how can 5/5 visits be terrible???  This was not an off night kind of thing.  Which is why I held off on writing this.  

For Pete's sake hire some servers!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  15mins sitting outside on average before I'd have to go in and ask for a server.  Even though the server walked by me several times.   

Drinks then take 15mins.

Food comes out 50mins later...  Cold!!!  

Overall it's an hour and a half for one drink and a cold sandwich.  

You leave frustrated and feeling completely unappreciated for spending your time and money.  

Please,  just hire some servers.  It's insane that every time I have been there it's one person working and tables are walking out in frustration. 

I really hope yall read this because I'd love to come back in and be proven wrong.

What a great experience! Chef Chris was absolutely awesome. My son and I had a great time and loved the traditional New Orleans fare. It was nice to be able to talk with Chef Chris about his experiences and get some ideas of local places to eat. Thanks Chef Chris! "The sticky bits, that's where it's at!"

Yummy small town chocolate ship that serves chocolates, ice cream and homemade Carmel corn. The Carmel corn is delicious. Ice cream is served up at an old fashioned bar and the place is well air conditioned. I loved the small town, olde time feel of this shop!

I think it's actually pretty funny that someone down there mentioned a chelsea cut, as I've been threatening to get one of them forever, and I feel like Amy gave me a modified chelsea.  And I also don't know what you guys are talking about, saying that Amy doesn't listen to her clients.  She wanted nothing more than tons of input from me, which actually I don't dig that much and had to keep telling her, "just do your thing".  Which is why I ended up with half of my head shaved at the last minute.  My new look is JUST what I needed, I love it, and I think I'm going to become one of those people who is obsessed with shaving their head. 

Plus, how has nobody else mentioned Gogo, the world's most adoring chihuahua?

I went to Mandarin for a private party.  I didn't get the whole experience, but the one that I did made me wanting to go back to check it out.

I say that because I hate trying new clubs!  As far as standards for Mandarin, I wanted to compliment the bartenders, and atmosphere, and bathroom!

The bartenders were super fast and friendly, that could be because we had a smaller group maybe than what they normally see.  Our party was probably 50 people.

The bathroom, clean, and I have seen this before, but I love it, the sink is open to the men's bathroom and th water just falls from the wall into the sink.  Love it!

The atmosphere was very, sophisticated, not a place I would normally go.  I loved the balcony and the variety of seating/tables.  There were pub tables along with alcoves for a little privacy and also more open couches.  My favorite was the balcony over looking the fountain.

I love to play games. Board games, card games, any games..... Add drinking to the equation, even better!  

Tower Pub has trivia on Thursday nights and it is the best around. This is a smoking, bring your own food, dollar bills on the ceiling kind of place so don't come expecting too much.  Although the patrons, bartenders and the trivia hosts are all nice and funny. 

Trivia starts at 8 p.m. but you'll want to get there at least by 7:30 so you get a table. Beers are very inexpensive and they have specials during Cards and Blues games. Trivia prizes include bar cash and some trinkets if you win the spirit award. 

So gather up your smartest friends and head to Tower Pub when you want to take part in a friendly game of trivia!

As a rule, I loathe chain eateries and especially those with order counters.  As exception, I love MOD which is a chain with that ordering set up.  As a rule, I dislike flash fired pizza joints that offer 'all the toppings you want' formats.  (I'm talkin' to you Blaze.)  As exception I love MOD which has this very format.

I'm a MOD fan based on multiple good experiences with MOD outlet in Oregon and my first at this newly opened (roughly mid November) location near Boise Towne Square Mall reinforced why that is so.

That this MOD was "lightly customered" on a weekday at the height of lunch time suggests many mall and Nordstrom Rack shoppers may be unaware this is now open since both are nearby.  But it is.  So here you are.  Now you can go.
